                              Late Edition - Final

Spare Times: For Children

BYLINE: By LAUREL GRAEBER

SECTION: Section C; Column 0; The Arts/Cultural Desk; Pg. 29

LENGTH: 3963 words


Brooklyn Book Festival Children's Day

You expect lots of little bookworms at an event celebrating children's reading.
But at Saturday's fair in Downtown Brooklyn, the guests will also include large
worms that have never read a word.

These two dozen night crawlers are traveling with Kevin McCloskey, author of
''We Dig Worms!'' Mr. McCloskey, who digs them in every way, will read from his
book, discuss the creatures and even feature them in a race: The first to crawl
to the edge of a circular mat wins. His workshop, ''Do You Dig Worms?!,'' is one
highlight of the Brooklyn Book Festival's first Children's Day, for ages 2
through 11. (Adolescents shouldn't despair: The main festival, on Sunday, will
devote a stage to young adult reading.)

''We realized that having a second day would really allow us to expand our
programming,'' said Liz Koch, co-producer of the festival. ''At our past
festivals, we'd have one tent for children. This year, we have two stages and
workshops throughout the day.''

At the New York University Polytechnic School of Engineering Auditorium, the fun
will start with ''What Are You Waiting For?,'' a conversation between the
much-loved authors Jon Scieszka and Kevin Henkes; Mr. Henkes will also read from
his latest work, ''Waiting.'' And all day, a Picture Book Stage outdoors on
MetroTech Commons will offer the youngest visitors readings by 11 authors,
including Drew Daywalt (''The Day the Crayons Quit'') and Edwidge Danticat
(''Mama's Nightingale''). (Above, little readers last year.)

Back in the auditorium, picture-book fans can enjoy a competition (this one's
without worms): In ''Illustrators in Action,'' Kevin Sherry, George O'Connor,
Aimee Sicuro, Kazu Kibuishi, Raúl Colón and Frank Morrison will square off.

''The illustrators are given a general theme, like, say, dinosaurs,'' Ms. Koch
said. ''And someone in the audience might say, 'Eating a hot dog,' '' The
artists respond to the prompts, children vote by applause, ''and the artwork is
given away at the end.''

The Young Readers Stage, also on the commons, will offer six presentations,
among them ''Readers Theater of Mystery and Magic,'' in which Chris Grabenstein,
Tracey Baptiste, Emily Jenkins and Sarah Mlynowski read from scripts adapted
from one another's novels. (They encourage audience participation.)

In addition to Mr. McCloskey and his night crawlers, the five workshops in the
N.Y.U. MetroTech Center will include Esther K Smith teaching how to make pop-up
books and Daniel Nayeri instructing in storytelling. (Both are for children 6
and up.)

What unites all the programming, Ms. Koch said, is that ''it allows kids to see
this magic as it's happening.''

(Saturday, 10 a.m. to 4 p.m., rain or shine. Details are at
brooklynbookfestival.org.)

For Children

'Archaeology Zone: Discovering Treasures From Playgrounds to Palaces'
(Continuing) Children will step into the shoes of an explorer like Indiana Jones
in this permanent exhibition at the Jewish Museum, but the adventures will be
purely scholarly. Still, there is plenty of excitement in analyzing Middle
Eastern artifacts like a jar handle, a clay jug and a bangle and figuring out
the purpose behind ancient pieces like a Greek helmet and a bull-shaped vessel.
This interactive show, for ages 3 to 10, also includes a recreated room from the
Ottoman period (around 1900) where young archaeologists can dress in costume and
portray early-20th-century immigrants to Palestine. 1109 Fifth Avenue, at 92nd
Street, 212-423-3200, thejewishmuseum.org.

'Brooklyn Sewers: What's Up Down There?' (Through May 29) When it comes to
subterranean infrastructure projects, New York City's subway system seems to get
all the attention. But a group of teenage curators at the Brooklyn Historical
Society would like to introduce you to another underground marvel: Brooklyn's
sewer system, one of the city's oldest and most extensive infrastructure
projects. This exhibition explores engineering conundrums and courtroom battles
and tells the story of the sewer system through photographs, drawings and maps.
128 Pierrepont Street, near Clinton Street, Brooklyn Heights, 718-222-4111,
brooklynhistory.org.

Bubble Do Beatles: 'All You Need Is Love' (Sunday) Picture a free Beatles
concert. That may be even harder to imagine than all the people living life in
peace, but Bubble, an esteemed tribute band, plans to come close at this event,
which helps inaugurate a new arts center: the Archbishop Fulton J. Sheen Center
for Thought & Culture. Made up of five musicians -- even though it's devoted to
the Fab Four -- Bubble will focus this free performance on Beatles songs about
love and hope. At 11 a.m., 18 Bleecker Street, at Elizabeth Street, NoHo,
212-925-2812, sheencenter.org.

Children's Museum of the Arts Free Art Island Outpost  (Saturday and Sunday)
This island fun doesn't require a flight to distant shores. The Children's
Museum of the Arts is offering another summer of free weekend workshops on
Governors Island, exploring a variety of crafts and materials. This season's
programs will be devoted to making works that reflect the importance of nature
and parks, and the human role in both. Children will also recycle and reuse
something that often blights nature -- trash -- by turning it into art. (Through
Sept. 27.) From 11 a.m. to 3 p.m., outside Building 14, Nolan Park,
212-274-0986, cmany.org/schoolsandcommunity/free-summer-programs.

'Connected Worlds' (continuing) Human choices and actions have an impact on the
world's ecosystems, but people usually can't see the effects as they happen.
That isn't true in this new permanent exhibition in the renovated Great Hall of
the New York Hall of Science. Consisting of huge screens (one is 38 feet tall),
the show depicts six interconnected environments with a shared water supply.
With the help of technology that responds to gestures, ''Connected Worlds''
allows children to use simple motions to plant, harvest, cut trees, create
clouds and make other changes in the projected landscapes -- and see how the
native flora and fauna fare. 47-01 111th Street, Flushing Meadows-Corona Park,
Queens, 718-699-0005, nysci.org.

Family Art Tour: Teardrop Park (Sunday) New York City doesn't have an active
volcano, but children will be invited to build one at this free event from the
Battery Park City Parks Conservancy, which will lead them in investigating the
intersection of nature and art. Dorothea Basile, an art historian, will help
visitors explore Ann Hamilton's park sculpture, whose overlapping bluestone
panels recall the earth's tectonic plates. Patricia Nadeau, a scientist from the
American Museum of Natural History, will discuss how the movement of these
plates relates to earthquakes and volcanoes. Then children will make individual
clay volcanoes as well as a larger one, which will erupt at the site, courtesy
of a mix of vinegar and baking soda. From 2 to 4 p.m. in the park, accessible
from Warren or Murray Street, Battery Park City, Lower Manhattan, 212-267-9700,
bpcparks.org.

Film Forum Jr.: 'Them!' (Sunday) As summer wanes, you can expect to see fewer
ants, but they will still be numerous -- and giant in size and appetite -- on
screen at Film Forum, which is presenting a new restoration of this 1954
science-fiction thriller. Part of a series developed to introduce classic cinema
to children, the movie belongs to a whole genre that imagined what might happen
to ordinary critters when exposed to radiation. It's not for little ones, but
children over 10 should appreciate seeing what scared their forebears in the
Cold War era. (Series runs through Dec. 27.) At 11 a.m., Film Forum, 209 West
Houston Street, west of Avenue of the Americas, South Village, 212-727-8110,
filmforum.org.

'Frida's Flora and Fauna' and 'Cooking With Frida' (Through Sept. 27) It's time
to say ''Olé!'' to all kinds of fun: The New York Botanical Garden is honoring
the Mexican artist Frida Kahlo (1907-1954) in its exhibition ''Frida Kahlo: Art,
Garden, Life,'' and it offers more than one program to introduce its youngest
visitors to this famous Latina. In ''Frida's Flora and Fauna,'' at the Everett
Children's Adventure Garden, they can go on a plant scavenger hunt; make
self-portraits, as Kahlo often did; play inside the Casita Azul, a model of her
blue house; and put on shows at Frida's Puppet Theater, with puppets
representing her many pets. In ''Cooking With Frida,'' at the Ruth Rea Howell
Family Garden through Nov. 1, children can explore the raw ingredients of
Mexican cuisine and enjoy cooking demonstrations inspired by Kahlo's
entertaining. ''Frida's Flora and Fauna'' runs weekdays from 1:30 to 5:30 p.m.,
and weekends from 10 a.m. to 5:30 p.m.; ''Cooking With Frida'' is on Wednesdays,
Saturdays and Sundays at 2 and 4 p.m.; Bronx River Parkway (Exit 7W) and Fordham
Road, the Bronx, 718-817-8700, nybg.org/frida.

'Frolic!' at the Children's Museum of Manhattan (Through Dec. 31) You're never
too young to rock -- and this space proves it. A new pop-up installation at the
museum, ''Frolic!'' uses rock music and a themed décor to stimulate sensory play
and learning in visitors ages 5 and under. In addition to a stage, a pretend
ticket booth and '70s-style props -- including a Volkswagen mini-van to climb
into -- the 1,500-square-foot area has programs of workshops and live
performances to help little ones get into the groove. (The museum is closed for
fall maintenance, reopening on Thursday.) The Tisch Building, 212 West 83rd
Street, 212-721-1223, cmom.org.

'From Your Mind to Design: Decorate Free School Supplies' (Saturday) A lot of
school supplies are pretty plain and utilitarian, but they don't have to be.
This workshop at the Museum of the City of New York invites children 6 to 12 to
create covers for this year's textbooks. They will draw inspiration from the
show ''Everything Is Design: The Work of Paul Rand,'' which includes that
designer's advertisements, posters and books. From 11 a.m. to 2 p.m., Fifth
Avenue at 103rd Street, East Harlem, 212-534-1672, mcny.org.

'The Gazillion Bubble Show: The Next Generation'  (Friday through Sunday)
Children love bubbles, and this interactive show promises not just a gazillion
but also some of the largest ever blown, along with light effects and lasers.
The stars are the members of the Yang family: Fan and Ana Yang and their son
Deni and others, who rotate as M.C.s for the production. Audience members may
even find themselves in bubbles of their own. (The run is open-ended.) Friday at
7 p.m.; Saturday at 11 a.m. and 2 and 4:30 p.m.; Sunday at noon and 3 p.m.; 340
West 50th Street, Clinton, 212-239-6200, gazillionbubbleshow.com.

'Go Fish!' (Saturday) Not surprisingly, this free event from the Battery Park
City Parks Conservancy focuses on fish, but since this Saturday is also Turtle
Day, the celebration will honor those creatures, too. Master anglers will help
children cast lines with barbless hooks into New York Bay, and all fish will be
placed in tanks and identified and observed before heading back to their homes.
Naturalists from the Theodore Roosevelt Sanctuary will present a program with
live turtles, discussing their evolution and life cycles; young visitors can
handle turtle shells and skulls. The day will also include a drop-in
turtle-related art project; a bird-watching walk; and a performance of ''Hook,
Line and Sinker: Fishing the Hudson River,'' the latest show by Arm-of-the-Sea
Theater, in which giant puppets plumb the river's identity. From 10 a.m. to 2
p.m., Robert F. Wagner Jr. Park, Battery Park City (access at Battery Place),
Lower Manhattan, 212-267-9700, bpcparks.org.

Hispanic Heritage Family Day (Saturday) This weekend Central and South America
are as close as Lower Manhattan, thanks to this free celebration at the
Smithsonian Institution's National Museum of the American Indian. Children can
embrace life in the Amazon jungle by decorating jaguar masks, coloring creature
pendants and making animal buttons. They can also investigate the roles of
important crops in those regions by watching corn-grinding demonstrations and
the documentary ''The Chocolate Farmer.'' From noon to 4 p.m., 1 Bowling Green,
212-514-3700, nmai.si.edu.

Hudson River Park Wild! (Sunday) There are plenty of wild things in New York,
and not just the ones you meet on the street. Hudson River Park invites young
people and their families to learn about the area's native plants and insects,
as well as the more than 85 species of birds that live within the park's
boundaries. Experienced naturalists lead these free hourlong walks every Sunday
through September. At 9 a.m., meeting at the Christopher Street Fountain, north
of Pier 40, Christopher Street and the West Side Highway, West Village,
hudsonriverpark.org.

'The Hunger Games: The Exhibition' (Through Jan. 3) What enterprising 12- or
13-year-old wouldn't like to foment a little rebellion? Such a visitor can do so
vicariously at this attraction at Discovery Times Square, stepping into the role
of Katniss Everdeen, the teenage heroine of ''The Hunger Games'' and the
ultimate leader of the resistance against her nation's totalitarian government.
Based on the Lionsgate film adaptations of Suzanne Collins's novels, the show
includes costumes and artifacts from the movies, as well as re-creations of
Katniss's journey and interactive, role-playing elements like a gamesmaker's
table and a chance to learn and practice stunt choreography. 226 West 44th
Street, Manhattan, 866-987-9692, discoverytsx.com, thehungergamesexhibition.com.

'If You Lived Here, You'd Be Home' (Through Jan. 17) Maps present facts, but
they can also engage the imagination. This new exhibition at the Children's
Museum of the Arts explores the intersection of cartography and art, showing
work that expands upon, redefines or simply refers to maps. Among the eight
artists represented are Matthew Cusik, who makes collages from map fragments;
Joyce Kosloff, who layers images and textured paint onto maps; Loren Munk, who
adds plaques of color and information to street maps; and Nikki Rosato, who
subtracts from maps, cutting away all but roads and rivers. In the museum's
Cynthia C. Wainwright Gallery, 103 Charlton Street, between Hudson and Greenwich
Streets, South Village, 212-274-0986, cmany.org.

'Jack and the Beanstalk' (Saturday and Sunday) Many plants grow in Central Park,
so why not a beanstalk? This one sprouts indoors at the Swedish Cottage
Marionette Theater, which has revived Michael Alogna's adaptation of the classic
fairy tale about Jack, the Giant (here named Milford), Dolly the Cow and the
famous Golden Goose. Bruce Cannon, the theater's artistic director, has revised
the script, and a human actor now also stars in the show, which closes this
weekend. Reservations required. At 1 p.m., 79th Street and the West Drive,
Central Park; 212-988-9093, cityparksfoundation.org/arts.

'Jean-Michel Cousteau's Secret Ocean' (Friday through Thursday) Ever encounter a
goby or a blenny? How about a Christmas tree worm? These small marine species,
often unnoticed and uncelebrated, are among the stars of this new Imax movie at
the American Museum of Natural History. Filmed by Jean-Michel Cousteau, son of
the ocean explorer Jacques Cousteau, and Holly Lohuis, a marine biologist, the
film captures 30 species that are among the tiniest to inhabit the seas.
(Through Jan. 10.) Hourly from 10:30 a.m. to 4:30 p.m., with 2-D screenings at
11:30 a.m. and 4:30 p.m.; all other screenings are 3-D. Central Park West and
79th Street, 212-769-5200, amnh.org.

Kite Festival (Saturday) This weekend, sailing will take place in the air as
well as on the waterfront at Brooklyn Bridge Park. This festival will offer
kites for sale, or families can take their favorites from home. The free event
is on the Harbor View Lawn, so pack a picnic. (Cameras are suggested, too.) From
11 a.m. to 3 p.m., Pier 1, Brooklyn Bridge Park, Old Fulton Street, at Furman
Street, Dumbo, Brooklyn, brooklynbridgepark.org.

'The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe'  (Saturday) If the children of the
Pevensie family could travel to the magical land of Narnia through something as
simple as a wardrobe, why shouldn't two hard-working actors be able to play them
and all the characters found there? That's what Chris Boerner and Erin Layton
are attempting in the Off Broadway Family Theater's first production, le Clanché
du Rand's adaptation of C. S. Lewis's classic novel. (The run is open-ended and
continues on Saturdays.) At 11 a.m., St. Luke's Theater, 308 West 46th Street,
Clinton, 212-239-6200, narniaoffbroadway.com.

Mid-Autumn Moon Festival (Saturday) You've probably heard of the cow that jumped
over the moon, but what about the jade rabbit that actually lives there? That
rabbit, a beautiful woman and a brave archer all play roles in the mythology
behind the Mid-Autumn Moon Festival, a Chinese holiday being celebrated at the
Museum of Chinese in America. In addition to hearing the tale, young visitors
can take part in activities that include a moon-theme scavenger hunt; an
investigation and tasting of mooncakes, a traditional confection; and drop-in
workshops to make lanterns, moon paintings and shadow puppets. Chinese Theater
Works will also present ''Tiger Tales,'' a shadow-puppetry production. Noon to 4
p.m., 215 Centre Street, between Howard and Grand Streets, Lower Manhattan,
212-619-4785, mocanyc.org. Space is limited, and advance ticket purchase is
recommended.

Music in Motion (Saturday) That motion is the gentle rocking of a boat for this
series of family neighborhood concerts presented by Bargemusic, the floating
barge at the foot of the Brooklyn Bridge. As always, the material -- announced
just before the performance -- is chamber music, but these programs differ in
important ways from the regular Bargemusic fare: With unreserved seating, they
last only an hour, include a post-show question-and-answer session with the
musicians and are free. (Through Nov. 28.) At 4 p.m. (doors open at 3:45),
Fulton Ferry Landing, next to the Brooklyn Bridge, Brooklyn, 800-838-3006,
bargemusic.org.

Prospect Park Audubon Center Nature Programs (Saturday and Sunday) There's a
whole woodland of wildlife to be discovered in Prospect Park in Brooklyn, and
the park's Audubon Center has increased its Pop-Up Audubon programs, weekends
from 10 a.m. to 3 p.m., to include two tents with themed nature investigations
in different parts of the park. At the Zucker Natural Exploration Area, whose
September theme is ''Radical Raptors,'' children can learn about migrating birds
of prey, and get an opportunity to dissect an owl pellet; at the tent in the
Nethermead, whose theme is ''Climate Clues,'' they can explore how environmental
change affects the park's ecosystems. Both tents feature nature walks and
opportunities to help the environment. The center is at the boathouse, near the
Lincoln Road and Ocean Avenue park entrance, 718-287-3400, prospectpark.org. All
activities are free.

Shinnyo Lantern Floating for Peace (Sunday) As the saying goes, it is better to
light a candle than to curse the darkness. At this free event, taking place one
day before the International Day of Peace, Shinnyo-en, a Buddhist organization,
invites families to Lincoln Center to make lanterns which they'll inscribe with
individual messages promoting harmony and understanding. The lanterns,
illuminated with LED candles, will be set afloat in the Paul Milstein Reflecting
Pool. The celebration, which culminates with a Buddhist ceremony at dusk, will
also offer performances, including taiko drummers; Decadancetheatre, a hip-hop
crew; and Misty Copeland, principal dancer with American Ballet Theater. From 1
to 8 p.m., Hearst Plaza, 40 Lincoln Center Plaza, between Broadway and Amsterdam
Avenue, bealightforpeace.org.

'Stand Clear of the Closing Doors, Please' (Sunday) When a toy is lost on the
subway, it's usually gone for good. But in this interactive play for
preschoolers, the toy, Catbear, finds its own way home. Presented by Spellbound
Theater, Catbear's journey involves a miniature New York landscape and six
subway lines, each with its own tale. Each 35-minute performance is preceded by
15 minutes of craft activities for small theatergoers. At 10 and 11:15 a.m., Old
Stone House, 336 Third Street, between Fourth and Fifth Avenues, Park Slope,
Brooklyn, brownpapertickets.com/event/2260201.

Stories at the Statue of Hans Christian Andersen  (Saturday) Not everything that
blooms perennially in Central Park is a flower or a tree. Storytelling also
returns there each summer, as the city's Parks and Recreation Department, the
Central Park Conservancy and the Hans Christian Andersen Storytelling Center
bring narrative performers to Andersen's statue every Saturday. The free series,
for ages 6 and older, continues this Saturday with Jim May and Peter Stevenson
telling tales from Haiti and Wales. (Through Sept. 26.) At 11 a.m., inside the
park at 72nd Street and Fifth Avenue, rain or shine, hcastorycenter.org.

Sunday Story Time in Mr. Morgan's Library (Sunday) That Mr. Morgan is none other
than Pierpont (1837-1913), whose library is now a cozy museum. Children ages 3
through 6 are invited there on Sundays to hear about Alice's amazing trip to
Wonderland and what she found there. The program relates to the museum's show
''Alice: 150 Years of Wonderland,'' which includes the book's original
manuscript, along with illustrations and other vintage objects that young
visitors can see in a brief visit after the story. (Through Oct. 11.) From 3 to
4 p.m., 225 Madison Avenue, at 36th Street, 212-685-0008, themorgan.org.

'Superbunny's Pirate Vacation' (Friday through Sunday) And you thought only
parrots hung out with pirates. In this new musical, based on a book series by
Amber L. Spradlin, Superbunny encounters the buccaneers while he's trying to
save the polluted and trash-filled waters off a tropical island. (He's a bit of
an eco-warrior as well as a superhero.) This busy bunny's adventures -- which
also involve the audience members, who can sing along in a number with the
pirates -- are brought to the stage by the appropriately named Rabbit Hole
Theatricks. The production has a book and lyrics by Michael MacKenzie Wills and
music by Alastair William King. Free performances are on Friday at 11 a.m.;
Saturday and Sunday at 2 p.m.; the Actors Fund Arts Center, 160 Schermerhorn
Street, between Smith and Hoyt Streets, Boerum Hill, Brooklyn, 917-563-9830,
rabbitholetheatricks.org.

'A Taste of Magic' (Saturday) Would you like a side of sleight of hand with that
burger? This show, developed by Magnets, a collective of local magicians, brings
wizardry to the dinner table. Taking place at various restaurants, the
presentation includes acts like mind reading and card tricks, which
professionals perform close-up for guests; there's also a cabaret-style show.
And the admission price includes a full meal. (Through Nov. 24.) At 8 p.m., Ben
& Jack's Steakhouse, 225 Fifth Avenue, between 28th and 29th Streets,
atasteofmagicnyc.com.

'A Voyage Through Jewish History'  (Continuing) This journey involves not just
miles, but years. In this permanent interactive exhibition at the Jewish
Children's Museum, young visitors can travel from Abraham and Sarah's tent to
the Western Wall in contemporary Jerusalem and beyond. Activities along the way
include giving water to Rebecca's camels, playing the strings on David's harp (a
high-tech version with beams of light that emit sounds when struck) and taking
part in the exodus from Egypt. (The museum is closed from Tuesday through Sept.
29 because of Jewish holidays.) 792 Eastern Parkway, at Kingston Avenue, Crown
Heights, Brooklyn, 718-907-8833, jcm.museum. LAUREL GRAEBER

http://www.nytimes.com/2015/09/18/arts/spare-times-for-children-for-sept-18-24.h

(89%); NOVELS & SHORT STORIES (78%); ADOLESCENTS (74%); ARTISTS & PERFORMERS
(73%); FICTION LITERATURE (73%); VISUAL ARTISTS (66%)

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (93%)

                              89 of 259 DOCUMENTS


                               The New York Times

                           September 18, 2015 Friday
                              Late Edition - Final

The Listings: Theater

BYLINE: By THE NEW YORK TIMES

SECTION: Section C; Column 0; The Arts/Cultural Desk; Pg. 15

LENGTH: 4658 words


Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless
otherwise noted. Full reviews of current productions, additional listings,
showtimes and ticket information are at nytimes.com/theater. A searchable,
critical guide to theater is at nytimes.com/events.

Previews and Openings

BAM Next Wave  (performances start on Thursday) The surf is high in Brooklyn
with the launch of this autumnal festival of experimental performance work. This
year's lineup includes the director Ivo van Hove's ''Antigone,'' starring
Juliette Binoche; fresh material from the nouveau-cirque artist James Thierrée;
a participatory performance piece form Miranda July and new work from Anne
Bogart, Carl Hancock Rux and Kia Corthron. Various locations on the Brooklyn
Academy of Music campus, Fort Greene, 718-636-4100, bam.org. (Alexis Soloski)

'Barbecue' (previews start on Tuesday; opens on Oct. 8) There's more than meat
that's cooking in Robert O'Hara's comedy at the Public Theater. Mr. O'Hara's
''Bootycandy,'' a hit last season, satirized race and sexuality. This new play,
which begins at an awkward party disguising an intervention, joyfully roasts
family, addiction, art and fame. The director Kent Gash brings the lighter
fluid. 425 Lafayette Street at Astor Place, East Village, 212-967-7555,
publictheater.org. (Soloski)

'Clever Little Lies'  (previews start on Friday, opens on Oct. 12) Joe
DiPietro's last comedy, ''Living on Love,'' expired quickly on Broadway, but
maybe he'll serve an ace with this show, which debuted at the George Street
Playhouse. When a father returns from a tennis game with his married son, he
brings troubling news. It's up to matriarch Alice (Marlo Thomas) to save the
match. Westside Theater Upstairs, 407 West 43rd Street, 212-239-6200,
cleverlittlelies.com. (Soloski)

'Cloud Nine'  (in previews; opens on Oct. 5) A fantasia of sex and sovereignty,
empire and dissolution, Caryl Churchill's landmark play arrives at the Atlantic
Theater under James Macdonald's direction. Set in Victorian Africa and 1979
London, the play explores shifting power dynamics and sexual mores. The cast
includes Brooke Bloom, Sean Dugan, Lucy Owen and Chris Perfetti. Linda Gross
Theater, 336 West 20th Street, Chelsea, 866-811-4111, atlantictheater.org.
(Soloski)

'Daddy Long Legs'  (in previews; opens on Sept. 28) In John Caird and Paul
Gordon's two-character musical, an adaptation of the Jean Webster novel of the
same name, an anonymous benefactor sends an orphan girl to school. The only
catch: She has to write him a letter every month. And this was a time when you
couldn't just let predictive messaging and emojis do all the work. Megan
McGinnis and Paul Alexander Nolan conduct the epistolary romance. Davenport
Theater, 354 West 45th Street, 212-239-6200, daddylonglegsmusical.com. (Soloski)

'Dames at Sea'  (previews start on Thursday; opens on Oct. 22) Broadway, ahoy!
Nearly 50 years after it docked at Caffe Cino, this parody of 1930s movie
musicals and the sailors and chorus girls who populated them is dropping anchor
on Broadway. The director and choreographer Randy Skinner captains a cast that
includes John Bolton, Mara Davi and Lesli Margherita. Helen Hayes Theater, 240
West 44th Street, 212-239-6200, damesatseabroadway.com. (Soloski)

'Fondly, Collette Richland'  (in previews; opens on Sept. 28) The hills are
alive with the sound of Sibyl Kempson. The Downtown playwright makes her New
York Theater Workshop debut with this play, in collaboration with Elevator
Repair Service. Set mainly in a grand hotel somewhere in the Alps, it concerns
political insurrection, public radio and the milk of a mysterious pig dog. John
Collins directs the bizarre travelogue. 79 East Fourth Street, East Village,
212-460-5475, nytw.org. (Soloski)

'Fool for Love'  (in previews; opens on Oct. 8) What remains of the West when
the prairies have been paved, the buffalo no longer roam and the only thing a
cowboy can lasso is a bedpost? Sam Shepard explores this decline in his romantic
drama about May and Eddie, former lovers who may also be current siblings. Under
Daniel Aukin's direction, Nina Arianda and Sam Rockwell reprise the roles they
first essayed at the Williamstown Theater Festival last summer. Samuel J.
Friedman Theater, 261 West 47th Street, 212-239-6200, foolforlovebroadway.com.
(Soloski)

'Fulfillment'  (in previews; opens on Monday) Thomas Bradshaw, a playwright who
prides himself on an unstinting devotion to the id, has explored dark territory
before -- slavery, fanaticism, crises of faith. But now he is taking on perhaps
his most threatening subject yet: New York real estate. In this play, directed
by Ethan McSweeny, a successful lawyer sees his life upended when he buys an
apartment. Flea Theater, 41 White Street, TriBeCa, 866-811-4111, theflea.org.
(Soloski)

'The Gin Game'  (previews start on Wednesday; opens on Oct. 14) When it comes to
career, James Earl Jones and Cicely Tyson have both played their cards very
well. With any luck their winning streak will continue when they star in the
Broadway revival of D. L. Coburn's Pulitzer prizewinner. They play two nursing
home residents confronting life, loss and regret over hands of gin rummy. Golden
Theater, 252 West 45th Street, 212-239-6200, thegingamebroadway.com. (Soloski)

'A Midsummer Night's Dream' (in previews; opens on Sunday) The course of true
love never did run smooth. Will it be especially bumpy when Bedlam Theater's
Eric Tucker attempts it with just five actors? In a production that originally
played the Hudson Shakespeare Festival, a small cast, including the Pearl
Company members Sean McNall and Joey Parsons, plays all the lovers, fairies,
mechanicals, courtiers and more. Pearl Theater, 555 West 42nd Street,
212-563-9261, pearltheatre.org. (Soloski)

'MotherStruck'  (previews start on Thursday; opens on Oct. 7) When the slam poet
Staceyann Chin turned 35, she realized she wanted a baby. She didn't have a
partner or substantial savings, but she embarked on fertility treatments and has
transformed her successful trek to motherhood into a one-woman show. The
director Cynthia Nixon is midwife to this work, presented by Culture Project and
Rosie O'Donnell. Lynn Redgrave Theater at Culture Project, 45 Bleecker Street,
near Lafayette Street, East Village, 866-811-4111, cultureproject.org. (Soloski)

'The New Morality'  (in previews; opens Monday) Harold Chapin's life was not
especially funny. He died as a stretcher-bearer in France during World War I.
But before that early death, he wrote several droll plays, including this
marital comedy, revived by the Mint Theater. A houseboat on the Thames is not a
home to domestic bliss when a wife accuses a neighbor of dallying with her
husband. 311 West 43rd Street, 866-811-4111, minttheater.org. (Soloski)

'Old Times' (in previews; opens on Oct. 6) It's new times for the improbably
suave actor Clive Owen as he makes his Broadway debut in this Harold Pinter
play. He'll play Deeley, a man whose life is upended by a visit from his wife's
former roommate. Or is she something more? Or less? Douglas Hodge directs a cast
that also includes Eve Best and Kelly Reilly. American Airlines Theater, 227
West 42nd Street, 212-719-1300, roundabouttheatre.org. (Soloski)

'The Quare Land'  (previews start on Tuesday; opens on Oct. 1) In this play at
the Irish Rep, a farmer with a relaxed approach to hygiene takes his first bath
in four years. He spends his time in the tub wrangling with a property developer
desperate to buy his field. The actors Peter Maloney and Rufus Collins and the
director Ciarán O'Reilly have a soak in John McManus's drama. DR2 Theater, 103
East 15th Street, 212-727-2737, irishrep.org. (Soloski)

'Spring Awakening'  (in previews; opens on Sept. 27) Plenty of teenagers don't
listen to their parents. Especially the adolescents populating Duncan Sheik and
Steven Sater's musical adaptation of the Frank Wedekind play. But metaphors of
speech, silence and communication should feel particularly rich when Deaf West
brings its new production, which is performed in sign language and spoken
English, to Broadway. Brooks Atkinson Theater, 256 West 47th Street,
877-250-2929. springawakeningthemusical.com. (Soloski)

'Ugly Lies the Bone'  (in previews; opens on Oct. 13) Jess has been scarred by
her tours of duty in Afghanistan. Some of these scars are visible -- the weals
and puckers and grafts that mark her face and body -- and some go deeper. In
Lindsey Ferrentino's play, part of Roundabout Underground, Mamie Gummer's Jess
attempts to heal, with a little help from virtual reality. Harold and Miriam
Steinberg Center for Theater, Black Box Theater, 111 West 46th Street,
roundabouttheatre.org, 212-719-1300. (Soloski)

Broadway

'Amazing Grace'  The unusual life story of John Newton (a jaunty Josh Young),
the Englishman who wrote the lyrics to the titular hymn -- he matured from slave
trader and scapegrace to fervently religious clergyman -- is explored in this
earnest but somewhat overstuffed musical with music and lyrics by Christopher
Smith and book by Mr. Smith and Arthur Giron (2:30). Nederlander Theater, 208
West 41st Street, 877-250-2929, amazinggracemusical.com. (Charles Isherwood)

? 'An American in Paris' The ballet luminary Christopher Wheeldon makes a
triumphant debut as a Broadway director with this rhapsodic stage adaptation of
a classic musical with a heavenly Gershwin score. The ballet dancers Robert
Fairchild and Leanne Cope, as the semi-star-crossed lovers, are radiant, and Max
von Essen sings like a dream as an heir who aspires to a nightclub career. Pure
joy (2:30). The Palace Theater. 1564 Broadway, at 47th Street, 877-250-2929,
ticketmaster.com. (Isherwood)

? 'The Curious Incident of the Dog in the Night-Time'  Simon Stephens's
adaptation of Mark Haddon's best-selling novel, about an autistic boy's
coming-of-age, is one of the most fully immersive works ever to wallop Broadway.
Be prepared to have all your emotional and sensory buttons pushed. Marianne
Elliott (''War Horse'') directs the excellent cast, led by Alex Sharp, and the
dazzling technical team (2:25). Ethel Barrymore Theater, 243 West 47th Street,
curiousonbroadway.com, 212-239-6200. (Ben Brantley)

'Finding Neverland'  This musical adaptation of the 2004 biopic about J. M.
Barrie, the creator of ''Peter Pan,'' heightens the film's tidy psychologizing
and life-affirming messages by thickening their syrup and corn quotients. The
show brings to mind those supersize sodas sold in movie theaters. It's mostly
empty calories. Diane Paulus directs a cast led by Matthew Morrison (2:30).
Lunt-Fontanne Theater, 205 West 46th Street, 877-250-2929, ticketmaster.com.
(Brantley)

? 'Fun Home'  This extraordinary musical memory play about a girl and her
father, adapted by Jeanine Tesori (music) and Lisa Kron (book and lyrics) from
Alison Bechdel's graphic novel, occupies that mysterious place where we all grew
up -- the shifting landscape governed by those contradictory creatures, our
parents. Sam Gold directs a nigh-flawless cast in a show that brings fresh
oxygen to Broadway (1:40). Circle in the Square Theater, 1633 Broadway, at 50th
Street, funhomebroadway.com, 212-239-6200. (Brantley)

? 'Hamilton'  Yes, it really is that good. Lin-Manuel Miranda's rap-driven
portrait of the rise and fall of Alexander Hamilton, directed by Thomas Kail,
makes us feel the unstoppable, urgent rhythm of a nation being born. A show that
changes the language of the American musical, while offering resounding evidence
that this beleaguered genre is not only surviving but thriving (2:45). Richard
Rodgers Theater, 226 West 46th Street, 877-250-2929, hamiltonbroadway.com.
(Brantley)

? 'Hand to God' Robert Askins's black comedy, about a mild Christian boy whose
hand puppet may (or may not) be possessed by the Devil, is as outlandishly funny
as it is seriously spooky. Steven Boyer gives a bravura performance as the
troubled teenager with the evil imp on his arm, and Geneva Carr is moving as his
addled, newly widowed mother. The play, previously seen in two Off Broadway
runs, has grown even sharper, and more disturbing, in its move uptown to
Broadway (2:00). Booth Theater, 222 West 45th Street, 212-239-6200,
handtogodbroadway.com. (Isherwood)

? 'The King and I'  Bartlett Sher's resplendent revival of this Rodgers and
Hammerstein classic, set in the royal court of 19th-century Siam, is both
panoramic and personal, balancing epic sweep with intimate sensibility, lavish
set pieces with exquisitely sung soliloquies. Kelli O'Hara's Anna Leonowens is
something wonderful indeed (2:50). Vivian Beaumont Theater, Lincoln Center,
212-239-6200, lct.org. (Brantley)

'Something Rotten!' This rambunctious show, which weds the Elizabethan theater
and the brassy Broadway musical, dances dangerously on the line between tireless
and tedious. But the large cast, which includes Brian D'Arcy James and Christian
Borle, remains as wired as Adderall-popping sophomores during exam week. Casey
Nicholaw directed this exhausting frolic from Wayne and Karey Kirkpatrick, and
John O'Farrell (2:20). St. James Theater, 246 West 44th Street, 212-239-6200,
rottenbroadway.com. (Brantley)

Off Broadway

? 'The Absolute Brightness of Leonard Pelkey'  In James Lecesne's enchanting
solo show, the friends of a happily flamboyant 14-year-old New Jersey boy turn
to the police after he disappears. With great heart and humor, Mr. Lecesne
portrays more than a dozen characters in this sweet, sad, Dickensian show that
returns to the stage after a run at Dixon Place earlier this year. Westside
Theater, 407 West 43rd Street, absolutebrightnessplay.com, 212-239-6200.
(Isherwood)

'Desire: An Evening of Plays Based on Six Stories by Tennessee Williams'  Six
playwrights, including John Guare, Beth Henley and Rebecca Gilman, adapt
Tennessee Williams short stories (mostly written in the 1940s) in this uneven
but mostly uninspired collection of short plays directed by Michael Wilson
(2:20). 59E59 Theaters, 59 East 59th Street, 212-279-4200, 59e59.org.
(Isherwood)

? 'Drop Dead Perfect'  Returning in a production that played last year, Everett
Quinton is in his old Ridiculous Theatrical Company glory days as a repressed
Florida spinster in this farcical thriller, with tons of TV and old-movie
melodrama, silly double entendres and a Cuban hunk named Ricardo (1:30). Theater
at St. Clement's, 423 West 46th Street, Clinton, 845-786-2873,
dropdeadperfect.com. (Gates)

? 'The Flick' Annie Baker's Pulitzer Prize-winning play about the beauty and
sadness in the lives of three workers in a run-down movie theater has been
remounted under the deeply focused direction of Sam Gold. Moving, funny,
unforgettable, but definitely a polarizing night at the theater, thanks to Ms.
Baker's quietly observational pacing (3:10). Barrow Street Theater, 27 Barrow
Street, at Seventh Avenue South, West Village, 212-868-4444,
barrowstreettheatre.com. (Isherwood)

'Isolde' This play about a romantic triangle, from the experimental auteur
Richard Maxwell, returns after having its United States premiere at Abrons Arts
Center in 2014. Taking place, more or less, in a drawing room, Mr. Maxwell's
play encourages us to see a hoary theatrical form with X-ray eyes -- to look for
the plasterboard behind the wallpaper and the skull beneath the skin (1:25).
Theater for a New Audience, Polonsky Shakespeare Center, 262 Ashland Place,
between Lafayette Avenue and Fulton Street, Fort Greene, Brooklyn, 866-811-4111,
tfana.org. (Brantley)

'Judy'  The title character never makes an appearance in Max Posner's
pretentious puzzle of a play. And one is thankful, since the rest of the bunch
in this dystopic comedy-drama are extraordinarily wearisome company (2:00). New
Ohio Theater, 154 Christopher Street, West Village, 866-811-4111, page73.org.
(Isherwood)

'Laugh It Up, Stare It Down' An existentialist attempt at light romantic comedy,
Alan Hruska's quaintly absurdist play follows Joe (Jayce Bartok) and Cleo (Katya
Campbell) from first date to probable death. There's a lot of whimsy here and it
would grow more wearing if not for the extravagant pace of Chris Eigeman's
direction and the brisk brightness of the performances (1:30). Cherry Lane
Theater, 38 Commerce Street, West Village, 866-811-4111, laughitupplay.com.
(Soloski)

? 'The Legend of Georgia McBride' An Elvis impersonator (the winning Dave Thomas
Brown) finds a more lucrative calling when he puts on a dress and heels and
becomes a drag star under the tutelage of a maternal mentor, Miss Tracy (the
superb Matt McGrath), in Matthew Lopez's light, sweet comedy (1:45). Lucille
Lortel Theater, 121 Christopher Street, West Village, 866-811-4111,
mcctheater.org. (Isherwood)

'Little Thing, Big Thing' The nun and the ex-con are a mismatched duo on the
lam, but Donal O'Kelly's well-populated two-hander is not the moldy caper you
might expect. Performed by Mr. O'Kelly and the impeccable Sorcha Fox, the
sometimes too-loose production by Dublin's Fishamble: The New Play Company is a
cloak-and-dagger comedy with a social conscience. Part of Origin Theater's First
Irish Festival (1:20). 59E59 Theaters, 59 East 59th Street, Manhattan,
212-279-4200, 59e59.org. (Laura Collins-Hughes)

'Love & Money'  A.R. Gurney's slender new comedy-drama finds a well-to-do woman,
played by Maureen Anderman, making plans to give away her considerable fortune
to charity -- she's decided too much money is a curse -- until a young man
(Gabriel Brown) arrives on her doorstep claiming to be a previously unknown
grandson (1:15). Pershing Square Signature Center, 480 West 42nd Street,
212-244-7529, signaturetheatre.org. (Isherwood)

? 'Mercury Fur'  Even those who binge on apocalyptic splatter movies are likely
to be rattled by Philip Ridley's portrait of savage revels in a war-ravaged New
York City. But this New Group production, directed by Scott Elliott, is a
penetrating analysis of how a culture shaped by violence transforms its
inhabitants. It's as intelligent as it is lurid (2:00). Pershing Square
Signature Center, 480 West 42nd Street, Clinton, 212-279-4200, thenewgroup.org.
(Brantley)

'My Son the Waiter: A Jewish Tragedy' Brad Zimmerman's solo show about almost
three decades of working in restaurants while not becoming a famous actor, and
his Jewish mother's shame, is low-key, half-familiar, half-mordant and pretty
delicious (1:30). Stage 72, 158 West 72nd Street, 212-868-4444,
mysonthewaiter.com. (Anita Gates)

'Ruthless!' This spiked Shirley Temple of a show, which first opened in 1992 and
now returns with less fizz, follows the adventures of Tina Denmark (Tori
Murray), a stage-struck prepubescent with occasional homicidal tendencies. But
what must have once seemed wildly satirical could practically pass for
documentary (1:35). St. Luke's Theater, 308 West 46th Street, Clinton,
212-239-6200, ruthlessthemusical.com. (Soloski)

? '39 Steps' This century's most tireless and high-profile example of the little
show that could, adapted from Alfred Hitchcock's 1935 movie and seen on Broadway
in 2008, returns for yet another antic struggle with bad guys with bad accents.
Directed by Maria Aitken, with a cast of four playing too many roles to count,
this paradigm of bare-bones theater remains indomitably funny (1:40). Union
Square Theater, 100 East 17th Street, 877-250-2929, 39stepsny.com. (Brantley)

? 'Whorl Inside a Loop' The Broadway veteran Sherie Rene Scott, in collaboration
with Dick Scanlan (co-writer and co-director) and Michael Mayer (co-director),
returns to the autobiographical form (well, semi-autobiographical) in this
moving and funny play about her experience working with convicts confronting
their ugly pasts through verbal storytelling (1:40). Second Stage Theater, 305
West 43rd Street, 212-246-4422, 2st.com. (Isherwood)

Off Off Broadway

? 'Empire Travel Agency'  This gloriously inventive and appallingly fun
theatrical scavenger hunt is easily the most ambitious and fully realized work
yet from Woodshed Collective. You and three others will dash from location to
location, trying to prevent a mysterious substance from leaching out of New
York. Part Paul Auster, part Alan Moore and part Dan Brown (probably too much
Dan Brown), it's a trip. Take it. Undisclosed location, empiretravelagency.com.
(Soloski)

'Genet Porno' A play in which a pair of rubber phalluses are the most credible
and intriguing performers, Yvan Greenberg's misbegotten performance piece
combines Jean Genet's novel ''Our Lady of the Flowers'' with a pornography
star's YouTube diary. The flaccid result is baldly puerile and aggressively dull
(1:20). Here, 145 Avenue of the Americas, at Dominick Street, South Village,
212-352-3101, here.org. (Soloski)

'Our Last Game' Ed Schmidt delivers three locker room speeches to his basketball
team in a show that hustles but lacks star power (1:20). Nord Anglia
International School, 44 East Second Street, East Village, ourlastgame.com.
(Zinoman)

'Ziegfeld's Midnight Frolic' The death by poison of Olive Thomas, the ''Ziegfeld
Follies'' beauty, is at the center of this diffuse, immersive show created by
Cynthia von Buhler (''The Bloody Beginning''). The cast is talented, the
costumes are glittery, and aerialists dangle from above, but the performance
feels less like a theater piece than like an imitation 1920s cabaret show with a
thematically related art installation taking place around it (2:45). (Saturdays
only.) Liberty Theater, behind the Liberty Diner, 234 West 42nd Street,
866-811-4111, speakeasydollhouse.com. (Laura Collins-Hughes)


Long-Running Shows

'Aladdin'  The Disney movie refashioned for the stage, with shtick, sparkles and
silliness cutting the syrup (2:20). New Amsterdam Theater, 214 West 42nd Street,
866-870-2717, aladdinthemusical.com.

'Avenue Q' R-rated puppets give lively life lessons (2:15). New World Stages,
340 West 50th Street, 212-239-6200, telecharge.com.

'Beautiful: The Carole King Musical'  Becoming Carole King, song by song by song
(2:25). Stephen Sondheim Theater, 124 West 43rd Street, 212-239-6200,
telecharge.com.

'The Berenstain Bears Live! In Family Matters, the Musical' An adaptation of
three of Stan and Jan Berenstain's children's books (:55). Saturdays and
Sundays, Manhattan Movement & Arts Center, 248 West 60th Street, Manhattan,
866-811-4111, berenstainbearslive.com.

'Black Angels Over Tuskegee' The tear-jerker story of these trailblazing
African-American pilots (2:30). (Sundays only.) Actors Temple Theater, 339 West
47th Street, Clinton, 212-239-6200, telecharge.com.

Blue Man Group Conceptual art as entertainment (1:45). Astor Place Theater, 434
Lafayette Street, East Village, 800-258-3626, ticketmaster.com.

'The Book of Mormon' Singing, dancing, R-rated missionaries proselytize for the
American musical (2:15). Eugene O'Neill Theater, 230 West 49th Street,
212-239-6200, telecharge.com.

'Celebrity Autobiography'  (Saturday) Celebrities read selections of the witless
wisdom culled from the tell-all tomes of the rich and famous. Saturday
edition's, part of First Irish festival, features Michael Urie, Geraldine
Hughes, Tate Donovan, Jackie Hoffman, Alan Zweibel, Eugene Pack and Dayle
Reyfell. At 9:30 p.m., Stage 72 at the Triad Theater, 158 West 72nd Street,
celebrityautobiography.com.

'Chicago' Jazz Age sex, murder and razzle-dazzle (2:25). Ambassador Theater, 219
West 49th Street, 212-239-6200, telecharge.com.

'The Fantasticks' Boy meets girl, forever (2:05). Snapple Theater Center, 210
West 50th Street, 800-745-3000, ticketmaster.com.

'Fuerza Bruta' This shiny, sensory-overload spectacle from the creators of ''De
la Guarda'' is rife with not especially impressive acrobatics, throbbing music,
many-colored lights and high winds from machines set at storm speed (1:20).
Daryl Roth Theater, 20 Union Square East, at 15th Street, 212-239-6200,
fuerzabrutanyc.com.

'A Gentleman's Guide to Love & Murder'  A feast of murder, music and merriment
in Edwardian England (2:20). Walter Kerr Theater, 219 West 48th Street,
212-239-6200, telecharge.com.

'Jersey Boys' The biomusical that walks like a man (2:30). August Wilson
Theater, 245 West 52nd Street, 212-239-6200, telecharge.com.

'Kinky Boots' These boots are made for dancin' -- and stompin' out bigotry
(2:20). Al Hirschfeld Theater, 302 West 45th Street, Clinton, 212-239-6200,
telecharge.com.

'The Lion King' Disney's call of the wild (2:45). Minskoff Theater, 200 West
45th Street, 800-870-2717, ticketmaster.com.

'Matilda the Musical'  The children's revolution, per Roald Dahl (2:35). Shubert
Theater, 225 West 44th Street, 212-239-6200, telecharge.com.

'Les Misérables' The celebrated musical about that hard-luck bread-stealer is
back -- again (2:50). Imperial Theater, 249 West 45th Street, 212-239-6200,
telecharge.com.

'Perfect Crime' The murder mystery that has been investigated since 1987 (1:30).
Snapple Theater Center, 210 West 50th Street, 800-745-3000, ticketmaster.com.

'The Phantom of the Opera' Who was that masked man anyway (2:30)? Majestic
Theater, 247 West 44th Street, 212-239-6200, telecharge.com.

'Queen of the Night'  An ultra-lavish immersive theater piece with cocktails, a
meal and a circus-style show (2:45). Diamond Horseshoe at the Paramount Hotel,
235 West 46th Street, 866-811-4111, queenofthenightnyc.com.

'Sex Tips for Straight Women From a Gay Man' Part bachelorette party at
Chippendales, part embarrassing midnight show in Pigalle (1:20). Fridays and
Saturdays at 777 Theater, 777 Eighth Avenue, at 47th Street, 888-841-4111,
sextipsplay.com.

'Sistas: The Musical' Black women reflect on their lives, with songs (1:30).
(Saturdays and Sundays.) St. Luke's Theater, 308 West 46th Street, Clinton,
212-239-6200, sistasthemusical.com.

'Sleep No More' A movable, murderous feast at Hotel Macbeth (2:00). The
McKittrick Hotel, 530 West 27th Street, Chelsea, 866-811-4111,
sleepnomorenyc.com.

'Stomp' And the beat goes on (and on), with percussion unlimited (1:30). Orpheum
Theater, 126 Second Avenue, at Eighth Street, East Village, 800-982-2787,
ticketmaster.com.

'Then She Fell' Go ask Alice (2:00). The Kingsland Ward at St. John's, 195
Maujer Street, near Humboldt Street, Williamsburg, Brooklyn, 718-374-5196,
thenshefell.com.

'Wicked' Oz revisited (2:45). Gershwin Theater, 222 West 51st Street,
800-745-3000, ticketmaster.com.

Last Chance

'Delirium's Daughters' (closes on Sunday) Nicholas Korn's one-act comedy about
four Italian suitors asking for the hands-in-marriage of three young women is
mostly just silliness, good-natured and competently executed. The ghost has the
best scene (1:10). Clurman Theater at Theater Row, 410 West 42nd Street,
212-239-6200, triumvirateartists.com. (Gates)

'The Taming of the Shrew' (closes on Sunday) It takes gumption to stage a comedy
about a husband breaking the will of his hot-tempered wife, even if Shakespeare
wrote it. But the Drilling Company sweetens some of its aftertaste with this
agreeable production, which offers Petruchio (Alessandro Colla) as a New England
fisherman and a Kate (Evangeline Fontaine) of yacht-club stock. The production
has many other players, but it's the romantic leads who give it wings (1:40).
The Upper Terrace in Bryant Park, Avenue of the Americas, at 40th Street,
212-873-9050, drillingcompany.org. (Andy Webster)

'They Are Gone But Here Must I Remain' (closes on Saturday) Part multimedia
lecture, all provocation, this rather muddled show from the Sister Sylvester
company is about the power of artists to incite action with images. Using Peter
Whitehead's 1969 film ''The Fall'' to examine contemporary protest and apathy,
the performance is rife with arresting visuals, but its concerns feel
intellectualized, and the chicken wandering the stage is a compelling
distraction (1:30). Jack, 505 1/2; Waverly Avenue, near Fulton Street, Clinton
Hill, Brooklyn, 800-838-3006, jackny.org. (Collins-Hughes)

Enlivening Bureaucracy

BYLINE: By SIOBHAN BURKE

SECTION: Section C; Column 0; The Arts/Cultural Desk; Pg. 14

LENGTH: 441 words


Employees of Brooklyn Borough Hall emerged from their offices on Wednesday
afternoon to the unlikely sounds of dancehall music pulsing through the
building. Down in the light-filled lobby, the dancer and choreographer Blacka Di
Danca was leading a free demonstration and class in that Jamaican-born style.
''I'm going to put you all in my next music video,'' he shouted in time with a
step called the Willie Bounce, addressing a few especially lively onlookers in
the balcony.

The eventful lunch hour was part of the BEAT Festival, which brings performing
arts to nontheatrical sites in Brooklyn -- parks, warehouses, galleries --
highlighting artists with strong ties to the borough. (The acronym stands for
Brooklyn Emerging Artists in Theater.) Blacka Di Danca was born and raised in
the Crown Heights section of the borough, though these days he spends much of
his time teaching and choreographing internationally.

The BEAT organizers aren't always prudent in their pairing of artist and site;
last year's nocturnal performances in Green-Wood Cemetery, for instance,
underutilized that locale. ''Dancehall in Borough Hall'' at first seemed like
another mismatch, the bureaucratic vibes at odds with the dynamism of Blacka Di
Danca and his sidekicks, Janelle Garvey and Aliyah Ali. But as they settled in
for a 15-minute show, followed by a 45-minute class for adventurous audience
members (the rest of us could just observe), the sterility of the space fell
away. And it didn't matter that only a few people were watching; a wiry, daring
dancer with unlimited charisma, Blacka Di Danca can work a crowd of any size.

He seemed most in his element when teaching, breaking down the dipping, swaying,
gyrating steps we had seen in his opening performance: how to do them, what they
mean. The back stories were as compelling as the movements themselves. The Tek
Weh Yuhself -- a pattern of side-to-side, front-to-back footwork, animated by
pulling and pushing arms -- has its roots in ''taking yourself away from a
negative situation,'' he said. In the Nuh Linga (No Linger), the foot draws an
S-shape on the floor while the upper body snakes and fingers snap. Down the
Flank resembles the act of kicking a soccer ball and the Gully Creeper that of
sneaking out at night. In one final demonstration, we learned about the links
between Ska -- an arm-waving, torso-bopping 1960s move -- and its 21st-century
incarnation, Syvah. Excited to the point of giddiness by the history of his
form, Blacka di Danca is keeping it very much alive.

The BEAT Festival continues through Sunday at various locations;
beatbrooklyn­.com.




URL:
http://www.nytimes.com/2015/09/18/arts/dance/review-blacka-di-danca-shakes-his-w
ay-through-borough-hall.html

GRAPHIC: PHOTO: Blacka Di Danca: This choreographer, center, and Janelle Garvey
in Brooklyn Borough Hall. (PHOTOGRAPH BY JULIETA CERVANTES FOR THE NEW YORK
TIMES)

GALLERIES (75%); HUMANITIES & SOCIAL SCIENCE (75%); MUSIC INDUSTRY (73%)

Review: 'Bonobos: Back to the Wild,' a Sanctuary's Rehab Mission

BYLINE: By NEIL GENZLINGER

SECTION: Section C; Column 0; The Arts/Cultural Desk; Pg. 9

LENGTH: 250 words


''Bonobos: Back to the Wild'' is an uncomfortable mix of fictionalized account
and nature film, but you have to admire the work it documents.

The movie examines the efforts of a conservationist named Claudine André, who
has spent years working to rescue bonobos, a species of great ape in Central
Africa that has been feeling the pressures of poaching, habitat destruction and
war. She runs a sanctuary in the Democratic Republic of Congo for orphaned and
otherwise rescued bonobos, and the film portrays her first efforts to release
some of them back into the wild.

But the film is not a documentary; instead it is, the screen credits say,
''freely adapted from an original idea by Claudine André and the true story of
Beni,'' whatever that means. Beni, a particularly inquisitive bonobo, comes to
the sanctuary as a very young orphan. As he grows, we hear his thoughts via a
cloying voice-over, and they're very human.

The practice of attributing the emotions and aspirations of people to wild
animals is questionable, but it's not uncommon in nature films and TV shows,
especially those trying to appeal to children. For grown-ups, at least, it's
distracting here, and you're never quite sure how much of what you're seeing
actually occurred. But none of that diminishes your admiration for Ms. André and
the staff members at the sanctuary as they labor to preserve bonobos, one animal
at a time.

Bonobos

Back to the Wild

Opens on Friday

Directed by Alain Tixier

1 hour 24 minutes; not rated




URL:
http://www.nytimes.com/2015/09/18/movies/review-bonobos-back-to-the-wild-a-sanct
uarys-rehab-mission.html

GRAPHIC: PHOTO: Claudine André and a baby at her sanctuary. (PHOTOGRAPH BY
VANESSA WOODS)

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

DOCUMENT-TYPE: Review

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

(78%); ANIMALS (77%); ORPHANS (76%); ENVIRONMENTALISM (72%); ADULTS (67%);
CHILDREN (51%)

COUNTRY: CONGO, THE DEMOCRATIC REPUBLIC OF THE (92%); CENTRAL AFRICA (90%);
AFRICA (90%)

Museum Is Reborn, Brick by Brick

BYLINE: By ROBERTA SMITH

SECTION: Section C; Column 0; The Arts/Cultural Desk; Pg. 21

LENGTH: 1432 words


HARTFORD -- Hurrah. Another American museum has gotten it right, bracing against
the tide of disastrous new buildings and additions that ruin and sometimes
cripple so many of these institutions.

The cause for celebration is a makeover at the venerable Wadsworth Atheneum
here, which opened its doors in 1844 and is this country's oldest art museum in
continuous operation. It joins a growing list of successful expansions and
refurbishments that may mark the end of an era of architectural indulgence that
began in 1978 with the opening of the National Gallery's East Wing, the putative
mother of useless event spaces that nourish neither art nor the people who love
it.

The roster of recent winners includes museums that have moved house, like the
Whitney and the Parrish Art Museum, with excellent results; others that have
grown significantly, like the Clark Institute and Yale University Gallery of
Art, and some that have repurposed existing space, like the Metropolitan Museum
of Art, knowing not to fix what isn't broken. The Met's galleries for European
painting were recently expanded in its characteristic understated style.

The Atheneum has executed a transformation almost as profound as the Whitney's
without venturing beyond its footprint. When its 1910 Morgan Memorial building,
the largest of five connected structures, reopens on Saturday, it will also
bring back some Old World museum conventions, sharpened by 21st-century
scholarship, self-awareness and panache -- namely an imposing Great
Hall-turned-picture gallery, hung salon-style, and a lavish cabinet of
curiosities. These showstoppers seem designed to draw in and delight seasoned
and new viewers alike.

Much of the credit goes to Susan L. Talbott, who became director in 2008. Plans
for a new wing were shelved in favor of a relatively frugal $33 million plan of
extensive repairs and upgrades. These have made the most of the museum's
structures, enabling it to display its collection as never before. The very
spirit of the place has been renewed: It has a bigger wingspan.

The Morgan Memorial all but disappeared during the last eight or so years, as
most of its galleries were closed either by leaks, or the need to store
displaced artworks. The two-story building reflected the largess of J.P. Morgan,
one of the greatest philanthropists of American museums, who grew up in Hartford
where his father, Junius Spencer Morgan, was a prominent businessman. The son
dedicated his Atheneum wing to the father, supplementing it with gifts of
adjacent real estate for future expansions and finally, after his death, a
substantial gift of art and decorative arts.

Sparkling with color in art and on walls alike, the Morgan building's
reinstalled galleries are stunning and astute. They play to the Atheneum's
strengths by repeatedly combining European painting -- especially Baroque --
with arrays of decorative arts. The rehang has been overseen by two
complementary curators, Linda Roth, curator of European decorative arts and an
Atheneum employee since 1980, and Oliver Tostmann, curator of European art, who
arrived two years ago.

The Great Hall now is probably just like Morgan pictured it. This double-story
space, painted dark blue, presents some 70 American and European paintings great
and so-so, from the 17th to the 19th centuries -- with two 16th-century works by
Tintoretto. Copies are included, like the late 19th-century rendition of
Raphael's 16th-century ''Madonna della Sedia,'' acquired as the genuine article
in 1897 in a robber-baron frame.

Made possible by Renaissance Revival architecture, the Great Hall hanging was
inspired by one of the most singular paintings in an American museum, centered
on the north wall: Giovanni Paolo Panini's ''The Picture Gallery of Cardinal
Silvio Valenti Gonzaga,'' from 1749. This aerial view of a soaring hall hung
cheek-to-jowl with paintings shows the red-robed cardinal studying an earlier
copy of the aforementioned Raphael Madonna.

Mr. Tostmann has dug up smaller related works, including a view of the picture
gallery of the American painter Benjamin West, by John Pasmore II, from around
1821. West is also present in a full-length portrait by Thomas Lawrence and his
own ''Raising of Lazarus,'' from 1780.

In this manner, the installation builds on echoing connections of subject,
color, style or back story. There's a marvelous group of small Dutch paintings
and a wonderful landscape by Aelbert Cuyp and impressive works by Ribera,
Murillo, Frederic Lord Leighton and the lesser known French painter Constance
Mayer (1775-1821), a full-length self-portrait with her father from 1801. An
infectiously urbane Rubens has the Holy Family returning from Egypt as if from
an afternoon stroll.

With some 50,000 objects, the Atheneum is not quite an encyclopedic museum. The
displays in the smaller galleries around the Great Hall form a beautifully
arranged, vividly illustrated Cliffs Notes of Western culture that makes
excellent use of its smatterings of Greek, Roman, Egyptian and medieval art and
slightly more Renaissance Art. The only non-Western art on view on the ground
floor is a handful of Chinese works, including a newly rediscovered Ming
painting on plaster. It was among several works that resurfaced when the
renovation all but forced a thorough sifting of the collection, accompanied by
much reassessment and conservation.

The Big Bang impression of the Great Hall repeats on the second floor with the
expansive Cabinet of Art and Curiosities, which illuminates the genesis of the
public museum in the hands of acquisitive scientists, aristocrats and monarchs
across Europe, especially in the 18th century. It will take several visits to
absorb its illustrated books, paintings and bravura displays of human skill
(Neolithic axes, Egyptian jewelry, Venetian glass) as well as natural wonders
like nautilus shells accessorized with gold. Pullout drawers reveal Persian
manuscript pages and enamel portraits.

The remaining 16 galleries on the second floor begin with one devoted to the
Atheneum's justly renowned early Baroque paintings, centering on Caravaggio's
''Saint Francis of Assisi in Ecstasy,'' and Poussin's only crucifixion, darkened
by age and later additions, but engrossing nonetheless. The museum's great
Zurbarán, of the white-robed Saint Serapion hanging by his wrists, will return
in about a month, from conservation in Spain.

Then commences the great give-and-take between paintings and porcelains, bronzes
and silver. The sense of luxurious consumption crests in the late Baroque
gallery dominated by two large abduction scenes (Helen of Troy, Europa) by Luca
Giordano that overlook a veritable throng of Meissen figurines.

The fever breaks two galleries on, with an especially disparate yet effective
group of paintings from just before and after the French Revolution, grouped
around the large, operatic ''Louis XVI Saying Farewell to His Family'' painted
by the American Mather Brown in 1793, near some Sèvres once owned by Madame de
Pompadour.

I'd like to highlight the paintings worth dwelling on, but nearly all qualify in
some way, creating a personal, egalitarian demeanor unusual for a public
collection, and implying generations of stringent-looking and creative
parsimony. There are of course significant works by well-known artists from
Frans Hals to Toulouse Lautrec, but many paintings seem to have been chosen for
their own, often idiosyncratic, visual effect. The names on the labels ring few
bells. One example must suffice: An 1833 landscape by a German artist named
Georg Heinrich Crola that is dominated by a tree whose branches writhe like
snakes.

And the decorative arts rarely fail to chime in. Among the Atheneum's most
popular paintings is William Holman Hunt's ''The Lady of Shallot'' (around
1890-1905), a late Pre-Raphaelite tour de force of intricacies. Here it has a
perfect comeuppance in a vitrine marked ''Islamic Revival'': a small ceramic
vase both comic and beautiful. Its contrasting areas of saturated magenta and
olive green are sewn together with trompe l'oeil stitches of bright aqua
complete with stretch marks.

With the born-again Atheneum, the large, diverse yet exclusive club of the
Eastern Seaboard's great museums adds a worthy new member. It comes into its own
bearing an important message: Museums must consider carefully and at length what
they already have before slapping on new wings. Connecticut, its capital city
and the Atheneum itself should be proud.

The Wadsworth Atheneum opens on Saturday in Hartford; 860-278-2670,
thewadsworth.com.

piece-of-renovation.html

                              Late Edition - Final

She'd Be Sad, if She Cared (but She Doesn't)

BYLINE: By JON CARAMANICA

SECTION: Section C; Column 0; The Arts/Cultural Desk; Pg. 4

LENGTH: 890 words


Lana Del Rey looks out into the world and all she sees are stares. Cold faces,
eyes hard with judgment. And lights, too -- sharp beams that poke like needles
and cut like lasers. For years, she has been scrutinized as intently as she's
been listened to. You would not blame her even a bit for wilting.

Instead, she has hardened, ossified into a thing of refined cool. The more
famous Ms. Del Rey has grown, the more obscure she's become. What was once
something of an elaborate performance has become merely a simple mode of being.

Now, she meets the glares and the harsh lights with ... nothing. Total
blankness. The way that celebrities stand still on the red carpet and fix their
eyes on some far-off point while a violent scrum of photographers fire flash
bombs and shout their names, resulting in picture after picture of sturdy
serenity, that's Ms. Del Rey's everyday. There's no moment she's not above the
fray.

Because of this, ''Honeymoon'' (Interscope), her third major-label album,
achieves a sublimity missing from her first two. She's been angry, and then
bored of being angry, but now she's just bored, and her boredom is entrancing.

There's that taffy voice, resignedly oozing all over the place -- rarely does
Ms. Del Rey check in at something more intense than a yawn. She's not an ornate
singer, but she achieves a great deal with only the many shades of exhaustion.

On ''Salvatore,'' when she ooohs about ''soft ice cream,'' she's a billowy
cloud. On ''Music to Watch Boys To,'' she sighs, ''I like you a lot,'' but her
voice is multitracked, as if arguing with herself whether it's even worth the
bother.

And in several places, she refers to the blues -- the music, but also the color,
and the mood. ''Got my blue nail polish on/It's my favorite color and my
favorite tone of song,'' she sings on ''The Blackest Day.'' On the title track,
she merely exhales: ''Dah-ah-ah-ah-ark bluuuuuuuuue.'' Her blue is the ocean,
and it's clear sky, and it's also blood.

For much of ''Honeymoon,'' she dwells on relationships so toxic they've turned
her into an emotional refusenik. On ''Terrence Loves You,'' she sings, ''I lost
myself when I lost you/And I still get trashed, darling/When I hear your
tunes,'' and on ''High by the Beach,'' she moans, ''We won't survive/We're
sinking into the sand.''

''Religion,'' a love song that would seem to demand preachy fervor, is instead
delivered with a shrug:

'Cause you're my religion, you're how I'm livingWhen all my friends say I should
take some spaceWell, I can't envision that for a minuteWhen I'm down on my
knees, you're how I pray

Ms. Del Rey's weakness remains her narrow field of vision. And her apathy does
tend towards lethargy -- individual songs seep long past their most pungent
moments, and her unwavering vocal approach can induce somnolence.

Apart from the album-closing cover of ''Don't Let Me Be Misunderstood'' and the
T.S. Eliot poem Ms. Del Rey reads during an interlude, all the songs were
written by her with Rick Nowels (Lykke Li, Belinda Carlisle), and the album was
produced by them along with Kieron Menzies.

Together, they have arrived at a solution to a problem that bedeviled Ms. Del
Rey on her first two albums, ''Born to Die'' from 2012, and ''Ultraviolence''
from last year. On ''Born to Die'' especially, she was thwarted by the ambitions
of her producers. Ms. Del Rey was still unsteady as a character, and the
gorgeous, lush production often highlighted how fragmented she was.

Now she is steady, and resolute too. And so the music stays out of the way,
ranging from melancholy to aspirated but never overwhelming, whether it's the
ethereal desert vibes of ''God Knows I've Tried,'' or the piano dirge ''Terrence
Loves You,'' or the exceptional ''High by the Beach,'' which is like an ASAP
Rocky song dubbed onto a fuzzy cassette.

Ms. Del Rey sounds lonely here, and fine with that. Perhaps ''Honeymoon'' is the
first great prison album of the 21st century, her jail being celebrity and the
scrutiny that comes with it. This album's opening couplet is a hilarious troll:
''We both know that it's not fashionable to love me/But you don't go, 'cause
truly there's nobody for you but me.'' And her cover of ''Don't Let Me Be
Misunderstood'' feels wholly earned -- brittle and distant, a sad-sack
meditation on inevitable disappointment.

Her acceptance of her absurd condition is there, vividly, in the incisive
''Freak,'' about life and love under the magnifying glass, which has a woozily
seductive chorus:

Baby, if you wanna leaveCome to CaliforniaBe a freak like me, tooScrew your
anonymityLoving me is all you need to feelLike I do

In the video for ''High by the Beach,'' Ms. Del Rey lolls about in a glorious
house on the Pacific until she's interrupted by a helicopter with a paparazzo
inside. She skips down to the beach, grabs a rocket launcher hidden in the
rocks, and blasts the copter out of the sky, then resumes her blithe bliss.

And so after four years in the limelight, here lounges Ms. Del Rey, immune to
the gravitational pull of the discourse about her. Once a careful invention, she
is now glassy-eyed and glassy-voiced, too cool to care. The result is something
like a dog that, when its leash is tugged, simply lies on the ground and shuts
its eyes: basking in the sun, feeding off its warmth, never giving an inch.




URL:
http://www.nytimes.com/2015/09/18/arts/music/review-lana-del-rey-honeymoon.html

GRAPHIC: PHOTO

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

SUBJECT: MUSIC (86%); CELEBRITIES (76%); SINGERS & MUSICIANS (75%)

LOAD-DATE: September 18, 2015

                              Late Edition - Final

Beltran, Once Central to Mets, Is Now a Key Figure in Another Borough

BYLINE: By BILLY WITZ

SECTION: Section B; Column 0; Sports Desk; Pg. 13

LENGTH: 967 words


For anyone who was unaware that the Yankees are locked in a playoff race at a
point in the season when each pitch carries added gravity, there were a couple
of unmistakable signs on Wednesday at Tropicana Field.

They both involved Carlos Beltran, the 38-year-old outfielder who has mastered
the twin arts of economy of movement and self-preservation.

First, Beltran -- on a double by Greg Bird into the right-center-field gap --
did something not often seen this season as he took off from first base. His
stride lengthened, his arms pumped and before long Beltran was at a dead run. If
he did not quite recall the days when he stole 40 bases in a season, Beltran
nevertheless came sprinting, straining and finally sliding into home with an
early lead.

Next, Beltran helped preserve it by doing something even more scarcely seen.
When Logan Forsythe led off the fourth inning by lacing a line drive to right
field, Beltran charged forward, left his feet and made a sliding catch.

If those plays were enough to stir memories for Yankees fans of what once was
for Beltran, his mere presence in right field this weekend at Citi Field is
certain to do the same for Mets fans.

Beltran was a central figure for the Mets the last time they carried playoff
aspirations, from the what-might-have-been 2006 postseason to the stupefying
collapses of 2007 and 2008.

Though the intracity series has an uncommon spice this season, thanks to the
second half of it being played in September for the first time and the status of
both teams as playoff contenders, Beltran, like several teammates, said it was
just another important moment as the Yankees try to catch Toronto in the
American League East.

''For the fans, this type of series are always big and huge,'' said Beltran, who
like his teammate Chris Young and Mets outfielder Curtis Granderson and reliever
Tyler Clippard has played for both teams. ''For us as ballplayers, we
concentrate on playing the game. We don't get caught up on the whole hype.''

Now at the tail end of his career, Beltran nearly spent his prime with the
Yankees instead of the Mets.

As an impending free agent in 2004, Beltran carried the Houston Astros, who had
acquired him in midseason, to the brink of the World Series, hitting eight home
runs during the playoffs. That performance set Beltran up for a big payday, and
the Yankees seemed a likely target -- not just because of their deep pockets but
because they had just gone four years without winning a World Series title and
were watching their own center fielder, Bernie Williams, start to decline.

But while Beltran's agent at the time, Scott Boras, tried vigorously to engage
the Yankees, they had other priorities, such as acquiring starting pitching,
which they did with Randy Johnson and Carl Pavano.

They also wanted to avoid still another hefty luxury tax payment, which they
would have incurred by signing Beltran.

''When you get to be a free agent, you've got to put a list of teams that you
think you could be able to go -- the Yankees were one of them,'' Beltran said.
''But at the end of the day, it's just the team having the interest in the
player. In that case, the Yankees were looking for pitching, so it wasn't like
we got anything close to signing.''

So, Beltran, convinced of the Mets' aspirations with their previous signing of
Pedro Martinez, gladly accepted a seven-year, $119 million contract from them in
early 2005.

A year later, the Mets, and Beltran, were on the verge of the World Series.

He had helped get them there with a strong 2006 season that enabled him to
finish fourth in the National League Most Valuable Player Award balloting.

Still, it was his bases-loaded strikeout for the final out of Game 7 of the
National League Championship Series, a 3-1 loss to St. Louis, that remains in
many minds -- as frozen as he was at the plate by Adam Wainwright's final
curveball.

And while he had strong Septembers in the Mets' back-to-back collapses that
followed 2006 -- he hit .282 with eight homers and 27 R.B.I. in 2007 and .344
with six homers and 19 R.B.I. in 2008 -- he could not prevent his club from
falling apart.

In any case, by necessity, his approach to the game is more calculated.

After signing a three-year, $45 million contract with the Yankees before last
season, Beltran was off to a good start when he tumbled over a wall in a game at
Tampa Bay in late April, jamming his shoulder and wrist. Soon after, bone chips
in his elbow made it too painful for him to play in the outfield. A series of
cortisone shots eased the pain somewhat, but not as much as off-season surgery
did.

Healthy, he plays the game as if he intends to remain that way.

Which means, in the field, he is not close to the Gold Glove center fielder he
was for the Mets. But he does remain a formidable middle-of-the-order bat for
the Yankees and, after a slow start and a stint on the disabled list in early
July with a strained oblique muscle, he has been the Yankees' most consistent
bat over the second half of the season, hitting .320 since July 31.

Beltran also delivered possibly the biggest hit for the Yankees this season: a
pinch-hit, three-run homer that beat Toronto last month.

The Yankees' hitting coach, Jeff Pentland, who has known Beltran since his early
days coming up with Kansas City, said Beltran's bat speed -- once among the
game's quickest -- had picked up in recent weeks after he tweaked his swing
because he was using too much of his upper body.

A year ago, Beltran looked broken down, waiting to have surgery, his season and
the Yankees' a great disappointment. Now, his bat is revitalized, and with the
Yankees in the pennant race, his legs and his glove may be coming to life, too.

It feels good, Beltran acknowledged.

''I feel like I'm doing my job,'' he said.




URL:
http://www.nytimes.com/2015/09/18/sports/baseball/carlos-beltran-once-central-to
-mets-is-now-a-key-figure-for-yankees.html

playoff appearance. (PHOTOGRAPH BY CHANG W. LEE/THE NEW YORK TIMES)
