Norway Hails Vikings Again, Minus the Pillaging

BYLINE: By ANDREW HIGGINS; Henrik Pryser Libell contributed reporting from Oslo.

SECTION: Section A; Column 0; Foreign Desk; SELJORD JOURNAL; Pg. 4

LENGTH: 1364 words


SELJORD, Norway --  Jeppe Nordmann Garly has for years been a ''recreational
Viking,'' a keen member of a fringe fraternity of would-be Norse warriors who
dress up in 10th-century clothing, attend weekend craft fairs and trade tips
over the Internet on where to pick up an authentic helmet or sword.

He has now become a full-time Viking. Formerly a teacher and jewelry maker in
Denmark, Mr. Garly last month began a new job on a hillside campus in central
Norway as the director of Scandinavia's first government-funded training course
on how to live like a Viking.

Or, that is, a politically correct one, purged of the bloodthirsty aggression
that made the Viking Age a byword for macho violence.

''I am a very peaceful man. I have never plundered anything,'' said Mr. Garly, a
36-year-old Dane whose modest stature, jocular manner and portly figure belie
his enthusiasm for ancient warriors. He does, at least, have a beard.

''Rape and pillage are not part of the curriculum,'' Mr. Garly added.

Also banished from the campus here in Seljord, a pretty lakeside town 115 miles
west of Oslo, are Nazi symbols of Nordic origin, which Nazi Germany and a puppet
fascist government used in Norway during World War II as emblems of their racist
creed.

Instead, students enrolled in the new Viking course at a continuing-education
college in Seljord learn about the Vikings' love of intricate artwork and
beautiful objects. They sew their own Viking-style garments and craft boots from
leather.

Military paraphernalia is studied for its artistry, not its violent purpose.
''Look at the amazing workmanship on this,'' Mr. Garly said, fingering the
interlocking metal rings on a coat of mail.

In a country that awards the Nobel Peace Prize each year and delights in its
reputation for tolerance, the rebranding of Vikings from violent thugs to
peaceable craftsmen is part of a broader resurgence of interest in a historical
period previously embraced mostly by far-right nationalists.

It has helped make pride in the Viking Age respectable at a time when
Norwegians, like many other Europeans, are looking to the past to shore up
identities shaken by alarm over immigration and the impact of globalization.

A Norwegian publishing house has started a new Internet magazine called ''The
Happy Viking,'' a Norwegian film director has just made what is billed as a
Viking blockbuster due for release early next year, and attendance at museums
displaying Viking ships in Oslo and Lofoten has surged.

Even so, Norway, still somewhat squeamish about celebrating a part of its
history hijacked by the Nazis, lags behind foreigners in plundering the Viking
past for inspiration and cash. The television series ''Vikings'' is an
Irish-Canadian production, and the fantasy drama ''Game of Thrones'' was made
for HBO.

Lars Ueland Kobro, a tourism investment adviser, told the Norwegian state
broadcaster NRK that Norway needed to overcome its lingering inhibitions and
embrace the business opportunities offered by the Vikings. He said it was now
''time to invest in large Viking experience centers in Norway.''

Others, however, like Anders Kvale Rue, a Viking fan who leads a group of
amateur enthusiasts from around Seljord called Olaf's Men, cautioned that
Vikings, particularly their symbols and taste for violence, remained a touchy
subject for some.

''Before the Second World War, the whole nation was proud of our Viking
heritage. But after the war it was banned from the public arena for more than 50
years,'' he said. ''We can still feel the negative effects today. Some people
feel disgust with the Viking Age and think that it is connected to racism.''

Mr. Rue and fellow members of his group are all Christians, a faith that early
pagan Vikings frequently attacked with gusto but to which many later converted,
following the lead of Norway's 11th-century king, Olaf Haraldsson.

Mr. Rue, wearing a helmet and carrying an ax and sword during a visit to a
13th-century wooden church in Heddal, said he was delighted when a Somali-born
youth joined a local Viking-inspired scouts group.

The Vikings, he added, were ''big slave traders'' but ''were not racists.''
Their slaves were fellow whites seized during raids in places like England.

But this has not stopped avowed white supremacists from claiming the Viking
heritage as an endorsement of their beliefs.

Norway's wartime leader, Vidkun Quisling, and the far-right Norwegian terrorist
Anders Behring Breivik, now serving a 21-year sentence for the murder of 77
people in 2011, championed the Vikings as heroes of the Aryan race. Stormfront,
a neo-Nazi Internet forum, uses a Viking cross as its logo and features postings
praising the Vikings.

Arve Husby, the principal of the Seljord college, said staff members initially
had doubts about adding the new course: ''Everyone was very skeptical. They
said, 'What is this Viking thing?' ''

But serious interest in Vikings would help push extremists ''onto the
sidelines,'' he said, and reclaim an important part of Norway's past that
included not only slaughter but also major achievements like sailing to North
America about 500 years before Columbus.

Mr. Husby said the college has laid down strict rules that the Viking students
would not engage in ''inappropriate'' activities. Animal sacrifices, violent
sword play, hallucinogenic mushrooms -- which some believe the Vikings used to
pep themselves up for battle -- are all off limits.

Vikings, he said, were sometimes violent but were also ''brave, curious people''
whose history and lifestyle should not be left to right-wing extremists. ''We
have to weaken this link,'' he said.

Another link Mr. Garly, the teacher, would like to diminish is how the image of
Vikings had also been hijacked by heavy metal rock bands, which have often
studded their noisy acts with Viking themes. A recent hit song by Judas Priest,
''Halls of Valhalla,'' recounts Vikings sailing through a storm and creating
''life from death.''

''Vikings have a bad reputation, and everyone thinks they dressed like stand-in
drummers for Kiss,'' Mr. Garly said.

The nine-month course he is leading in Seljord plays down the blood and gore and
focuses instead on the Vikings' technical prowess and craftsmanship.

The course, which costs each student 18,000 kroner, about $2,200, includes a
trip to the English city of York, renamed Jorvik after it fell to the Vikings in
866.

The 14 students -- nine men and five women, all Norwegians -- said they had been
attracted by the opportunity to work with their hands and reconnect with a part
of their country's history that, once cleansed of its gruesome associations,
made them feel proud.

Hammering at an anvil in the campus blacksmith's hut, one student, Alexander
Fredriksen, 20, noted that Vikings had many talents beyond spreading mayhem.

''They were great warriors and very good at killing, but this was just a small
part of what they did,'' he said.

Because the Vikings wrote only short messages in runic script and left no
detailed written account of their exploits, much of their history -- and
terrible reputation -- was shaped by Christian monks and others who suffered at
their hands.

''They miserably ravaged and pillaged everything,'' a monk wrote of a late
eighth-century Viking raid on a monastery on Lindisfarne, an island off the
northeast coast of England. ''Some of the brethren they slew; some they carried
off in chains.''

Their grisly image, however, began to improve, at least in academic circles,
when a revisionist view took hold in recent decades and convinced some
historians that Vikings had been unfairly maligned.

Even some Viking fans worry that this revisionist view has gone too far, pushed
toward what Mr. Rue mocked as ''warrior flower power'' by ''old hippies'' who
want to turn Vikings into new-age peaceniks.

''The politically correct Viking,'' he warned, has become so far removed from
the Viking Age creed of ''keep struggling and never give up'' that ''he does not
really appeal to anybody.''

Get news and analysis from Europe and around the world delivered to your inbox
every day with the Today's Headlines: European Morning newsletter. Sign up here.




URL:
http://www.nytimes.com/2015/09/18/world/europe/norway-again-embraces-the-vikings
-minus-the-violence.html

his girlfriend, Linnea Bang-Madsen, in Seljord, Norway. Below, students
practiced metalworking. (A4)
 Anders Kvale Rue, center, who leads a group of Viking enthusiasts, with his
friends Oystein Rivrud, 52, right, and Mr. Rivrud's son Nils, 20, left, at a
13th-century church in Heddal, Norway. (PHOTOGRAPHS BY MAURICIO LIMA FOR THE NEW
YORK TIMES) (A6) MAP (A6)

(70%); NOBEL PRIZES (67%); AWARDS & PRIZES (62%); GLOBALIZATION (60%);

GERMANY (69%)

                           September 18, 2015 Friday
                              Late Edition - Final

Review: In 'Veteran,' an '80s Cop Comedy Vibe From South Korea

BYLINE: By MIKE HALE

SECTION: Section C; Column 0; The Arts/Cultural Desk; Pg. 10

LENGTH: 354 words


Ryoo Seung-wan's ''Veteran,'' in which an honest detective takes on the
pampered, sociopathic heir to a family-owned business conglomerate, must have
had plenty of resonance in South Korea. Released in August, nine months after
the daughter of the chairman of Korean Air threw a fit over a bag of nuts and
blew up her career, it is already one of the 10 highest-grossing domestic films
in that country's history.

American audiences are less likely to care about the film's treatment of
chaebols and their undue influence in South Korean society, however, than its
strong debt to 1980s American cop comedies like ''Beverly Hills Cop,'' ''48
Hrs.'' and ''Lethal Weapon.'' (The link to the period is reinforced by the use
of Blondie's ''Heart of Glass'' on the soundtrack in the movie's opening
seconds.)

And it mostly stands up to the comparison. Mr. Ryoo (''The Unjust,'' ''The City
of Violence'') isn't known for his sense of humor, but ''Veteran'' is amusing
throughout, even if the funny scenes are more subdued or go on a beat or two
longer than American viewers are used to. He may not have Walter Hill's or
Richard Donner's gift for melding comedy to action and maintaining a tone of
antic menace, but he delivers a solid, consistently entertaining story
punctuated by the balletic action sequences he's known for. (He also wrote the
screenplay, which is considerably more linear and coherent than the South Korean
norm.)

Hwang Jung-min is cool and capable as the longtime detective whose investigation
of a friend's suicide attempt pits him against the conglomerate's lawyers, thugs
and paid-off policemen; he's a quieter version of the Eddie Murphy or Mel Gibson
cop who plays the fool but is good in a fight. The Korean heartthrob Yoo Ah-in
plays the preening adversary, whose response to being shown up is to humiliate
the nearest woman or assault the nearest pet. Oh Dal-su of ''Oldboy'' and ''The
Host'' steals most scenes he's in as a weary police chief -- he's the real
veteran of ''Veteran.''

Veteran

Opens on Friday

Directed by Ryoo Seung-wan

In Korean, with English subtitles

2 hours 4 minutes; not rated

http://www.nytimes.com/2015/09/18/movies/review-in-veteran-an-80s-cop-comedy-vib
e-from-south-korea.html

(PHOTOGRAPH BY CJ ENTERTAINMENT)

Review: 'Uncle John' Is Steeped in Secrets

BYLINE: By NEIL GENZLINGER

SECTION: Section C; Column 0; The Arts/Cultural Desk; Pg. 10

LENGTH: 242 words


The simmering mystery ''Uncle John'' is so subtle, so exquisitely paced and so
determined not to go in any of the obvious directions that it's hard to believe
the film is Steven Piet's first feature. Mr. Piet, who with Erik Crary also
wrote the script, sketches some memorable characters while keeping his
two-pronged story sparse, ominous and deliciously ambiguous.

John Ashton is just right as the inscrutable title character, an older fellow in
a rural town where an unlikable man named Dutch has gone missing. Shortly before
his disappearance, Dutch apparently found Jesus, and he had been visiting
various townspeople, confessing to misdeeds and such. Dutch and John's sister
were an item long ago, but something murky happened to the sister, and perhaps
now something murky has happened to Dutch.

While all of this is being slowly revealed, many miles away in Chicago a young
man named Ben is becoming smitten with a new co-worker, Kate. Alex Moffat and
Jenna Lyng are very watchable as this might-become-a-couple, but what do they
have to do with the goings-on out in the country? Turns out Ben has a beloved
uncle who raised him, a man by the name of John. And when the two young flirters
head his way for an impromptu visit, all secrets will be revealed.

Or will they? It's tantalizing, sublimely creepy stuff that keeps you guessing
even after the credits roll.

Uncle John

Opens on Friday

Directed by Steven Piet

1 hour 54 minutes; not rated

http://www.nytimes.com/2015/09/18/movies/review-uncle-john-is-steeped-in-secrets
.html

Review: In 'A Trick of the Light,' the German Answer to the Lumière Brothers

BYLINE: By RACHEL SALTZ

SECTION: Section C; Column 0; The Arts/Cultural Desk; Pg. 9

LENGTH: 468 words


France has the aptly named Lumière brothers and their Cinématographe. America
has Thomas Edison and his Kinetoscope. And Germany has the Skladanowsky brothers
and their Bioskop.

''A Trick of the Light,'' from 1995, is a tribute to the Skladanowskys and to
that moment 100 years or so earlier when movies were being born, seemingly all
over the world. Charming without tipping over into the wonderstruck, this movie,
or ''lichtspiel,'' was made by Wim Wenders and students of the University of
Television and Film Munich. (It had not been formally released in the United
States until now.)

Shot mostly with a hand-cranked camera from the 1920s, the silent
black-and-white images, with their little sprocket hops and slightly variable
speed, tell the story of three brothers in Berlin -- Max (Udo Kier), Emil (Otto
Kuhnle) and Eugen (Christoph Merg) -- tinkering, experimenting and having
something that looks suspiciously like fun as they try to capture movement.
Eugen juggling; a (reluctant) boxing kangaroo; the Serpentine dance, with its
circular flutters of white winglike sleeves: These were among the film sequences
that the Skladanowskys showed at the Wintergarten in Berlin in November 1895,
just two months before the Lumières showed their movies in Paris (made, by all
accounts, with a superior process).

With its light silent comedy, Mr. Wenders's film presents movie history as a
meeting of the inventive and the inevitable -- a playful lark. That's reinforced
by the child's-eye narration, delivered by Max's little daughter Gertrud. Soon,
though, the movie tucks away childish things, jumping to the documentary
present-tense of 1995 Berlin, where Gertrud's younger sister Lucie, then 91, was
still living in the house in Pankow. (The family had occupied the house since
1907, a fact that sends the mind tripping gently down corridors of German
history.)

Mr. Wenders and his crew, modern equipment in place -- booms and lights and film
cameras -- interview Lucie, and we see her treasures: the flipbooks that she
says made her father more money than his movies; rolls of decayed film; the
magic-lantern slides he painted. And we ride through 1995 Berlin, a city of
cranes and construction and nonancient ruins that seems a slightly sad, distant
relation of the black-and-white city of this movie's film within a film.

An unforced melancholy hangs over ''A Trick of the Light,'' with its
appreciation of cinema's first days and the try-try-again spirit of its
pioneers. Twenty years on, the melancholy tugs harder, as the technology
celebrated here -- film, running through a camera or flickering on a makeshift
screen -- is itself becoming an artifact of the past.

A Trick of the Light

Opens on Friday

Directed by Wim Wenders

In German, with English subtitles

1 hour 16 minutes; not rated




URL:
http://www.nytimes.com/2015/09/18/movies/review-in-a-trick-of-the-light-the-germ
an-answer-to-the-lumiere-brothers.html

GRAPHIC: PHOTO: A scene from Wim Wenders's ''A Trick of the Light,'' about an
early cinema invention. (PHOTOGRAPH BY WIM WENDERS STIFTUNG)

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

DOCUMENT-TYPE: Review

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

SUBJECT: FILM (90%); FILM HISTORY (78%); DOCUMENTARY FILMS (76%); STUDENTS &
STUDENT LIFE (70%)

CITY: BERLIN, GERMANY (90%); PARIS, FRANCE (59%)

COUNTRY: GERMANY (90%); UNITED STATES (90%); FRANCE (59%)

                              Late Edition - Final

Playthings Put a Country's Ingenuity on Display

BYLINE: By KEN JOHNSON

SECTION: Section C; Column 0; The Arts/Cultural Desk; Pg. 28

LENGTH: 902 words



Presenting more than 300 playthings dating from the 17th to the early 21st
century, ''Swedish Wooden Toys,'' at the Bard Graduate Center, will be catnip
for anyone interested in antique toys. It's also an excellent occasion to ponder
ideas about toys in general in a time when electronic devices are replacing
traditional, comparatively simple objects for children's entertainment.

Organized by the center's director, Susan Weber, and Amy F. Ogata, an art
historian at the University of Southern California, the show includes diminutive
vehicles of all kinds, from old-time wagons, trains and fully rigged sailboats
to futuristic cars and a rocket ship. There are naturalistic and anthropomorphic
animals, rocking horses, weapons, puzzles, games, dollhouses and architectural
construction kits.

While many of these items were produced by big manufacturers with international
distribution like BRIO and Playsam, many others are one-of-a-kind works. Carved
with exacting delicacy by an unknown artisan around 1900, a miniature baking set
includes rolling pins, spatulas, a ladle and other implements all fitting into a
wooden tray just eight inches long.

Essays by a dozen scholars in the excellent catalog tell several different but
intersecting stories. One is about wood. Today we may think of things made from
wood as special -- natural rather than synthetic, and redolent of old-world
craftsmanship. But when toy manufacturing began to rise in densely forested
Sweden in the mid- to late-19th century, wood was the most commonplace of
materials. Woodworking was widespread, and in the 20th century the country
became internationally known for toys as well as wood furniture. Now, sadly,
wooden toy manufacturing has succumbed to global economics: While they are still
designed in Sweden, toys by the biggest companies are made in Asia.

Another narrative has to do with concerns for the welfare, education and
socialization of children. Toward the end of the 19th century, formal schooling
became compulsory for all Swedish children, and toys were considered by the
progressively minded to have pedagogical and morally elevating value. A section
of the exhibition devoted to educational toys includes abacuses, toy telephones,
a child-size loom and kits for constructing machines, cars and buildings. The
wall label for a Noah's Ark notes that it would have been intended for ''quiet
Sabbath day occupation and instruction in Lutheran Sweden.''

There are interesting stories behind many individual objects, few more so than
that of the Labyrinth game. This now familiar device consists of a perforated
maze on a tilting board through which the player guides a steel marble by means
of control knobs on the side. Designed in the 1940s by Sven Bergling and
produced by BRIO beginning in 1946, it was used in Britain to rehabilitate
fighter pilots wounded during World War II and became a favorite with Swedish
Air Force personnel. Abercrombie & Fitch featured the game in its toy department
in the early 1950s, and it has since been the most widely copied of all BRIO
products.

Among the most appealing objects for contemporary design aficionados will
probably be the minimalist, cartoonlike cars and other vehicles called
Streamliners,  designed by Ulf Hanses for Playsam. The original 1984 design was
featured on a 2005 Swedish postage stamp. While not directly addressed in the
exhibition, Mr. Hanses' extremely simple concept invites thinking about realism
and complexity versus abstraction and simplicity in toys.

An especially striking example of that dichotomy is in the dollhouse section.
Here there's a spectacular four-story dwelling in a repurposed glass-front
display cabinet standing over six feet high. Created in 1912 by an amateur named
John Carlsson when he was just 18, it is filled with finely detailed Victorian
furniture, lights and decorative objects and populated by stylishly dressed
little porcelain people. Most remarkably, it has attached to the outside a
working elevator made of metal and powered by an electric clock motor.

By contrast to Carlsson's busy abode, an all-white dollhouse designed by Eva
Schildt for Playsam in 2008 is free of excess ornament. Standing just under a
foot tall, it has a rounded roof, and its two stories are open to the front with
a circular window on the second floor. That may sound austere, but it is
dreamily evocative, and it would seem to offer as much if not more room for a
child's actively imaginative engagement than more realistic types.

In a catalog essay called ''Designing Wooden Toys in the Age of the
Technological Imagination,'' Nina Stritzler-Levine, the gallery director,
observes, ''Swedish toy manufacturers have reduced their production of wooden
toys in the 21st century in tandem with the growth of technology,'' and she
quotes a Swedish journalist who suggested that BRIO would have to switch ''from
steam locomotives and cute dachshunds to design and cyberspace.''

Parents throughout the modern world may lament their children's captivity by
computer games and videos, but probably there's no going back. So, while this
exhibition is fun, it marks the end of an era, and the questions it indirectly
raises about the future of toys and the shaping of children's minds are sobering
to contemplate.

''Swedish Wooden Toys'' runs through Jan. 17 at Bard Graduate Center Gallery,
Manhattan; 212-501-3023, bgc.bard.edu.




URL:
http://www.nytimes.com/2015/09/18/arts/design/review-swedish-wooden-toys-mix-ing
enuity-and-education.html

GRAPHIC: PHOTOS: Swedish Wooden Toys: Clockwise from above, a dollhouse with a
motorized elevator made in 1912 by John Carlsson, alongside houses from 1936 and
1944, part of this Bard Graduate Center Gallery exhibition
an articulated elephant by BRIO
a motorcyclist from the 1940s
 and the Labyrinth game, which was used in rehabilitating wounded World War II
pilots. (PHOTOGRAPHS BY BYRON SMITH FOR THE NEW YORK TIMES)

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

DOCUMENT-TYPE: Review

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

SUBJECT: TOYS & GAMES MFG (90%); TOYS & GAMES (90%); CHILDREN (89%); WORLD WAR
II (83%); HISTORY (78%); AIR FORCES (74%); ART HISTORY (70%); AIRCRAFT PILOTS
(60%); ARMED FORCES (50%)

COMPANY: ABERCROMBIE & FITCH CO (60%)

ORGANIZATION: UNIVERSITY OF SOUTHERN CALIFORNIA (57%)

TICKER: ANF (NYSE) (60%); AFT (FRA) (60%)

INDUSTRY: NAICS448140 FAMILY CLOTHING STORES (60%); SIC5651 FAMILY CLOTHING
STORES (60%)

STATE: CALIFORNIA, USA (72%)

COUNTRY: SWEDEN (88%); ASIA (77%); UNITED STATES (72%)

                              Late Edition - Final

Don't Sit on Medical Breakthroughs

BYLINE: By ERIC J. TOPOL and HARLAN M. KRUMHOLZ.

Eric J. Topol is a cardiologist at the Scripps Clinic and a professor of
genomics at the Scripps Research Institute. Harlan M. Krumholz is a cardiologist
at Yale-New Haven Hospital and professor of medicine at Yale.

SECTION: Section A; Column 0; Editorial Desk; OP-ED CONTRIBUTORS; Pg. 29

LENGTH: 846 words


IN this age of instant information, medicine remains anchored in the practice of
releasing new knowledge at a deliberate pace. It's time for medical scientists
to think differently about how quickly they alert the public to breakthrough
findings.

Last week the National Institutes of Health announced that it had prematurely
ended a large national study of how best to treat people with high blood
pressure because of its exceptional results.

In this trial of more than 9,000 people age 50 and older with high blood
pressure, an aggressive treatment strategy to keep systolic blood pressure below
120 was compared with a conventional one aimed at keeping it below 140. The
subjects all had a high risk of heart attacks, stroke and heart failure. The
N.I.H. concluded, six years into a planned eight-year study, that for these
patients, pushing blood pressure down far below currently recommended levels was
very beneficial.

Ending a study early is rather unusual. In such cases, studies are stopped not
by the investigators, but by an independent group of expert scientists who
monitor the trial for evidence of unexpected harm or benefit that requires swift
action. When a trial is halted early it is a surprise to the researchers who
must not only move quickly to notify the participating doctors and subjects, but
also decide how to communicate the results. The usual practice is to make a
public announcement with an interpretation of the findings and then finalize the
database and write the paper.

The N.I.H. followed this playbook, and the media reported that the findings
supported more vigorous treatment of high blood pressure, treatment that could
be lifesaving. It was reported as major news.

The problem is that many details of the study have not been released. It will be
months before the study is presented at a major scientific meeting and possibly
even longer before it is published. All we know at this point is that there was
a 30 percent reduction in heart attacks and strokes and a 25 percent reduction
in deaths. But there are a lot of critical details that have yet to be revealed.
The percent reduction means little without knowing, in absolute numbers, how
many people benefited or how many suffered strokes or heart attacks or died. We
also don't know about the risks of aggressive treatment or the types of patients
who derived particular benefit. Without knowing all this information, it is not
possible for doctors and patients to know how to translate these findings into
action.

But we do already know that aggressive treatment of high blood pressure with
medication carries a risk of fainting and other important side effects. There
are over 79 million Americans with high blood pressure and more than a billion
people affected worldwide. High blood pressure is the most common chronic
medical condition and it carries the risks of heart attack and stroke. Using
additional medications to achieve a goal of less than 120 may cost more money,
possibly expose people to new side effects and, for some patients, lower blood
pressure to dangerous levels.

The new information may justify a more vigorous strategy for treating blood
pressure, but for now doctors and patients have been left with incomplete
results, some headlines and considerable uncertainty about whether to modify
current treatments.

Medicine needs to change its approach to releasing new, important information.
Throughout science we are seeing more rapid modes of communication. The
traditional approach was not to publish until everything was finalized and ready
to be chiseled in stone. But these sorts of delays are unnecessary with the
Internet. Moreover, although all the trial data has yet to be tabulated, an
analysis was considered sufficiently definitive to lead independent experts to
stop the multimillion-dollar study.

We believe that when there is such strong evidence for a major public health
condition, there should be rapid release of the information that led to the
decision to stop the trial. This approach could easily be accomplished by
placing the data on the N.I.H. website or publishing the data on such platforms
as bioRxiv.org, which enables fast, open review by the medical community.

Such transparency would ensure that the public and the scientific community
could see and understand the basis for the decision. While it is still important
to publish the final results in a peer-reviewed journal, the sharing of
available results could ease the time delay inherent in our current publication
process and be more in keeping with the best interests of patients. Data that
was good enough to persuade experts to stop the trial should be good enough to
share.

Kudos to the scientists who conducted such a large, complex and important study
with what will be likely to have lifesaving consequences for a condition that
can be treated easily in most patients. Now the medical community needs to adopt
a new approach in situations like this one to disseminate lifesaving results in
a timely, comprehensive and transparent way. Lives depend on it.




URL:
http://www.nytimes.com/2015/09/18/opinion/dont-delay-news-of-medical-breakthroug
hs.html

GRAPHIC: DRAWING (DRAWING BY MARK PERNICE)

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

DOCUMENT-TYPE: Op-Ed

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

HYPERTENSION (90%); EDITORIALS & OPINIONS (90%); HEART DISEASE (89%);
CARDIOVASCULAR DRUGS (89%); STROKES (89%); CARDIOVASCULAR DISEASE (89%);
DISEASES & DISORDERS (78%); RESEARCH INSTITUTES (78%); CHRONIC DISEASES (76%);
HEALTH DEPARTMENTS (73%); PHYSICIANS & SURGEONS (73%); CONFERENCES & CONVENTIONS
(72%)

On Any Given Thursday: N.F.L. Annexes Another Night

BYLINE: By VICTOR MATHER

SECTION: Section ; Column 0; Sports Desk; Pg.

LENGTH: 597 words


In America, fall Sundays are for pro football. As are Monday nights, of course.

And now, those who aren't die-hard football fans -- but have a spouse, parents
or friends who are -- can scratch Thursday night off the social calendar as
well. Thursday night N.F.L. football, once a rarity, has gradually become a
regular part of the national viewing landscape.

The N.F.L. has always played games on Thanksgiving. And through the early years
of the league, a game would be played now and again on nonholiday Thursdays.

But in the 21st century, the occasional Thursday game turned into five per year,
then seven. And since last year, the N.F.L. has scheduled a Thursday nighter
every week of the season but the last.

Like it or not, the N.F.L. extended weekend is now five days long.

On Oct. 12, 1922, the Rochester Jeffersons lined up against the Akron Pros at
Elk's Field in the newly named National Football League. The game ended in a
13-13 tie when Al Nesser returned a blocked punt for a touchdown. Thursday
N.F.L. football was born.

Despite the occasional weekday foray over the next decades, the phenomenon
really began in October 1978, when the Vikings visited the Cowboys for the first
non-Thanksgiving Thursday game of the Super Bowl era. ABC's ''Monday Night
Football'' team presided, giving the game a big-event feel.

There was complaining about the short rest for the teams, but Vikings Coach Bud
Grant was sanguine. ''If you're one of the contending teams, you've got to play
at odd times,'' he told The Chicago Tribune. ''Teams like us and Dallas are used
to playing at 3 o'clock or on Monday night. It's the cross you bear.'' The
Vikings won, 21-10.

In 2002, a Bon Jovi concert led into a game in East Rutherford, N.J., and the
tradition of a Thursday night season opener began, now generally featuring the
defending champion. Jeremy Shockey made his pro debut for the Giants, but they
lost to the 49ers, 16-13.

The ubiquity of Thursday night football really began in 2006 when the league
added four Thursday games late in the season as a way of boosting the NFL
Network, which at the time was on very few cable systems.

The number of weeks with Thursday games continued to increase incrementally, and
this season there will be Thursday football in every week but the last, in which
every game will fall on Sunday.

Thursday has been an attractive night to the N.F.L. because under the terms of
the 1961 law that gave the league its antitrust exemption, it may not play on
Friday or Saturday during most of the season to protect high school and college
football.

You would not call the Thursday games popular with the teams, exactly. Guard
Josh Sitton of the Packers called them ''stupid'' last year, telling ESPN:
''That's what this league is about, is about making money, which is fine. I like
to make money as well. But, yeah, it's tough on your body, tough on your head.''

Saints Coach Sean Payton was incensed last year when his team was asked to play
on Thursday after a Sunday night game. ''It's foolish,'' he said at a postgame
news conference, despite winning. ''You got three guys that are hurt in there
right now.''

Fans and analysts have complained that the players' short rest makes the games
sloppy and unentertaining.

But television ratings have been good. Every game on CBS last year was the
highest rated program of the night, and the games on the NFL Network were the
highest rated cable shows of the night. That means that Thursday football is
unmistakably here to stay.

Still, Tuesdays and Wednesdays remain pro football free. For now.




URL:
http://www.nytimes.com/2015/09/18/sports/football/on-any-given-thursday-nfl-anne
xes-another-night.html

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

SUBJECT: THANKSGIVING (90%); AMERICAN FOOTBALL (90%); SPORTS (90%); HOLIDAYS &
OBSERVANCES (89%); SPORTS & RECREATION EVENTS (78%); SPORTS FANS (78%); AMERICAN
FOOTBALL TOURNAMENTS (78%); MAMMALS (58%); ANTITRUST & TRADE LAW (50%)

ORGANIZATION: NATIONAL FOOTBALL LEAGUE (94%); MINNESOTA VIKINGS (55%); DALLAS
COWBOYS (54%)

STATE: NEW JERSEY, USA (52%)

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (92%)

Review: 'The Cut' Depicts the Armenian Diaspora Through a Searching Father

BYLINE: By NICOLAS RAPOLD

SECTION: Section C; Column 0; The Arts/Cultural Desk; Pg. 8

LENGTH: 293 words



Fatih Akin's ''The Cut'' brings the monumental scale of an epic to the Armenian
genocide of 1915 without toning down the murderous cruelty and upheaval of the
events.

The film depicts the forced diaspora and mass suffering through the grueling
search of a bereft, wandering father. Nazaret (Tahar Rahim) is a well-off
craftsman in the Ottoman Empire when he is wrenched away from his family one
night by Turkish soldiers during a mass roundup of Armenian men. He proceeds to
survive forced labor and marches and an execution attempt that cuts his vocal
cords. Reports that his twin daughters may be alive lead him to Aleppo and
refuge in a soap factory; from there, he chases tips overseas to Cuba, the
American South and beyond.

Nazaret's inability to speak makes him especially tragic (and may double as a
reference to the longtime silence maintained by Turkey concerning the genocide).
It's a considerably risky move by Mr. Akin, and it echoes the unevenly balanced
priorities of the film.

Great care is taken with the panoramic vistas of Turkish badlands and richly
detailed interiors, the searchingly cyclical motif of the score and the
portrayal of the wearying, touch-and-go ordeals of encountering friends and
enemies on the road. But there's a recurring -- and frankly mystifying --
shortfall when it comes to the screenplay, by Mr. Akin and Mardik Martin. Too
many scenes feel routine or clichéd, sometimes even those depicting extreme
experiences.

Mr. Akin made his name with the dramatic vim and vigor of films like
''Head-On,'' and one can only wish ''The Cut'' had gone that extra mile.

The Cut

Opens on Friday

Directed by Fatih Akin

In English, Arabic, Turkish, Kurdish and Spanish, with English subtitles

2 hours 18 minutes; not rated




URL:
http://www.nytimes.com/2015/09/18/movies/review-the-cut-depicts-the-armenian-dia
spora-through-a-searching-father.html

BY GORDON MUEHLE/STRAND RELEASING)

MULTIPLE BIRTHS (72%); FORCED LABOR (72%); MANUFACTURING FACILITIES (70%)

COUNTRY: ARMENIA (95%); TURKEY (90%)

Unbeaten Clemson Keeps Louisville Winless

BYLINE: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

SECTION: Section B; Column 0; Sports Desk; SPORTS BRIEFING | COLLEGE FOOTBALL;
Pg. 14

LENGTH: 32 words


Deshaun Watson threw two touchdown passes, Wayne Gallman ran for 139 yards, and
No. 11 Clemson (3-0) held off host Louisville (0-3), 20-17, in the Atlantic
Coast Conference opener for both teams.



URL:
http://www.nytimes.com/2015/09/18/sports/unbeaten-clemson-keeps-louisville-winle
ss.html

ORGANIZATION: ATLANTIC COAST ATHLETIC CONFERENCE (81%)

Header Gives Borussia Dortmund 10th Straight Win

BYLINE: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

SECTION: Section B; Column 0; Sports Desk; SPORTS BRIEFING | SOCCER; Pg. 14

LENGTH: 77 words


Borussia Dortmund needed a stoppage-time goal for its 10th straight win to start
the season, beating Krasnodar, 2-1, in the Europa League. Borussia Dortmund's
winner was an unlikely diving header by South Korea defender Park Joo-ho.

Napoli, a semifinalist last season, opened its group stage campaign by routing
Bruges, 5-0. Liverpool was held, 1-1, at Bordeaux, which got an 81st minute goal
from the Brazilian Jussiê to cancel out Adam Lallana's shot in the 65th.

0th-straight-win.html

Gasol Leads Spain Past France and Into Final

BYLINE: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

SECTION: Section B; Column 0; Sports Desk; SPORTS BRIEFING | BASKETBALL; Pg. 14

LENGTH: 276 words


Pau Gasol overwhelmed host France, the defending champion, by scoring 40 points
in an 80-75 victory in overtime on Thursday in Lille as Spain advanced to the
final of the European basketball championship and into next year's Rio de
Janeiro Olympics. Spain, the champion in 2009 and 2011, will play the winner of
Friday's semifinal between Serbia and Lithuania. The two finalists qualify
automatically for the 2016 Olympics.

â-  Allie Quigley scored 20 points to help the host Chicago Sky beat the Indiana
Fever, 77-72, in the opener of the W.N.B.A.'s Eastern Conference semifinals.
Elena Delle Donne, the league's most valuable player, had 14 points for Chicago
-- 12 after halftime.

â-  Phoenix Mercury center Brittney Griner has won the W.N.B.A. Defensive Player
of the Year Award for the second straight season. The 6-foot-8 Griner became the
first player in league history to average at least four blocks a game, with 105
in 26 contests.

â-  Courtney Paris of the Tulsa Shock won the W.N.B.A. Peak Performance Award
for rebounding for a second straight season. Paris averaged 9.3 rebounds per
game.

â-  A federal appeals court said a minority owner of the Miami Heat could not
stop a woman from running a scathingly critical blog featuring an unflattering
photo of him. Raanan Katz, a Florida real estate developer, had sought to stop
Irina Chevaldina, a disgruntled former tenant in one of his shopping centers,
from using the ''ugly'' and ''embarrassing'' photo, for which he held the
copyright. But the United States Court of Appeals for the 11th Circuit agreed
with a lower court judge that Chevaldina had made fair use of the photo.
(REUTERS)




URL:
http://www.nytimes.com/2015/09/18/sports/basketball/gasol-leads-spain-past-franc
e-and-into-final.html

Colsaerts Sets Pace at Italian Open With a 63

BYLINE: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

SECTION: Section B; Column 0; Sports Desk; SPORTS BRIEFING | GOLF; Pg. 14

LENGTH: 39 words


Nicolas Colsaerts had eight straight birdies and finished with a nine-under-par
63 to take the lead in the Italian Open at Golf Club Milano in Monza. Francesco
Molinari was tied for second at 65 with Kristoffer Broberg and Shiv Kapur.



URL:
http://www.nytimes.com/2015/09/18/sports/golf/colsaerts-sets-pace-at-italian-ope
n-with-a-63.html

                         The New York Times on the Web

The Best Sellers: Filed Under Sports

SECTION: Section ; Column 0; Sports Desk; Pg.

LENGTH: 414 words


Here are the best-selling sports books in August 2015, according to the New York
Times best-seller list:

1. THE BOYS IN THE BOAT by Daniel James Brown (Penguin). The University of
Washington's eight-oar crew and its quest for gold at the 1936 Berlin Olympics.

2. UNBROKEN by Laura Hillenbrand (Random House). An Olympic runner's story of
survival as a prisoner of the Japanese in World War II; a 2014 movie.

3. MY FIGHT / YOUR FIGHT by Ronda Rousey with Maria Burns Ortiz (Regan Arts).
Rousey -- an Olympic medalist in judo, an undefeated Ultimate Fighting
Championship women's bantamweight champion and a Hollywood celebrity -- tells
her story.

4. BARBARIAN DAYS by William Finnegan (Penguin Press). This surfing chronicle
and memoir by a New Yorker writer celebrates a lifelong obsession.

5. YES! by Daniel Bryan and Craig Tello (St. Martin's). Behind the scenes with
the former World Wrestling Entertainment heavyweight champion.

6. SABAN by Monte Burke (Simon & Schuster). A biography of Nick Saban, the
University of Alabama football coach.

7. FRIDAY NIGHT LIGHTS by H. G. Bissinger (Da Capo Press). The now classic tale
of a season in the life of the Permian High School Panthers of Odessa, Tex.

8. THE BEST TEAM MONEY CAN BUY by Molly Knight (Simon & Schuster). The inside
story of the Los Angeles Dodgers' 2013 and 2014 seasons and how the team was
remade from top to bottom.

9. IT'S GOOD TO BE GRONK by Rob Gronkowski with Jason Rosenhaus (Gallery/Jeter).
The New England Patriots tight end takes readers on a tour of his life, with
stops at his parents' kitchen table, the playing field, the locker room and the
green room.

10. WHEN THE GAME WAS OURS by Larry Bird and Earvin Magic Johnson with Jackie
MacMullan (Houghton Mifflin Harcourt). Two great basketball players discuss
their careers, their long rivalry and their eventual friendship.

And One ...

18. RED SOX RHYMES by Dick Flavin (William Morrow). Sixty-four ''verses and
curses'' inspired by the Boston Red Sox, written by the announcer and poet
laureate for Fenway Park.

Rankings reflect sales for August 2015. The sports titles ranked here are
selected by the editors from among all adult nonfiction books in all print and
electronic formats, as reported to the New York Times best-seller lists for the
previous month. The definition of sports is deliberately broad and inclusive, so
as to reflect all manner of the outdoor sports world, varying from the
professional leagues to personal athleticism.




URL: http://www.nytimes.com/2015/09/18/sports/the-best-selling-sports-books.html

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

DOCUMENT-TYPE: List

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                               The New York Times

                           September 18, 2015 Friday
                              Late Edition - Final

Spare Times

BYLINE: By JOSHUA BARONE

SECTION: Section C; Column 0; The Arts/Cultural Desk; Pg. 29

LENGTH: 3424 words


Museums and Sites

American Museum of Natural History: 'Countdown to Zero' (continuing) Smallpox is
the only human disease to have been eradicated, but what about Guinea worm,
polio, malaria and others? This exhibition, presented in collaboration with the
Carter Center, examines international efforts to control and wipe out infection.
Daily from 10 a.m. to 5:45 p.m., Central Park West and 79th Street,
212-769-5200, amnh.org.

Center for Jewish History: 'Allied in the Fight: Jews, Blacks and the Struggle
for Civil Rights' (through Oct. 9) Told through photos, letters, archival
materials and film, this exhibition looks at the complicated role that Jewish
people played in the American civil rights movement, with a focus on the shared
projects and joint organizational efforts of black and Jewish people in the
fight against injustice. 15 West 16th Street, Flatiron district, 212-294-8301,
cjh.org; closed from 2 p.m. Tuesday until 9:30 a.m. Thursday.

'The Fence' (through Oct. 11) This outdoor photo installation stretches along
1,250 feet of Brooklyn Bridge Park's greenway. A sister initiative to United
Photo Industries's ''Photoville'' (also in the park through Sunday), the show
aims to assemble photographers whose work best represents the idea of community
across cultural and geographic boundaries. Old Fulton Street, at Furman Street,
Dumbo, Brooklyn, 718-215-9075, fence.photoville.com; free.

Free Third Fridays at Brooklyn Historical Society (Friday) Every third Friday
through November, the historical society will stay open after hours with free
admission. The program begins this week with a chance to explore the museum's
exhibitions with music, wine and beer (also free). From 5 to 9 p.m., 128
Pierrepont Street, near Clinton Street, Brooklyn Heights, 718-222-4111,
brooklynhistory.org.

'Global Citizen: The Architecture of Moshe Safdie' (through Jan. 10) This
touring exhibition, a retrospective of Mr. Safdie's career of more than 50
years, makes its way to New York with new material based on the architect's
recent work related to dense urbanism in Asia. Donald Albrecht from the Museum
of the City of New York organized the material in this show, which also explores
Mr. Safdie's design philosophy that buildings should be extensions of their
physical, historical and cultural contexts. National Academy Museum, 1083 Fifth
Avenue, at 89th Street, 212-369-4880, nationalacademy.org.

Morgan Library and Museum: 'Alice: 150 Years of Wonderland' (through Oct. 12)
The centerpiece of this exhibition is the original manuscript of Lewis Carroll's
''Alice's Adventures in Wonderland,'' traveling from the British Library in
London. Joining the book are letters, drawings, photographs and more that shed
light on how the beloved book came to be, and why it still holds our attention
after 150 years. 225 Madison Avenue, at 36th Street, 212-685-0008,
themorgan.org.

Museum of Chinese in America: 'Sub Urbanisms: Casino Urbanization, Chinatowns
and the Contested American Landscape' (Thursday through Jan. 31) Stephen Fan, an
architecture professor and curator, examines the trend of Chinese casino workers
in Connecticut converting suburban homes into multifamily communities. This
exhibition is both creative and historical; it takes the present to imagine the
future of housing design while looking back on the events that created the trend
of suburban migration. 215 Centre Street, Lower Manhattan, 212-619-4785,
mocanyc.org.

Museum of the Moving Image: 'How Cats Took Over the Internet' (through January)
Even people who hate cats can't easily get through an hour of browsing online
without coming across some kind of feline clickbait. This exhibition takes a
critical look at and tells the story of how we, as a society, got to this point.
Yes, there are cat GIFs. 35th Avenue at 37th Street, Astoria, Queens,
718-784-0077, movingimage.us.

National Museum of the American Indian: 'Meryl McMaster: Second Self' (through
Dec. 11) Meryl McMaster, an artist from Canada and a Plains Cree member of the
Siksika Nation, shows her ''Second Self'' photography series, which uses
portraiture to explore the complex ways in which identity is constructed. 1
Bowling Green, Lower Manhattan, 212-514-3700, nmai.si.edu; free.

New York Transit Museum Grand Central Terminal Gallery Annex: 'New York's
Transportation Landmarks' (through Nov. 1) It's been 50 years since New York
passed its Landmarks Law, which covers over 30,000 buildings and structures
around the city. To celebrate the anniversary, the New York Transit Museum has
created an exhibition that explores the history of development, use and even
rescue of these landmarks. More information: 212-878-0106,
web.mta.info/mta/museum.

New York Transit Museum: 'Spanning the Narrows: The Verrazano Bridge at 50'
(through fall) Photographs, maps, drawings, models and other archival materials
related to the construction of the bridge (including correspondence from Robert
Moses, who oversaw the project) are part of this exhibition commemorating its
50th anniversary. Boerum Place and Schermerhorn Street, Brooklyn Heights,
718-694-1600, mta.info/mta/museum.

New-York Historical Society: 'The Hirschfeld Century: The Art of Al Hirschfeld'
(through Oct. 12) This exhibition includes over 100 original drawings by the
illustrator Al Hirschfeld (1903-2003), who was known in particular for his
drawings of celebrities. The show has a special emphasis on his work for The New
York Times, where he was a contributor for more than 70 years. Tickets are
available at the museum or in advance online. 170 Central Park West, at 77th
Street, 212-873-3400, nyhistory.org.

Old Stone House: 'In Search of One City: Sensing (in)equality' (through Oct. 10)
This exhibition, with a variety of works gathered by the artist Katherine
Gressel, explores the role of artists in investigating, making sense of and
possibly even reconciling problems of income inequality in New York. Art from
the show includes, for example, posters that advise poor people on how to suffer
politely, as well a jukebox that plays interviews with low-wage workers. On view
Fridays from 3 to 6 p.m. and by appointment, 336 Third Street, between Fourth
and Fifth Avenues, Park Slope, Brooklyn, 718-768-3195, theoldstonehouse.org.

'Picture This: New Orleans' (Saturday and Sunday) The photographer Mary Ellen
Mark was commissioned by CNNMoney in April to document the ongoing recovery
efforts in New Orleans a decade after Hurricane Katrina. The assignment turned
out to be her last -- Ms. Mark died just after returning. She was 75. Her last
photographs, as well as a related video and slide show of pictures by her former
students, are on display here as part of this multimedia project presented by
CNN and the International Center of Photography. (Through Sept. 27.) Nolan Park,
Building 19A, Governors Island, 212-857-0000, icp.org/exhibitions.

'Sea Level: Five Boroughs at Water's Edge' (through Dec. 31) In its first pop-up
exhibition for the Seaport Culture District, the American Institute of
Architects presents a water's eye view of the city through photos by Elizabeth
Felicella and accompanying essays by Robert Sullivan. The panoramic view of New
York starts at New York Harbor and makes its way along the East River, showing
the shore of each borough along the way. Center @ the Seaport, 181 Front Street,
South Street Seaport, Lower Manhattan, 212-683-0023, cfa.aiany.org.

'Webtoon' (through Oct. 16) This exhibition highlights the culture of Korean
webtoons -- comics specifically made for the Internet. In addition to displaying
the comics, this show will also take a look at the media and commercial products
that have been inspired by popular webtoons. Korean Cultural Service New York,
Gallery Korea, 460 Park Avenue, at 57th Street, Manhattan, 212-759-9550,
koreanculture.org.


Events

92Y Annual Street Festival (Sunday) The 92nd Street Y presents an afternoon of
Broadway, dance, martial arts and more. There's also a kid-friendly stage, with
concerts and student dancers. Visitors can take a peek at 92Y's class offerings,
and raffles provide a chance to join one for free. Other prizes include tickets
to talks, concerts and the upcoming revival of ''Fiddler on the Roof.'' From
noon to 5 p.m., 1395 Lexington Avenue, at 92nd Street, 212-415-5500,
92y.org/event/street-festival.

The Big Emmys Quiz Thing (Sunday) This isn't an Emmys party for couch potatoes.
The Big Quiz Thing brings its trivia prowess to Le Poisson Rouge for a live game
show throughout the Emmy Awards, beginning with the red carpet and lasting
throughout the ceremony. During commercial breaks, there will be quick games and
chances to win prizes all night. At 6 p.m., 158 Bleecker Street, Greenwich
Village, 212-505-3474, lepoissonrouge.com, bigquizthing.com.

Crossing the Line 2015 (through Oct. 4) This festival, an interdisciplinary
wonder from the French Institute Alliance Française, returns with nearly a month
of programming that aims to reach all ages and tastes. On Saturday and Sunday,
the artists Gustavo Ciriaco and Andrea Sonnberger present the American premiere
of ''Here Whilst We Walk,'' a performance piece in which participants are
brought together by a giant rubber band. Other highlights include the multimedia
artist Shezad Dawood's ''It Was a Time That Was a Time,'' a postapocalyptic film
shot on the beaches of New York, as well as the artist Elana Langer's pop-up
shops as part of her hybrid performance piece ''What I Live By,'' an exploration
of luxury that attaches a new label to everyday accessories. The pop-up's
schedule, along with the festival's lineup, is at fiaf.org/ctl. At various times
and venues.

El Grito: Mexico's Independence Day (Friday) El Grito de Dolores (Spanish for
''the cry of Dolores'') marked the beginning of the Mexican War of Independence
on Sept. 16, 1810. Mano a Mano: Mexican Culture Without Borders, along with Masa
and the Jaime Lucero Mexican Studies Institute, commemorate the 205th
anniversary with an evening of festivities celebrating Mexican culture and
traditions. At 6 p.m., Church of the Intercession, 550 West 155th Street, near
Broadway, Harlem, 212-587-3070, manoamano.us; free, but reservations are
recommended.

Feast of San Gennaro (through Sunday) This annual tribute to the patron saint of
Naples is also known for its spectacle, food and music. Saturday is the official
feast day, which features a religious procession and the unveiling of what is
being billed as the world's largest gelato cone from Ferrara Bakery and Cafe. At
various times, Grand Street, at Mott Street, Chinatown, 212-768-9320,
sangennaro.org.

German-American Steuben Parade and Oktoberfest (Saturday) Germanic heritage is
on display at this annual parade, which coincides with the beginning of
Oktoberfest (Sept. 19 through Oct. 4). Marching bands, floats and dancers will
make their way down Fifth Avenue, from East 86th to 65th Street, from noon to 2
p.m. Afterward, the party moves to Central Park for Oktoberfest. From 2 to 6
p.m., Rumsey Playfield, midpark at 70th Street, 347-454-2269. More information
is at germanparadenyc.org.

Harlem Healthy Soul Festival (Saturday) The Apollo Theater, as well as 126th
Street behind it, is transformed into a wellness fair with free screenings,
nutritious cooking demonstrations, fitness and more to address health concerns
like obesity, asthma and high blood pressure. The day also features live
entertainment and celebrity appearances, such as music from Erica Campbell and
the D.J. Big Tigger. From noon to 7 p.m., Apollo Theater, 253 West 125th Street,
Harlem, harlemhealthy.org; free.

JCC Manhattan Open House (Sunday) This annual event gives the public a chance to
sample the physical fitness and artistic offerings of the JCC. From noon to 6
p.m., the health and wellness center hosts free yoga, dance and cardio classes.
The art studios are open from 3 to 6 p.m., during which time visitors can watch
crafting and cooking demonstrations, or take part in a workshop. Registration is
strongly encouraged. 334 Amsterdam Avenue, at 76th Street, 646-504-5708,
jccmanhattan.org; free.

New York Bike Jumble (Saturday) This flea market is like the used bicycle
section of Craigslist brought to life. Vendors come from up and down the East
Coast to sell beaters, vintage collectibles, accessories and more for a wide
range of prices. From 10 a.m. to 4 p.m., Old Stone House, 336 Third Street,
between Fourth and Fifth Avenues, Park Slope, Brooklyn, nybikejumble.com.

Peking Opera Festival (Sunday) ''The Three Inch Lotus'' makes its American debut
in this festival from the Peking Opera Company of China. Don't expect anything
along the lines of tuneful bel canto; this centuries-old opera form incorporates
a blend of song, dance and acrobatics. ''The Three Inch Lotus,'' a modern opera,
follows the story of a woman who was forced to follow traditions like
foot-binding and arranged marriage. As a mother, she must decide whether to
impose the same restrictions on her daughter. At 2:30 p.m., Skirball Center for
the Performing Arts, 566 La Guardia Place, at Washington Square South, Greenwich
Village, 866-811-4111, nyuskirball.org; sold out.

'Romeo and Juliet' (Thursday) Lincoln Center is adding dance to its
silver-screen repertoire with the series ''Great American Dance,'' which brings
tapings of past performances to movie theaters across the country. Opening the
series is the San Francisco Ballet production of Prokofiev's ''Romeo and
Juliet,'' staged by Helgi Tomasson and starring Maria Kochetkova, who recently
joined American Ballet Theater as a principal dancer. The film, hosted by Kelly
Ripa and Michael Strahan, will play in three theaters in Manhattan at 7 p.m.;
other locations and details are at lincolncenteratthemovies.org and
855-473-4612.

Videology Presents Movie Trivia (Tuesday) Videology, the Brooklyn bar and
cinema, hosts a free film-themed trivia contest every week. The game varies; you
will want to know theme songs, facts, quotations (especially ones from Nicolas
Cage) and more. The winning team receives a free round of drinks, and there are
chances to win drinks each round. At 8:30 p.m., 308 Bedford Avenue, at South
First Street, Williamsburg, Brooklyn, 718-782-3468, videology.info.

West Side Community Garden Arts and Crafts Festival  (Saturday and Sunday) This
quiet, lush garden tucked in the middle of an Upper West Side block hosts its
annual exhibition and sale of items like jewelry, ceramics, paintings and other
handmade crafts. Both days include performances and programming for children
(Danny the Clown at 12:45 p.m. Saturday) and adults (wine and cheese reception
at 4 p.m. Sunday). From 10:30 a.m. to 4:30 p.m., West 89th Street, between
Columbus and Amsterdam Avenues, westsidecommunitygarden.org; free.

Spoken Word

Kareem Abdul-Jabbar (Thursday) For Mr. Abdul-Jabbar's fiction debut, he took on
the Sherlock Holmes franchise and shifted the focus to the famous detective's
brother, Mycroft. Bryant Park Reading Room's summer season winds down with Mr.
Abdul-Jabbar discussing ''Mycroft Holmes'' with the novel's co-author, Anna
Waterhouse. Afterward he'll sign books (no memorabilia). At 12:30 p.m., Bryant
Park, Avenue of the Americas, at 40th Street, 212-768-4242, bryantpark.org;
free.

M.T. Anderson (Wednesday) Mr. Anderson, a National Book Award-winning author,
discusses his nonfiction debut, ''City of the Dead: Dmitri Shostakovich and the
Siege of Leningrad.'' As the book's title suggests, it focuses on the composer's
life, especially when he was writing his famous Leningrad Symphony during World
War II. At 7 p.m., KGB Bar, 85 East Fourth Street, East Village, 212-505-3360,
kgbbar.com.

Jonathan Franzen (Thursday) The 92nd Street Y's Poetry Center opens its 77th
season with Mr. Franzen reading from his latest novel, ''Purity.'' With the
book, which has an intimate plot but a wide-reaching scope, he ''has added a new
octave to his voice,'' Michiko Kakutani wrote in a review for The New York
Times. After the reading, Mr. Franzen will be interviewed by Mark Greif, a
founding editor of the journal n+1. At 8 p.m., 92nd Street Y, 1395 Lexington
Avenue, 212-415-5500, 92y.org.

Walking Tours

Long Island City Tours: Queens Cool Uncovered (Sunday) The idea behind this tour
is that Queens is due for more attention, starting with Long Island City. The
tour includes highlights of the neighborhood's history and arts scene, with
stops at galleries and crafts and food vendors. The meeting location is given at
registration. At 2:30 p.m., 212-209-3370, bqetours.com.

After Anatevka  (Sunday) At the end of the musical ''Fiddler on the Roof,'' the
Jewish residents of Anatevka are banished from their shtetl and Tevye, the
show's main character, leaves for America with his family. This walking tour is
a sort of sequel: a look at what life in the United States was like for the more
than two million Jews who came from Eastern Europe. And, because the tour is
inspired by ''Fiddler,'' it will include live musical accompaniment from the
violist Nikki Federman as well an appearance by Ben Rappaport, who will be
playing the part of Perchik in the musical's upcoming Broadway revival. At 11
a.m., beginning at the Museum at Eldridge Street, 12 Eldridge Street, Lower East
Side, 212-219-0888, eldridgestreet.org; reservations are required.

Bryant Park Public Tours (Wednesdays) Bryant Park hasn't always been the clean,
open space it is today. This tour provides some insights on its history,
including its darker days as a ''needle park'' in the 1970s, as well as its
award-winning design and maintenance efforts. The tour meets at the fountain at
41st Street at Avenue of the Americas. Registration is required. At 11 a.m.,
Bryant Park, 212-768-4242, bryantpark.org.

Flatiron District Walking Tour (Sundays) This free tour meets at 11 a.m. on the
southwest corner of Madison Square Park, at 23rd Street and Broadway, in front
of the William Seward statue. Sponsored by the Flatiron/23rd Street Partnership;
discoverflatiron.org.

History of Wall Street Tour (weekdays) Stops on this tour, led by Wall Street
Walks, include the New York Stock Exchange, Trinity Church, the Wall Street
Bull, and ground zero and the Sept. 11 memorial. The tours last 90 minutes and
begin at 11 a.m. and 1:30 p.m. (Also at 3 p.m. on Tuesdays and Fridays.) More
details: wallstreetwalks.com.

Jewish Colonial Manhattan (Sunday) This tour, in the midst of the High Holy
Days, follows the story of 23 Jewish immigrants who came to Manhattan in 1654.
The small group was heavily restricted, and finding work was difficult. Still,
they and future newcomers had to find ways to get by while creating a lasting
Jewish presence with, for example, kosher food and houses of worship. Meets at 1
p.m., in front of the National Museum of the American Indian, 1 Bowling Green,
Lower Manhattan, 212-242-5762, joycegoldhistorytours.com.

Save the Village (Saturday, Sunday and Tuesday) Last year the Steven Kasher
Gallery in Chelsea put on an exhibition with the photography of Fred W.
McDarrah, who documented the changing scene of Greenwich Village since the
1960s. Now, the spirit of that show has taken the form of this walking tour,
which includes stops at the places McDarrah captured on film: locales like
Washington Square Park and the Stonewall Inn. At 10 a.m.; the tour meets at
Christopher Park, Stonewall Place, at Seventh Avenue, West Village,
savethevillagetours.com.

A Taste of Jewish New York (Sunday) Participants in this tour will get an
insider's look at the customs of the Hasidic residents of Borough Park,
Brooklyn. Highlights include a stop at a lively shopping area and the chance to
try a variety of traditional foods. Modest attire is requested -- no shorts, low
necklines or sleeveless clothing. The tour meets at 9:45 a.m. at Fort Hamilton
Parkway and 44th Street; 718-339-2302, timelinetouring.com.

Union Square: Crossroads of New York (Saturday) Sponsored by the Union Square
Partnership, this free year-round tour focuses on the area's political and
social histories. The walk, led by guides from Big Onion Walking Tours, meets at
2 p.m. by the statue of Lincoln in Union Square Park, near the 16th Street
transverse. 212-517-1826, unionsquarenyc.org.

JOSHUA BARONE

versions of Around Town and For Children listings are in a searchable guide at
nytimes.com/events.

World Briefing | Africa; South Sudan: Scores Are Killed as Fuel Truck Explodes

BYLINE: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

SECTION: Section A; Column 0; Foreign Desk; Pg. 8

LENGTH: 272 words


JUBA, South Sudan --  A fuel truck exploded in South Sudan, killing dozens of
people who had converged around the vehicle to siphon fuel, officials said
Thursday.

Eighty-five people were killed in the accidental explosion in Western Equatoria
state on Wednesday, presidential spokesman Ateny Wek Ateny told The Associated
Press. However, the provincial governor, Patrick Raphael Zamoi, cited a much
higher death toll of 176 and said others were critically injured.

"People are still dying; they have not assessed the exact number in the
hospital," Zamoi said.

The explosion happened in Maridi town after the truck veered off the road,
according to Ateny.

Citing local authorities, he said the tanker was "full of petrol" that started
to leak and residents were siphoning off fuel when someone lit a cigarette,
sparking an explosion.

Ateny said the injured were taken to local hospitals, which were overwhelmed.
Some victims were burned beyond recognition, he said.

Layal Horanieh, spokeswoman for the International Committee of the Red Cross in
the South Sudanese capital of Juba, said the aid group has sent two burn kits to
Maridi, each with enough equipment to treat at least 50 patients.

Deadly fuel tanker explosions are common in East Africa, where poor residents
living near highways converge around fuel tankers involved in accidents to steal
gas and then sell it.

In June 2013, 29 people were killed and scores injured in an explosion after a
collision between a fuel truck and a passenger van in the Ugandan capital of
Kampala.

This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in
print.

Review: 'Some Kind of Hate,' a Bullying-Revenge Slasher Tale

BYLINE: By HELEN T. VERONGOS

SECTION: Section C; Column 0; The Arts/Cultural Desk; Pg. 8

LENGTH: 327 words


Lincoln Taggert, a human target and luckless hero, lives with his abusive,
alcoholic biker father. His mom survives only in Lincoln's sketches, crowned by
a penciled-in halo. His school is no escape.

There, a bully (read sadist) is waiting to dole out pain and humiliation --
until the day Lincoln loses his Zenlike cool. Releasing an almost primal rage,
he sinks his fork satisfyingly into his tormentor's face.

As punishment, Lincoln (Ronen Rubinstein, who set hearts to beating in his
single appearance on ''Orange Is the New Black'') is shipped off to Mind's Eye
Academy, a desert ''school'' for troubled kids that has a habit of losing its
charges.

Just on the other side of the filmy divide between this world and the next, is
another victim of bullies, the one blob of ectoplasm that no one at Mind's Eye
wants to meet: the walking-dead alum Moira, with her greenish pallor and choker
strung with razor blades. She is played by Sierra McCormick, who packs Disney
Channel credentials.

Suffice it to say that the divide is torn, freeing Moira to practice the
passive-aggressive telekinetic torture that is her forte. When she digs a blade
into her arm or slices her own throat, the pain and carnage are also visited on
her chosen victim. Jammy gouts of grenadine blood bubble from her wounds and
theirs, making a hemorrhage of the screen. She kills, but survives.

Watching self-mutilation become a weapon turns sickening fast, and you do not
want to see Moira's thuddingly disgusting technique for inflicting head
injuries. Mind you, she has her reasons.

''Some Kind of Hate'' succeeds at being discomfiting, and Mr. Rubinstein's role
is played well, but the film, directed by Adam Egypt Mortimer, simply does not
cohere. Worse yet, it fails to deliver a thrill -- not even a shiver, except of
revulsion -- rendering all that slasher gore downright anemic.

Some Kind of Hate

Opens on Friday

Directed by Adam Egypt Mortimer

1 hour 23 minutes; not rated

http://www.nytimes.com/2015/09/18/movies/review-some-kind-of-hate-a-bullying-rev
enge-slasher-tale.html

Late-Season Series Gives Rivalry an Added Edge

BYLINE: By JAY SCHREIBER

SECTION: Section B; Column 0; Sports Desk; KEEPING SCORE; Pg. 13

LENGTH: 632 words


Since regular-season interleague baseball made its debut in 1997, the Mets and
the Yankees have played each other every season.

In the beginning, it was a single three-game series, one year in the Bronx, the
next in Queens. It quickly expanded to an annual six-game affair, divided
between the two teams' parks, and was always played on weekends.

On a couple of occasions, rainouts led to the Yankees and the Mets playing
spiced-up, day-night, Queens-Bronx doubleheaders, with the teams starting the
day at one address and finishing at the other. And in 2013 and 2014, the teams
switched to a new format -- four games in a row in midweek, two in each stadium.

No matter the construct, one thing remained consistent: All the games took place
in May, June and the first half of July. None were played after the All-Star
break, and none came late enough in a season to directly influence a pennant
race in which the Mets or, more likely, the Yankees were involved.

Until now. Beginning Friday at Citi Field, the Mets and the Yankees will play a
three-game interleague series that will have a direct bearing on both teams'
postseason aspirations.

When they initially met in late April this season (also a first), it was not
clear that the Yankees would be able to rebound from two consecutive campaigns
in which they finished out of the playoffs. Nor was it that apparent that the
Mets would become contenders after six straight seasons in which they finished
under .500.

But that is exactly what both teams have done, and now the question is, What
will happen over the last two weeks of the season? Can the Mets win often enough
to nail down their first division title since 2006? (Their lead shrank just
enough in the last few days to make their fans nervous.)

And can the Yankees surge past the Toronto Blue Jays and capture the American
League East -- or, if not, at least secure home-field advantage for the
wild-card game?

The circumstances make this weekend series so notable. While it is not the
Subway Series of 2000, when the Yankees beat the Mets in five games to capture
their fourth championship in five seasons, it is the next best thing.

Adding to the intrigue are the pitching matchups, which come wrapped in all
sorts of cautionary health issues.

On Friday night, the Mets rookie Steven Matz will make just the fifth start of
his career, and only his third since missing two months with a torn muscle in
his back. It will also be his first outing in such an intense setting, although
he grew up on Long Island and probably knows what to expect from a such a
meaningful Yankees-Mets game.

He will go up against the Yankees' best pitcher, Masahiro Tanaka, who, for the
first time this season, will be making consecutive starts on four days of rest.
Underlining what is at stake, the Yankees also plan to bring back Tanaka a third
straight time on four days' rest -- next Wednesday in Toronto -- despite
concerns about his right elbow.

Saturday's game will match the Mets' Noah Syndergaard, who is on a rookie
innings limit this season, against Michael Pineda, who is now healthy but is
sometimes a mess on the mound. On Sunday night, the Yankees will send out C. C.
Sabathia, who, bad knee and all, is trying to make himself a late-season asset
despite horrible 2015 numbers -- 4-9 record, 4.93 E.R.A. -- against Matt Harvey,
who is under an innings limit that remains a matter of debate in his first
season back from Tommy John surgery.

Harvey will be making his first appearance since he was hit hard by the
Washington Nationals on Sept. 8 in a game the Mets came back to win. The Mets
intend to limit Harvey to five or six innings and then figure out what is next.
Some of that may depend on how this weekend goes, when interleague baseball will
have an unusual edge.




URL:
http://www.nytimes.com/2015/09/18/sports/baseball/subway-series-gives-yankees-me
ts-rivalry-an-added-edge.html

                         The New York Times on the Web

As Zombie Rumors Fly, China Punishes Social Media Pranksters

BYLINE: By AUSTIN RAMZY

SECTION: Section ; Column 0; Foreign Desk; Pg.

LENGTH: 625 words


A dead alien in the refrigerator. Zombies on the loose. A mythical beast in the
hills.

Scenes straight out of pulp magazines lurk in the back alleys of Chinese social
media, where they can quickly find an eager following and, almost as quickly,
earn a rebuke from skittish authorities.

Science fiction and fantasy tales have been growing in popularity in China,
where some creative efforts have earned official endorsement. Vice President Li
Yuanchao met this week with authors -- including Liu Cixin, who wrote the Hugo
Award-winning novel ''The Three-Body Problem'' -- and called on them to inspire
young people's interest in science and encourage ''faith in realizing the
Chinese Dream,'' the state news agency Xinhua reported.

But even as the Chinese leadership offered praise for the writers, the police
have been less tolerant of social media users' flexing their creativity. Several
people have been punished in the past few years for relaying tales of the
walking undead and extraterrestrial invaders for fear of touching off public
panic.

Here are some of the online rumors that have been met with penalties in China.

There's a Zombie in Guangzhou

Earlier this month, the police in the southern city of Guangzhou published a
notice online that images posted on Weibo of a woman covered in blood and a note
suggesting she was a zombie were fake. The online warning added a reminder for
residents to avoid hallucinogens.

A 21-year-old man from the area with the surname Zhang was given 10 days of
detention for posting the item, the Guangzhou Daily reported. The images were
actually from a film that was shot in Jiangsu Province, the newspaper said.

There's Also a Zombie in That Sarcophagus in Henan

In 2014, photos of a mummified corpse circulated online with suggestions that
they were evidence of a zombie found in the eastern city of Nanjing or in Jianli
County in Hubei Province. The police said the images were of an archaeological
dig the year before in Henan Province that turned up the well-preserved body of
a Qing dynasty official, but no signs of the undead.

Remains discovered in a tomb in Xiangcheng City, in #China 's Henan province..
Astonishingly well-preserved. pic.twitter.com/jd8FNFj3xN -- Ira Vanan
(@irationalme) October 1, 2014

A Mythical Beast Is Roaming Beijing

Also in 2014, photos emerged showing a Gollum-like creature kneeling in a rocky
ravine with a message declaring that it was a ''mythical beast'' discovered in
the Huairou District of Beijing. The local police said the images were merely
candid pictures of an actor in a film who was photographed going to the bathroom
while in costume, the website of People's Daily reported.

There's an Alien in the Fridge

[Video: Not all tales of alien invasion meet with official approval in China, as
was the case in 2013 when a farmer claimed to have electrocuted an
extraterrestrial.  Watch on YouTube.]

In 2013, a farmer in Shandong Province claimed to have encountered five
extraterrestrial creatures, one of whom was killed by an electric fence. The
farmer's story, and photos of the purported alien corpse he kept in a freezer,
drew widespread attention online. The local authorities investigated and held a
news conference to announce that the dead alien was actually made of rubber,
Southern Metropolis Daily reported. The farmer was sentenced to five days of
detention for disturbing public order, Xinhua reported.

(@dee_bosa) June 12, 2013
