from Serbia after Hungary closed its border with Serbia, with most of them
trying to reach Germany. (PHOTOGRAPH BY SERGEY PONOMAREV FOR THE NEW YORK TIMES)

bound for Zagreb. (PHOTOGRAPH BY JEFF J MITCHELL/GETTY IMAGES) MAP

Review: 'Maze Runner: The Scorch Trials' Pits Hardy Teenagers Against a
Mysterious Organization

BYLINE: By JOHN WILLIAMS

SECTION: Section C; Column 0; The Arts/Cultural Desk; Pg. 8

LENGTH: 306 words


Science doesn't yet know how many movies it will take to answer this century's
most pressing question: How will attractive teenagers survive the apocalypse?

''Maze Runner: The Scorch Trials,'' the second in a series about a racially
diverse but otherwise interchangeable set led by a hardy hunk named Thomas
(Dylan O'Brien), throws us right into the action. Stiff, vague bits of
exposition establish that the youths had, indeed, been in some kind of maze. Now
they are in a large industrial compound, saved from a nefarious organization
called WCKD by another mysterious crew led by Janson (Aidan Gillen), a
transparently shady guy himself. The teenagers are among the only people left
immune to a virus that turns humans into zombielike mutants that shriek like
velociraptors.

Thomas discovers that Janson is stringing kids up, unconscious and riddled with
tubes, for some reason related to the virus. That's enough info for him to grab
his friends and skedaddle. Their unlikely jailbreak sends them blinking into a
blasted landscape of ruined skyscrapers and giant sand dunes, like some
combination of Tatooine and Detroit, where they hope to survive long enough to
find a fabled group of resistance fighters.

''The Scorch Trials'' adds nothing new to the unkillable dystopian genre, but
it's at least less ponderous than its predecessor. The many chases and ludicrous
narrow escapes offer respectable doses of adrenaline.

''What do we do now?'' a weary character asks near the end. With one last
rousing speech from Thomas, that's obvious: Make a third movie, due in 2017.

''Maze Runner: The Scorch Trials'' is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned).
Occasional gun violence and fewer bad words than you would utter under similar
duress.

The Maze Runner

The Scorch Trials

Opens on Friday

Directed by Wes Ball

2 hours 11 minutes

http://www.nytimes.com/2015/09/18/movies/review-maze-runner-the-scorch-trials-pi
ts-hardy-teenagers-against-a-mysterious-organization.html

Lofland, Alex Flores and Dylan O'Brien in ''Maze Runner: The Scorch Trials,''
directed by Wes Ball. (PHOTOGRAPH BY RICHARD FOREMAN, JR./TWENTIETH CENTURY FOX
FILM)

Review: 'The Man Who Saved the World' Recounts a Cold War Near Miss

BYLINE: By DANIEL M. GOLD

SECTION: Section C; Column 0; The Arts/Cultural Desk; Pg. 8

LENGTH: 289 words


Accidental nuclear attacks have been the stuff of high-tech thrillers for a
half-century, at least since ''Fail-Safe'' (1964). But this apocalyptic fiction
almost became fact in 1983, averted only by the doubts of a single Soviet Union
officer.

As vividly portrayed in Peter Anthony's ''The Man Who Saved the World,'' Lt.
Col. Stanislav Petrov was in charge of the Soviet early warning systems
overnight on Sept. 26, 1983. Computerized satellites detected first one, then
other launches -- five in all -- of nuclear missiles by the United States. But
there was no visual confirmation, and Colonel Petrov decided to tell his
superiors they were false alarms, despite being required to report these
''maximum verifications.'' Had he followed protocol, retaliatory strikes would
surely have followed, triggering an American response in kind and mutually
assured destruction.

Somewhat clumsily, this hybrid documentary blends re-enactments of those and
other events with Mr. Petrov's real-life trip to the United States in 2006 to
accept an award from the United Nations. Mr. Petrov is a secretive, unlikable
old pensioner, who softens over time in the presence of his young interpreter
and in meetings with Walter Cronkite, Robert De Niro and Kevin Costner.
Depicting Mr. Petrov's bleak life since the death of his wife, the film reflects
on the links each individual has, willingly or not, to the rest of humanity. ''I
was just at the right place at the right time,'' Mr. Petrov says, a simple truth
that becomes shocking when considering the alternative. For that alone, this
account of a Cold War near miss deserves a wide audience.

The Man Who Saved the World

Opens on Friday

Directed by Peter Anthony

1 hour 45 minutes; not rated

http://www.nytimes.com/2015/09/18/movies/review-the-man-who-saved-the-world-reco
unts-a-cold-war-near-miss.html

A People Suffered; Their Art Tells the Story

BYLINE: By HOLLAND COTTER

SECTION: Section C; Column 0; The Arts/Cultural Desk; Pg. 21

LENGTH: 1350 words


Much art is made for pleasure or profit. Some is made to save lives and souls.
The 15 sensational carved wood figures, standing like thorny trees in a grove,
at the end of ''Kongo: Power and Majesty'' at the Metropolitan Museum of Art,
are examples of art of the rescuing kind. They are sculptural responses to a
slow-motion emergency, one that shaped the history of the African continent and
continues to resonate there today.

For centuries the West assumed that Africa had no history, because none had been
found written down. Instead, it was said to be timeless in the way that the
primitive was timeless: that is, retarded, suspended in backwardness. Call that
a state of innocence; call it savagery. Either way, it was a condition to be
patronized, corrected, exploited. Only beginning in the late 20th century, when
the notion of primitivism came under widespread critical fire, were the
antiquity and dynamism of African cultures acknowledged, and demonstrated in
long-researched exhibitions like this one, which has been organized by Alisa
LaGamma, the curator in charge of the department of the arts of Africa, Oceania
and the Americas.

It begins at a very specific time and place: the coast of Central Africa in
1483, the year a navigator named Diogo Cão, on a pioneering mission for the
Portuguese court, landed near the mouth of the Congo River to scout
possibilities for trade. He carried on board several seven-foot-high limestone
columns carved with a cross and the royal coat of arms. With them, he staked
territorial claims for Portugal in what is now Angola. All but one of those
columns vanished long ago. The sole survivor is at the Met, introducing the
exhibition in much the way that, centuries ago, it introduced Europe to Africa,
and vice versa.

The Portuguese had landed in territory occupied by Kongo peoples, who formed
several separate states ruled by kings in urban courts similar to those of
Europe. And the initial encounter was auspicious, viewed by both sides as a
meeting of equals. Spiritually adventurous and intellectually curious, the Kongo
elite took an avid interest in Christianity and quickly learned the skill of
writing. One of the earliest items in the show is a 1517 letter from the Kongo
king to his Portuguese counterpart requesting a shipment of prayer books and
liturgical instruments.

We know from records that many thousands of such things subsequently flooded
into Africa, though none have been tracked down there. What has been found are
religious images made by African artists after European prototypes. A little
brass Kongo figure of a crucified Christ with starburstlike hands and feet is
one. And Western museums hold a small number of objects that, in the 16th and
17th centuries, traveled from Africa to Europe as souvenirs or gifts, landing in
Medici palaces and cathedral treasuries.

A lot of what has been preserved of this precious export material is in the Met
show, and consists mainly of two types of luxury items: elephant tusks carved
with exquisite geometric patterns (one is from the Palazzo Pitti in Florence),
and woven palm-fiber textile panels incorporating the same abstract designs.
Examples of both float, as if on the sea, in the blue-walled opening gallery.
And they carry history with them. The patterns they share appear in almost
identical form on African ceramics dating to the late Iron Age, and on
ceremonial caps and capes made between the 16th and the early 20th century.

The wearers of such regalia included priests or ritual specialists, who played a
crucial role in governance. The Kongo cosmos was generally understood to be made
up of two realms, one occupied by the living, the other by the ancestral dead.
The priest's job was to maintain communication between the two, and to channel
otherworldly energy through certain charismatic objects, often sculpted figures
called minkisi (singular, nkisi), which policed human behavior and promoted
peace. Social balance and continuance were the highest good, embodied in paired
male and female images, and in the perfect, endless abstract patterns woven in
textiles and inscribed on ivories.

About halfway into the show, however, something appears that throws that balance
off: It's a tusk covered with tiny figures, among them shackled slaves. The
piece is late, probably from the 1880s, but the realities it documents are much
older. The rapport between Europe and the Kingdom of Kongo was brief. Portugal
soon made its colonialist intentions clear. Other Western nations -- France,
Britain, the Netherlands -- aggressively followed its lead. Kongo peoples lost
their gainful position as gatekeepers to the wealth of the continent's interior.

Worse, the effects of the Atlantic slave trade were catastrophic. Africans had
always participated as suppliers. But by the mid-17th-century, Kongo territory
roughly corresponding to modern Angola, Congo and the Congo Republic-- had
itself become a primary source of captives. By 1850, a third of its population
had ended up in chains in the Americas.

Nor was there relief to be found in Africa. There the age of colonialism was
underway. Forced labor was common. With the adult male population reduced by
slavery, the nuclear family, the core unit of Kongo social organization, was
shattered. Traditional occupations, economic structures and value systems, along
with the communal identity they sustained, were radically destabilized.

Religion was what was left. Female power figures, depicted as women of idealized
beauty supporting and nursing infant-size adult males, proliferated. Regal but
tender, they held the promise of fecundity in a withering time, and certain
sculptors made a specialty of them. Two such artists -- called the Master of
Kasadi, the Master of Makaya Vista and the Master of Boma Vonde, for the regions
where they worked -- have been identified by style. Although each adheres to a
fixed image type, their approaches, seen in comparative pieces in the show, are
distinctive in detail and mood.

As expressive as these images were, they could do nothing to prevent the reign
of terror visited on the Kongo world by Belgian colonial rule beginning in the
1870s. At that point, in what feels like a last-ditch move, a shock troop of
male power figures, called Mangaaka, was brought into play. Only around 20 are
known; 15 of those, from collections in Europe and the United States, including
the Met, are in the final gallery.

Just under life-size, they were carved from wood by master artists. Fitted with
animal-hair beards and huge white ceramic eyes, they lean forward, mouths open,
as if looking and listening intently, ready to leap. Their torsos bristle with
pounded-in spikes and nails, each the seal of a vow made or an injustice to be
prosecuted. The source of their energy lies in magical substances -- medicines
-- placed by priests in their hollowed-out bellies and behind their eyes.

Such images are the spiritual equivalent of antibodies, designed to hunt down
and eliminate infection in a social body on the verge of systemic collapse. They
were meant to stop a viral history in its tracks, reverse its course. They were
focused in a way that makes much other art, however ambitious, feel vague in
purpose, a distraction from, rather than an engagement with, the politics of
living and dying. It's a measure of the respect they inspired that all of the
figures, brothers in arms, seem to have had their medicine removed before
leaving Africa. The West would get the form but not the substance of their
might.

They make a memorable conclusion to an unusually tight, idea-filled and
troubling show. When these figures were conceived, the Scramble for Africa was
on full-bore, with Western nations barbarously slicing up and devouring a
continent. That depredation has never stopped, even if some of its participants
have changed, China being the latest scrambler. And Africa's history, embedded
in some of the world's most potent art, goes on.

''Kongo: Power and Majesty'' runs through Jan. 3 at The Metropolitan Museum of
Art; 212  535-7710; metmuseum­.org.




URL:
http://www.nytimes.com/2015/09/18/arts/design/review-kongo-power-and-majesty-at-
the-metropolitan-museum-of-art.html

Review: Illustrated Kimonos Celebrate Japan's Once Mighty Military

BYLINE: By KEN JOHNSON

SECTION: Section C; Column 0; The Arts/Cultural Desk; Pg. 23

LENGTH: 292 words



Enlightened modern people tend to think of war as a repugnant, if sometimes
regrettable necessity. At different times and places, however, it has been
regarded -- and still is for some cultures -- as an enterprise of great moral
and spiritual value. Such a positive perspective is vividly illustrated in this
visually and historically fascinating exhibition of more than 30 Japanese
kimonos with printed images celebrating Japanese military might. All but one are
from the 1930s and early 1940s, the period when Japan invaded Manchuria, waged
war against China and aligned with the Axis powers of Germany and Italy.

Created by unidentified graphic artists for men, women and children, the kimonos
bear lively compositions of utmost sophistication reflecting international
styles like Art Deco and Depression Modern. In patchwork patterns and suavely
muted colors, they depict fighter planes, battleships, antiaircraft artillery,
aerial landscapes, maps and cute children dressed as soldiers.

One of the most striking has scores of red-and-white fields of Japanese flags --
rising suns and simple discs -- overlapping to create an optically buzzing, near
abstraction. A poetic and beautiful woman's kimono shows red-and-yellow
airplanes decorated with cherry blossoms flying angelically this way and that
over a background of horizontal red-and-white stripes. The image on a man's
haori -- a kimono-style jacket -- envisions in black and white a luminous city
of the future with a streamlined zeppelin and airplanes flying over blocky,
modern buildings. War may be terrible, but for its victors it promises heaven on
earth.

'Japanese Propaganda Kimonos, 1905-1941'

Edward Thorp Gallery

210 11th Avenue, at West 25th Street, Chelsea

Through Oct. 17




URL:
http://www.nytimes.com/2015/09/18/arts/design/review-illustrated-kimonos-celebra
te-japans-once-mighty-military.html

GRAPHIC: PHOTO: A woman's haori, circa 1940, at the Edward Thorp Gallery.
(PHOTOGRAPH BY EDWARD THORP GALLERY, NEW YORK)

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

DOCUMENT-TYPE: Review

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

New Miami Art Museum Appoints a Director

BYLINE: By BRETT SOKOL, HILARIE M. SHEETS and JOSHUA BARONE

SECTION: Section C; Column 0; The Arts/Cultural Desk; INSIDE ART; Pg. 22

LENGTH: 983 words



The offices of Miami's newest art museum are about to become more crowded: The
Institute of Contemporary Art, Miami, has just appointed a new director, Ellen
Salpeter, and added two junior curators.

Ms. Salpeter, the deputy director for external affairs at the Jewish Museum in
New York, said she was anything but daunted by leaving a venerable institution
founded in 1904 for one not even a year old -- and still in temporary quarters,
awaiting the construction of its new 37,500-square-foot home and
15,000-square-foot sculpture garden. ''Having the opportunity to be in at the
beginning with the thinking and strategic planning is very exciting to me,'' she
said.

In a sense, Ms. Salpeter is returning to her roots. She was executive director
of the Thread Waxing Space in New York from 1994 until it closed in 2001. That
nonprofit was a focal point for downtown Manhattan's cultural scene, with key
early shows by artists like Leonardo Drew and Dara Friedman and concerts by a
Who's Who of indie rockers.

Ms. Salpeter said she looked forward to convening a similar stylistic mix in
Miami: ''Art and artists of any persuasion and any medium, whether it's
performing artists, visual artists or poets, have always been in my
wheelhouse.'' The museum is currently hosting a group show of emerging South
Florida artists, including Scott Armetta and Jason Hedges; coming months will
bring solo exhibitions from Shannon Ebner of Los Angeles and the New Yorker John
Miller.

When Ms. Salpeter begins in Miami on Dec. 1, at least she won't have to worry
too much about finances. Irma Braman, co-chairwoman of the museum's board of
trustees, and her husband, Norman, a billionaire auto dealer and longtime civic
activist, are personally funding the construction of the new building. The
museum is also relying solely on other private donors for its $5 million annual
budget. Mr. Braman refused to discuss the building's total cost and played down
an appeal filed by two of the site's neighbors to reverse its city zoning
approval. ''That won't stop us from breaking ground next month and starting
construction,'' with an anticipated museum opening in mid-2017, he said. ''We're
going full blast.'' BRETT SOKOL

Window on the High Line

If millions can stare into your window, why not give them a show? When Ryan Lee
Gallery moved into its third-floor space on West 26th Street in Chelsea in 2014,
with a window at eye level to the High Line, it inaugurated the space RL Window,
with video projections to hook the audience streaming through the elevated park.
Beginning on Oct. 29, it will present its first performance installation,
bringing to life Sandy Skoglund's comically disorienting 1979 photograph
''Hangers.''

A pioneer of staged photography, Ms. Skoglund built the original set for her
breakthrough image, first shown at Castelli Graphics, in her former tenement
studio on Elizabeth Street. There, she taped blue plastic hangers every which
way over aggressively yellow walls and a pink floor, and photographed a young
man in yellow pajamas entering this hallucinatory cabinet of curiosities, also
strewn with rubber duckies, rubber gloves and chairs of the same fluorescent
palette.

''I was imagining that a future culture coming upon these mass-produced objects
might display them as historical artifacts or try to come up with ideas of how
they were used,'' said Ms. Skoglund, who became well known in the 1980s and '90s
for images of people in mundane interiors invaded by, say, green radioactive
cats or giant goldfish that she constructed by hand.

At Ryan Lee, in her first solo show in New York since 2001, she will recreate
the ''Hangers'' tableau, but now oriented toward the High Line rather than a
camera. On Saturdays for the run of the show, a performer will periodically
wander into the room as a stranger in a strange land. ''In some ways, all my
work is a performance, even if it's been private for the camera,'' Ms. Skoglund
said. In the main gallery space, she will exhibit ''True Fiction Two,'' based on
handmade photo collages of people in incongruous places that were first shown at
Castelli in 1987 and later reworked with Photoshop ''to look more
photographic,'' she said.

Jeff Lee, a partner in the gallery, said: ''Handcrafted photography is something
explored by a lot of young artists, and I am really interested in how Sandy's
early body of work is in dialogue with a lot of things happening in contemporary
art. Her trippy psychological spaces and retro color palette are very fresh
again.'' HILARIE M. SHEETS

City of Brotherly 'Amor'

It's not English. But the playful and vibrant design -- four red letters
arranged in a square, the O tilting to the right -- is ubiquitous, and so is its
message: ''Amor.'' This Spanish-language form of Robert Indiana's famous
''Love'' sculpture, a 1998 update of his Pop Art classic, will be unveiled on
Tuesday outside the Philadelphia Museum of Art, about a mile from the tourist
favorite ''Love'' on John F. Kennedy Plaza. The sculptures will be bookends to
Benjamin Franklin Parkway, where Pope Francis is expected to celebrate Mass with
an audience of more than a million on Sept. 27.

Timothy Rub, the museum's director, said that his institution, along with the
Association for Public Art, wanted to commemorate the papal visit with a
sculptural installation. The choice came easily: ''Amor'' means love in both the
pope's native Spanish and the Roman Catholic Church's Latin. The Indiana
sculpture, which is on loan from the Morgan Art Foundation, ''recommended
itself,'' Mr. Rub said.

Come Sept. 28, the pope will be gone, but ''Amor'' will remain for four months.
''This is meant to be a celebration of the pope being here,'' said Penny Bach,
director of the Association for Public Art. ''But on a longer-term basis, it's a
celebration of Philadelphia and its message as an international city.'' JOSHUA
BARONE

http://www.nytimes.com/2015/09/18/arts/design/institute-of-contemporary-art-miam
i-names-ellen-salpeter-as-director.html

World Briefing | Asia; India: Diplomat Accused of Rape Leaves the Country

BYLINE: By NIDA NAJAR; Hari Kumar contributed reporting

SECTION: Section A; Column 0; Foreign Desk; Pg. 8

LENGTH: 757 words


NEW DELHI -- A Saudi diplomat accused of rape by two Nepali women who worked at
his home near Delhi has left India, according to the Indian government, which
confirmed that the man had diplomatic immunity from prosecution.

India's Ministry of External Affairs identified the diplomat as Majed Hassan
Ashoor, the first secretary at the Saudi Embassy, in a statement issued late
Wednesday. The statement did not say when Mr. Ashoor had left India.

Attempts to contact the Saudi Embassy on Thursday were unsuccessful, but it had
previously denied the women's accusations.

The two women, who had worked for Mr. Ashoor as maids, said last week that they
had been repeatedly raped, abused and threatened by the diplomat and other men
at his home in Gurgaon, a city near Delhi. They also said they had been confined
to the residence.

The police began an investigation and removed the women from Mr. Ashoor's home
last week, after receiving a tip from an advocacy group. The women, who have not
been identified and who were 50 and 25, police said, have returned to Nepal.

The ministry's statement on Wednesday said that Mr. Ashoor was protected by the
Vienna Convention on Diplomatic Relations, under which diplomats are immune from
criminal prosecution in the country where they are posted.

Traditionally, India has taken a strong stand on the inviolability of diplomatic
immunity, even when it touched on issues of mistreatment of domestic staff. In
2013, Devyani Khobragade, an Indian diplomat posted in New York, was arrested
and accused of submitting false documents to secure a work visa for her
housekeeper and paying her below the legal wage, but it was Ms. Khobragade's
treatment from the American authorities that provoked a furor in India.

Still, the case involving Mr. Ashoor has hit a nerve because it involves
allegations of rape in India, where sexual violence has been a pressing concern
lately, and because of fears of a rise in trafficking from Nepal since an
earthquake there in April.

G. Parthasarathy, a retired Indian diplomat, said that the Indian government
could have asked the Saudi Embassy to waive diplomatic immunity or expelled the
diplomat from the country. India may have preferred what happened, which was
that the Saudi Embassy withdrew the official, since it would have been reluctant
to provoke Saudi Arabia, Mr. Parthasarathy said.

''We are very sensitive about these matters,'' he said, mentioning the episode
with Ms. Khobragade.

The Criminal Investigation Bureau in Nepal arrested two people on Wednesday
under the Human Trafficking and Transportation Control Act. The two were
suspected of being involved in the recruitment of the women and helping to
connect them to agents in India, said Kiran Bajracharya, a police official with
the Criminal Investigation Bureau. A Nepali agent in Delhi took 100,000 Nepalese
rupees, under $1,000, from an Indian agent for each woman, he said.

The women came in April and June, respectively, from Nepal to India by land,
then later traveled to Sri Lanka, then Jidda, where they stayed for a month, Mr.
Bajracharya said. They ended up coming back to Delhi and working for Mr. Ashoor
in his Gurgaon apartment, though they told the Nepali authorities they were not
paid. It was unclear what they were doing in Saudi Arabia or in India before
they began working for Mr. Ashoor.

Rajendra Man Shrestha, a counsellor at the Embassy of Nepal in New Delhi, said
that the younger woman's husband was sick and needed an operation.

''The victim was motivated by the trafficker that you will be paid by 1,000 in
local money, Saudi money, which is really big money there,'' said Mr. Shrestha,
who spoke to the two women. ''She was convinced.''

Despite the concerns about an increase in human trafficking from Nepal since the
earthquake this spring, official numbers have not risen, said Sunita Nepal,
undersecretary at the human trafficking unit at the Ministry of Women and Child
Social Welfare in Nepal.

The police had been unable to question Mr. Ashoor because of his immunity.
Navdeep Singh Virk, the police commissioner in Gurgaon, said the authorities
would continue to investigate other individuals in connection with the
accusations, based on the women's statements.

''The case will go ahead,'' Deep Kumar Upadhyay, the Nepali ambassador to India,
said in a televised interview with the ANI news agency. He added that it was
''our duty to give justice to the poor victims.''

This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in
print.

left-india-government-says.html

                        The International New York Times

Underdogs or Not, Pressure Is On for Both Teams

BYLINE: By LISA D. MICKEY

SECTION: Section ; Column 0; Sports Desk; Pg.

LENGTH: 1090 words


It could be said that parity has arrived at the Solheim Cup.

Beginning with the inaugural event in 1990, the Americans dominated the biennial
match-play competition pitting Europe against the United States, winning five of
the first seven Solheim Cups.

But this year, for the first time in the event's history, many consider the
Americans to be underdogs against the Europeans, winners of the last two
editions.

When competition begins Friday in the 14th Solheim Cup, the United States will
attempt to wrestle away the trophy at the St. Leon-Rot Golf Club in St.
Leon-Rot, Germany.

And while the Americans hold the Solheim Cup record for most consecutive
victories (3), with triumphs in 1994, 1996 and 1998, as well as in 2005, 2007
and 2009, the Europeans have a chance to equal that streak this weekend.

''They've earned the right to carry that cup for the last two Solheims, and now
we have to earn the right to win it back,'' said Juli Inkster, the United States
captain, when she announced her team in August. ''It's been a long time since
we've been the underdogs. The only way to get that back is to go over there and
work hard and play some good golf.''

Both Europe and the United States will bring a mixture of team experience and
youthful firepower to Germany. Inkster added Alison Lee, 20, who has posted six
top-10 finishes as an L.P.G.A. rookie this season, including a tie for sixth
last week at the Evian Championship in France, the final major of the season.

Europe returns two players who were perfect at the 2013 Solheim Cup: Caroline
Hedwall of Sweden went 5-0, while Carlota Ciganda of Spain was 3-0 as a Solheim
rookie.

The American team has three players who have won L.P.G.A. tournaments this year,
while Europe has two L.P.G.A. tournament winners. The Americans hold a slight
edge in world rankings, with six members in the top 25, while Europe has only
two.

Both sides have six members who played college golf in the United States. In
addition, three of the Europeans have competed for the Great Britain & Ireland
team in the Curtis Cup, while eight of the Americans have competed in that
biennial event. Nearly a dozen players on both sides have competed in the
Women's World Amateur Team Championship.

Europe leads 33-23 in combined Solheim Cup points since 2011, while the
Americans lead 172-160 in points scored since the first event in 1990. The
United States leads the series, 8-5, but its last victory was in 2009.

As the defending champion, Europe needs to win only 14 of the total 28 points to
retain the cup. In 2013, the Europeans had earned 10 points after the first two
days of play and then either won or halved all but two of the 12 singles matches
on the final day to finish with a total of 18 points.

''People try to break it down and be scientific, but we just have to play good
golf, make putts, and the rest will take care of itself,'' said the American
player Gerina Piller. ''The goal is to play tough and win holes.''

Her teammate Lizette Salas was frank about the American squad's status.

''On paper, we are the underdogs and we'll be playing on foreign soil,'' she
said, ''but I also want to think that for an extra push, to stay motivated
throughout the week.''

Another American, Stacy Lewis, agreed that her team was the underdog.

''We've certainly had success in the Solheim Cup, but we have lost the last two
and we're playing in Europe this year,'' said Lewis, who is ranked No.3 in the
world. ''They definitely have the momentum in their favor right now.''

Even though Europe has home advantage, is the two-time defending champion and
will benefit from having two Germans, Sandra Gal and Caroline Masson, on their
side to rally local fan support, members of the European team say the Americans
are not the underdogs.

''On paper, it's the American team by far as the favorite, because the Americans
have a lot more wins,'' said Suzann Pettersen of Norway.

Gal said the United States team was ''very strong,'' pointing to the fact that
''more Americans are in the top world rankings.''

Added Masson: ''I think they're going to come here with some fire and Juli will
make sure they're ready to play.''

But the Europeans, even while overshadowed by their opponents statistically,
give themselves a nod for an intangible factor that wins Solheim Cups.

''As a team, I think Europeans are stronger together,'' Petersen said. ''We
always grind it out and make the best team players.''

In fact, the element of team play has been a focus for Inkster ever since she
was awarded the captain's job this summer. She has worked to help her players
bond. She has even had them take personality tests to gauge compatibility.

Most of all, she has watched how team cohesion has helped Europe find success in
recent years.

''They play with a lot of fire, a lot of passion and they go for broke,''
Inkster said. ''They are a good team, and we have our work cut out for us.''

But she added that the Americans were ''going to get back to basics, roll up our
sleeves and go to work.''

Brittany Lincicome has played on two winning and two losing American Solheim Cup
teams, and, like her captain, believes her side has much to learn from the
Europeans.

''They're really good team players,'' she said. ''We play so well individually,
but we need to learn how to play as a team again.''

And even though the event is returning to Europe, Karine Icher of France said
the long-playing St. Leon-Rot course, near Heidelberg, could favor the
Americans.

''It's a long course and maybe it's a small advantage for the American team
because they're long hitters compared to the Europeans,'' Icher said. ''The
Americans also don't give up.''

Inkster is counting on just that from her players, and some of her team veterans
hope to lead the charge.

''We have to take it to them this year,'' Angela Stanford said. ''We can't be
comfortable with any type of lead.''

Her teammate Morgan Pressel pointed out that winning as a team depended on
individual players winning their matches.

''Putting together the team and the pairings is all a big part of this event,
but at the end of the day, you just have to play really well,'' she said.
''That's what happened the last time: The Europeans outplayed us.''

So Europe has the momentum on home turf, and as Spain's Azahara Muñoz noted,
''Now we know we can win.''

But as both teams know, anything can happen in match play when two equally
matched sides compete.

''They are the two-time defending champs,'' Inkster said. ''The pressure is on
them.''

http://www.nytimes.com/2015/09/18/sports/golf/underdogs-or-not-pressure-is-on-fo
r-both-teams-golf-solheim-cup.html

                        The International New York Times

A Star Who Thrives Under Pressure

BYLINE: By LISA D. MICKEY

SECTION: Section ; Column 0; Sports Desk; SPECIAL REPORT: SOLHEIM CUP; Pg.

LENGTH: 911 words


At the 2013 Solheim Cup in Colorado, Sweden's Caroline Hedwall did something no
other player had ever done: She notched a 5-0 record.

She played in every match and won them all, leading her European Solheim Cup
team to a first-ever victory on American soil. Hedwall didn't bring the same
swashbuckling style to the team as Norway's Suzann Pettersen, or the veteran
confidence of Scotland's Catriona Matthew, or the electric style of Spain's
Azahara Muñoz. But she did offer a smorgasbord of shots that flattened her
competition like a stack of Swedish pancakes.

Even in 2011, when as a rookie professional she was a captain's pick on Europe's
team, Hedwall helped the squad win points in the last three singles matches,
sealing a 15-13 victory in Ireland.

She was two holes down in singles, but fought back and won the last two holes
against Ryann O'Toole to square her match and earn a half point. That half point
secured Europe's victory.

''She made the winning putts in Colorado and Ireland,'' said Carin Koch, the
European captain this year. ''She has that extra switch to turn on for match
play and she stays so cool in pressure situations.''

Hedwall won four tournaments in 2011 on the Ladies European Tour, finishing as
the L.E.T.'s top rookie and top player that year. She is still looking for her
first L.P.G.A. victory, as well as her first top-10 finish this season.

Now 26, she is back on the European Solheim Cup team despite a lackluster
L.P.G.A. season. In 18 tournaments, she had eight missed cuts and her best
result was a tie for 26, at the Swinging Skirts L.P.G.A. Classic in April. Her
season scoring average is 72.98, with only 16 rounds under par.

But what Hedwall will bring to the Solheim Cup, which starts Friday at the St.
Leon-Rot Golf Club in Germany, is not a quantifiable measurement. What she
offers is a quiet, simmering competitiveness that breeds confidence among her
captains and teammates.

''She is a grinder and a fighter,'' said Annika Sorenstam, the retired Swedish
star who is assisting the European side this weekend. ''She loves the team
atmosphere and she gets all fired up.''

Liselotte Neumann, captain of the 2013 European team, had complete confidence in
Hedwall and sent her out to play in every match.

''It's really hard to win all your matches, but she played great with Anna and
Caroline,'' Neumann said, referring to Anna Norqvist and Caroline Masson. ''She
brought out the best in them and they also brought the best out of her.''

While Hedwall had to adjust quickly to hitting her 7-iron 170 yards at altitude,
at the Colorado Golf Club near Denver, the fact that she figured it out and
trusted her putting produced confidence that trickled down to the rest of the
team.

''To win all five matches in Colorado inspired us all,'' Sorenstam said.

Hedwall's competitiveness is legendary, dating back to her days on the Swedish
national team, as well as at Oklahoma State University, where she played college
golf.

''She is a competitive person who comes alive in the team format,'' said the
L.P.G.A. player Pernilla Lindberg, who was Hedwall's teammate on the Swedish
team and at Oklahoma State. ''She is a great athlete who played lots of sports
growing up, so I think the team format brings out the athlete in her.''

Annie Thurman Young, her coach in Oklahoma, said Hedwall was ''the best player I
have ever coached.''

Hedwall played two years of college golf and won her first college tournament as
a freshman. She posted 15 top-10 finishes, won six college tournaments,
including the 2010 individual N.C.A.A. Division I Championship, and was college
golf's 2010 Player of the Year.

''She's very, very competitive,'' said Young, who is now the head women's golf
coach at Colorado State University. ''We played ping pong and random games when
she was in college and she always wanted to win. You know she's going to be a
good player when she's that competitive off the course.''

Hedwall is also physically strong, which translates into distance on the golf
course, and that advantage is enhanced by her deft putting touch, Young said.

''She's very powerful and has the skills to pull off a number of shots,'' she
said. ''When she hits the ball, it just has a different sound compared to most
other women golfers.''

Young and Lindberg agree that match play suits Hedwall's playing style, making
her an exceptional team player.

''It's the competitive side of her that really comes out in match play,''
Lindberg said. ''She is aggressive and fearless.''

When asked after Europe's triumph in 2013 to explain her 5-0 performance,
Hedwall replied: ''I'm just shaking. It's unbelievable.'' Later in the same
interview she admitted, ''I'm a really bad loser, so I just need to keep on
winning.''

Even after her team's disappointing loss at home, the 2013 United States Solheim
Cup Captain Meg Mallon praised Hedwall. ''She really played some spectacular
golf,'' Mallon said. ''What you're seeing is the future of the Solheim Cup,''
she said, adding: ''You're going to see a lot of these young players going at it
for a long time.''

It hasn't been the best of years for Hedwall, who has wrestled with health and
injury issues. But those who know her say they believe the Solheim Cup will stir
her fire once again.

''I wouldn't be surprised if she came out and played just as well as she did at
the last Solheim Cup,'' Young said. ''She's a good player and this competition
brings out the best in her.''




URL:
http://www.nytimes.com/2015/09/18/sports/golf/caroline-hedwall-a-star-who-thrive
s-under-pressure-golf-solheim-cup.html

NORWAY (73%); CENTRAL EUROPE (58%)

                        The International New York Times

All Blacks Ready to Start Anew at Rugby World Cup

BYLINE: By EMMA STONEY

SECTION: Section ; Column 0; Sports Desk; Pg.

LENGTH: 1186 words


WELLINGTON, New Zealand -- A veteran team that has set the standard of play for
years with its free-flowing attack enters a World Cup to defend the title it won
four years before when it ended decades of frustration.

Sound familiar? For New Zealand, there are plenty of parallels between its 2015
Rugby World Cup campaign and what the Spanish soccer team faced in 2014 at the
World Cup in Brazil.

A golden generation of players led Spain to its first major title since 1964
when it won the European Championship in 2008. Two years later, it ended decades
of Spanish misery at the World Cup when it won the tournament for the first
time, in South Africa.

The Spanish soccer team, like New Zealand's rugby team, for years set the
standards in its sport, with its world-class collection of players and tiki-taka
style of quick-pass, offensive soccer.

It successfully defended its title at the 2012 Euro. But Spain's quest for
back-to-back world titles ended in Brazil in embarrassing fashion when it failed
to get beyond the group stages followinglosses to the Netherlands and Chile.

In 2011, New Zealand won the Rugby World Cup for the first time in 24 years.
Since then, it has won 42 of 47 tests, against three losses and two ties.

The All Blacks have been the No.1 team for so long it is hard to remember when
they were not atop the World Rugby standings.

But no rugby team has ever defended a World Cup title successfully, and the All
Blacks have never won a final played outside of New Zealand.

But while New Zealand could suffer the same fate as Spain, it feels much less
likely, as the All Blacks re-enter rugby's biggest stage. The team may have lost
its Rugby Championship title to Australia and played below its usual standards,
but the tournament was shorter than normal this year because of the World Cup.
In addition, New Zealand Coach Steve Hansen tinkered with his teams throughout
the tournament to allow his players to show they deserved a spot on the World
Cup roster.

Hansen is fully aware of the task in front of his team.

''We've been the No.1 side in the world for a long time, and you just can't keep
plodding along, doing what you always do,'' Hansen said. ''You need something
else to get you motivated, and this certainly has got them motivated.''

Hansen has been skilled at introducing new players into the team during the past
four years. Being able to count on a core of talented veterans -- like captain
Richie McCaw, Dan Carter, Ma'a Nonu, Conrad Smith, Tony Woodcock, Keven Mealamu
and Kieran Read -- makes that transition easier.

New Zealand seems to have struck the right balance of youthful exuberance and
veteran experience, something every World Cup team needs.

Of the 31 players heading to the World Cup, 17 will be playing in their first
World Cup, yet the team has a combined 1,484 games of test experience.

Many of those 17 players are first-choice selections at their positions, and
except for Nehe Milner-Skudder, Waisake Naholo and Codie Taylor, all have at
least a year of international rugby under their belts.

But being the best in the world and having the most experienced group of players
does not guarantee success, as the All Blacks know too well.

After winning the inaugural World Cup in 1987, New Zealand suffered more than
two decades of disappointment. The nadir came in 2007, when it was knocked out
in the quarterfinals by France -- the team's earliest-ever exit -- at the
Millennium Stadium in Cardiff, Wales.

Six of the New Zealanders at this year's World Cup played in that tournament,
while many more of the players remember watching it on television.

In a twist of irony, this tournament, like the 2007 one, also sees New Zealand
in probably the weakest of the four pools, and it could meet France in the
quarterfinals in Cardiff.

Hansen said the team would not even talk about the knockout round, or potential
opponents, until it was done with the group stage.

''Everyone remembers 2007, whether you were there watching, or back home
watching,'' Hansen said. ''No one's forgotten it, and it's a great reminder to
all of us that if you don't step up, you go home.''

This World Cup has been touted as probably the most open in the cup's 28-year
history. England, Ireland, Australia, South Africa, Wales and New Zealand are
all title contenders, although New Zealand, by virtue of its performances during
the past four years, and England, with home-field advantage, are seen as the
favorites.

McCaw believes it will be the hardest-ever tournament to win. ''If we go there
thinking it won't be, we're kidding ourselves,'' he said.

While McCaw says the lessons learned in 2007 and 2011 will help, there has been
no talk of defending the 2011 crown -- instead, the team believes, it is a
trophy they must go out and win again.

''You've got 20 teams all on the start line that all believe they can do the
job, and we're just one of them,'' McCaw said. ''This crew is different to the
one in 2011, and the team that gets the job done is the one that gets it right
in the next six weeks, regardless of what happened last week, last year or four
years ago.''

The leadership and presence -- or mana as New Zealanders call it -- that McCaw
exuded in 2011 cannot be underestimated. He played the tournament with a broken
foot and kept the team focused and confident despite the loss of Carter -- and
then Carter's replacements Colin Slade and Aaron Cruden -- to injury.

McCaw will be just as influential this time around, both on and off the field.

''He sets the standards, which is really important I think,'' said the former
New Zealand lock Ian Jones, who played in three World Cups in the 1990s.
''Imagine yourself sitting there about to go and play a test match and Richie
McCaw is sitting next to you. It must give you tremendous confidence to go and
play with a guy who has played 140-odd test matches and been a great leader and
a guy who demands excellence.''

As for the other challengers, Australia, England and Wales have the toughest
road after being grouped together in Pool A along with Fiji and Uruguay, and
only two teams advance from each group.

For France and Ireland, there will be a huge advantage for finishing first in
Pool D -- the winner will avoid a quarterfinal matchup with the first-place Pool
C team, likely to be New Zealand.

It is a similar scenario for England, Wales and Australia in Pool A. Whoever
finishes atop their group is likely to play Samoa or Scotland from Pool B, while
the runner-up will have a likely quarterfinal against South Africa.

But the former Australia captain George Gregan believes the competitive nature
of the Wallabies' group could be an advantage.

''People always call it the Pool of Death, but I think it's also the pool of
strength, because you gain a lot of strength from playing hard games,'' he
explained. ''You then go into the playoffs stage knowing that you're
match-hardened and you've had to deal with pressure situations.

''Ultimately you've got to beat the best teams in the world to become a world
champion, so why not have a couple in your own pool?''




URL:
http://www.nytimes.com/2015/09/18/sports/rugby/all-blacks-ready-to-start-anew-at
-rugby-world-cup.html

                        The International New York Times

Rugby World Cup Preview: All Blacks Still the Favorites

BYLINE: By EMMA STONEY

SECTION: Section ; Column 0; Sports Desk; Pg.

LENGTH: 2075 words


The eighth edition of the Rugby World Cup will kick off Friday when the host,
England, takes on Fiji at Twickenham in London.

In all, 20 teams will be competing for the right to hoist the Webb Ellis Cup
after the final on Oct. 31.

The tournament is a grind at six weeks long, with 48 matches to be played in 12
English cities and in Cardiff, Wales. The Millennium Stadium, considered the
home of Welsh rugby, will get more than its fair share of action, with eight
matches, including two quarterfinals.

The early part of the tournament is split into four pools of five teams each,
with the top two teams from each group advancing to the knockout stage.

New Zealand, which won the title in 2011 on home soil, is ranked No.1 in the
world and is favored to repeat. The All Blacks won the inaugural World Cup final
in Auckland in 1987, when it co- hosted the event with Australia, but it has
never won the title while playing abroad. No team has ever won tournaments back
to back.

England, the 2003 champion, will need all the home field advantage it can get,
as it must advance through what most consider the Pool of Death, with Australia,
Wales, Fiji and Uruguay.

Other strong contenders for the title are Australia (winner in 1991 and 1999),
South Africa (2007 winner) and Ireland.


Pool A


Australia

Rugby World Cup record 1987, fourth; 1991, winner; 1995, quarterfinals; 1999,
winner; 2003, runner-up; 2007, quarterfinals; 2011, third.

Key statistic: 24  The last time Australia defeated England at a World Cup was
24 years ago, in the 1991 final. It has lost three times since then, in 1995,
2003 and 2007.

After an awful 2014, Australia seems to be getting back on track. Coach Michael
Cheika has the team playing more physically, but the scrum remains its Achilles'
heel. If the forwards get their job done, then Israel Folau and Kurtley Beale
could provide the game-winning difference.


England

World Cup record 1987, quarterfinals; 1991, runner-up; 1995, fourth; 1999,
quarterfinals; 2003, winner; 2007, runner-up; 2011, quarterfinals.

Key statistic: 20 The number of drop goals by England, the most in World Cup
history and seven more than the next closest team, South Africa.

England will have to cope with the pressure of being the host nation in a
cutthroat pool in which one of the world's top-ranked teams will not reach the
quarterfinals. England has developed into a more well-rounded team under Coach
Stuart Lancaster, but it has little margin for error if it wants to lift the
trophy.


Wales

World Cup record 1987, third; 1991, pool stage; 1995, pool stage; 1999,
quarterfinals; 2003, quarterfinals. 2007, pool stage; 2011, fourth.

Key statistic: 19 years, 166 days The age George North was when he scored two
tries against Namibia in 2011, making him the youngest player to score a try in
a World Cup.

Matches on Sept. 26 against England and Oct. 10 against Australia will determine
Wales's fate. After finishing fourth in 2011, not reaching the knockout stages
this time around would be a bitter blow for Coach Warren Gatland and his team.


Fiji

World Cup record 1987, quarterfinals; 1991, pool stage; 1999, quarterfinal
playoff; 2003, pool stage; 2007, quarterfinals; 2011, pool stage.

Key statistic: 108 The number of points Fiji scored against the Cook Islands in
its qualifying match for this World Cup. The Cook Islands scored 6.

Fiji showed with its scintillating performances in the Pacific Nations Cup that
it should not be underestimated in the Pool of Death.

It is likely to push its higher-ranked rivals hard, and with its flamboyant
attacking style, Fiji will undoubtedly be one of the most entertaining teams to
watch.


Uruguay

World Cup record 1999 and 2003, pool stage.

Key statistic: 98 The total number of points scored by Uruguay in seven World
Cup games.

Uruguay is back in the tournament for the first time in 12 years, but it will be
without its best player following Rodrigo Capó Ortega's sudden decision to
retire. The 31-man team has only four full-time professional players, so it is
unlikely that Los Teros will cause too many problems for the other teams in the
group.


Pool B


South Africa

World Cup record 1995, winner; 1999, third; 2003, quarterfinals; 2007, winner;
2011, quarterfinals.

Key statistic: 86.2% South Africa's winning percentage at the World Cup. They
have won 25 of 29 matches.

South Africa's buildup has been disrupted by injuries, which contributed to
losses in the Rugby Championship to Australia, New Zealand and Argentina. Always
a threat in the set-piece and at the breakdown, the Springboks now have, in
Handré Pollard, a flyhalf who can unleash the young duo of Damian de Allende and
Jesse Kriel, as well as the veteran winger Bryan Habana.


Samoa

World Cup record 1991, quarterfinals; 1995, quarterfinals; 1999, quarterfinal
playoff; 2003, 2007 and 2011, pool stage.

Key statistic: 3 The number of players on the team who play in Samoa. The
majority are employed by clubs in England and France.

Samoa looks to have put its off-field issues behind it and has a real shot at
making the quarterfinals. It plays hard, physical rugby, yet also has power and
speed in the backs. Samoa's match against Scotland on Oct. 10 will most likely
decide who progresses to the knockout stages.


Japan

World Cup record 1987, 1991, 1995, 1999, 2003, 2007 and 2011: pool stages.

Key statistic: 1 The only win Japan has managed in seven World Cups was a 52-8
victory against Zimbabwe in a pool-stage match in 1991.

Japan has had a mixed run-up to the tournament, winning the Asian Five Nations
tournament but finishing fourth in the Pacific Nations Cup. The Brave Blossoms
are quick and agile and love to attack carrying the ball, but the test for them
will be matching the bigger teams in the forward exchanges.


Scotland

World Cup record 1987, quarterfinals; 1991, fourth; 1995, quarterfinals; 1999,
quarterfinals; 2003, quarterfinals; 2007, quarterfinals; 2011, pool stage.

Key statistic: 15  The number of wins Scotland has had in 43 test matches since
the last World Cup.

Scotland has moved away from the dour rugby of previous regimes since the New
Zealander Vern Cotter took over as coach in June 2014. But while there have been
positive signs, wins have been hard to come by. The Scots lost every game in the
Six Nations tournament this year.


United States

World Cup record 1987, 1991, 1999, 2003, 2007, 2011, pool stage.

Key statistic: 38 The total number of points the United States scored in four
pool matches at the 2011 World Cup, the lowest among the 20 teams.

The USA Eagles are without their best-known player, the former captain Todd
Clever. Clever, who posed for ESPN The Magazine in its ''Body'' issue this year,
was axed on the eve of the Pacific Nations Cup, and his rugged play and
leadership skills will be missed. It will be a major surprise if the Eagles make
it beyond the pool stages, with their best chance coming against Japan.


POOL C


New Zealand

World Cup record 1987, winner; 1991, third; 1995, runner-up; 1999, fourth; 2003,
third; 2007, quarterfinals; 2011, winner.

Key statistic: 272  The total number of World Cup tries that New Zealand has
scored, the most by any country and 91 more than No.2 Australia (181).

New Zealand has a good chance to become the first country to win back-to-back
World Cups. It has retained its position at the top of the world rankings since
it won it all in 2011 and has lost just three times in 47 tests since the start
of 2012.


Argentina

World Cup record 1987, pool stage; 1991, pool stage; 1995, pool stage; 1999,
quarterfinals; 2003, pool stage; 2007, third; 2011, quarterfinals.

Key statistic: 64  With 64 test appearances, Juan Martín Fernández Lobbe will be
the most experienced Argentina player at the World Cup.

Always noted for its scrum and bruising forward play, Argentina is starting to
develop a more attacking brand of rugby under Coach Daniel Hourcade. A diet of
regular, tough test matches, thanks to its inclusion in the Rugby Championship,
has also helped the Pumas' development, and the quarterfinals should be a
realistic goal.


Tonga

World Cup record 1987, 1995, 1999, 2003, 2007, 2011, pool stage.

Key statistic: 3  The total number of World Cup red cards Tonga has had, the
same as Canada.

Tongan fans provided one of the most memorable experiences at the last World Cup
when they mobbed their team's arrival at the Auckland airport and brought the
city to a virtual standstill on opening night. Opposition teams tend to remember
the Tongans for their ferocious tackling, and it won't be any different this
time.


Georgia

Rugby World Cup record 2003, 2007 and 2011: pool stage.

Key statistic: 7,133  The number of registered rugby players in Georgia. Of the
20 World Cup teams, only Uruguay (6,069) has a lower number.

Georgia won the European Nations Cup, the second-tier continental tournament, in
March for a fifth consecutive time. The Lelos, famed for their powerful scrum
and forward play, are currently ranked 16th in the world, just two spots below
Italy, a Six Nations team. The majority of Georgia's players play their club
rugby in France, and back rower Mamuka Gorgodze will be one to watch.


Namibia

World Cup record 1999, 2003, 2007 and 2011: pool stage.

Key statistic: 15 The number of World Cup matches Namibia has played without a
win, the most in the competition's history.

Namibia will struggle to end that losing streak this year. In 2003, it lost to
Australia by a record score of 142-0. If New Zealand hits top gear on Sept. 24,
that record might be beaten.


POOL D


France

World Cup record 1987, runner-up; 1991, quarterfinals; 1995, third; 1999,
runner-up; 2003, fourth; 2007, fourth; 2011, runner-up.

Key statistic: 17  The number of 9/10 combinations that Coach Philippe
Saint-André has used in 40 tests since the last World Cup.

The French were the basket case of the 2011 tournament, when a virtual mutiny
against its coach at the time, Marc Lièvremont, threatened to derail its whole
campaign, yet Les Bleus still reached the final against New Zealand. France has
been underwhelming under its new coach, Saint-André, but it is a World Cup, so
France could spring a surprise, no matter how unlikely that seems.


Ireland

World Cup record 1987, quarterfinals; 1991, quarterfinals; 1995, quarterfinals;
1999, quarterfinal playoff; 2003, quarterfinals; 2007, pool stage; 2011,
quarterfinals.

Key statistic: 0 The number of times that the back-to-back Six Nations champion
has made the World Cup semifinals.

Ireland has been the best team in Europe for the past couple of years, and it
probably has its best chance ever to reach the semifinals. Flyhalf Jonathan
Sexton holds the key to any success, so Irish fans will be praying he stays
healthy in what will be a bruising six weeks.


Italy

World Cup record 1987, 1991, 1995, 1999, 2003, 2007, 2011, pool stage.

Key statistic: 113  The number of tests Sergio Parisse has played for Italy, the
most by any Azzurri player.

Italy has slumped to 14th in the world rankings and had its preparations
disrupted by a players' strike and the loss of the first-choice No.10 Kelly
Haimona to a broken arm. In 15 years of Six Nations rugby, Italy has managed to
beat France twice and Ireland only once, so its chances of making the
quarterfinals are remote.


Canada

World Cup record 1987, pool stage; 1991, quarterfinals; 1995, 1999, 2003, 2007
and 2011: pool stage.

Key statistic: 7  Canada is one of seven World Cup teams that has a New
Zealander as the head coach. The others are New Zealand, Wales, Ireland,
Scotland, Fiji and Georgia.

Canada beat Tonga and tied with Japan at the last World Cup, but it will
struggle to match that success at this year's tournament. It needs to learn how
to win in tight matches after losing recently to late scores against Samoa and
the United States in the Pacific Nations Cup.


Romania

World Cup record 1987, 1991, 1995, 1999, 2003, 2007 and 2011: Pool stage.

Key statistic: 3  Romania tied Georgia for scoring the fewest tries, 3, during
the pool stages of the 2011 World Cup.

Romania did not win a match at the 2011 tournament, the first time since the
1995 World Cup it failed to do so. The Oaks, one of the stronger
forward-oriented teams in second-tier rugby, will hope the inclusion of New
Zealand-born flyhalf Michael Wiringi and Tongan center Paula Kinikinilau will
add some spark in the backs.

5 Players to Watch at the Rugby World Cup

BYLINE: By EMMA STONEY

SECTION: Section ; Column 0; Sports Desk; Pg.

LENGTH: 957 words


Wellington, New Zealand -- Five players to watch at the Rugby World Cup, which
starts Friday in London.

Israel Folau (Australia, fullback)

Folau burst onto the international scene during the British & Irish Lions tour
of Australia in 2013 and has been wowing rugby crowds ever since. The
26-year-old scored 10 tries in 2013, but one of the most memorable images of him
was when Lions winger George North hoisted Folau onto his back and carried the
Australian during the second Lions test. Folau, courtesy of a stint in
Australian Rules football, is the best fullback in the world under the high
ball, but the former rugby league star is also dangerous on the counterattack
where his size, silky running skills and offloading make him as good at creating
tries as he is at finishing them. Folau was a bright light in a difficult 2014
for the Wallabies, and he has been a steady influence at the back during this
year's Rugby Championship as Wallabies Coach Michael Cheika has tried different
players in the playmaking No.10 role in the buildup to the World Cup.

Julian Savea (New Zealand, wing)

Nicknamed ''The Bus'' because of his ability to run over or bounce defenders out
of the way, Savea has been compared with the All Blacks legend Jonah Lomu -- and
the 25-year-old Savea certainly lives up to the hype. He has an impressive
strike rate on the left wing, scoring 30 tries in 35 tests since his debut in
2012. The former All Blacks winger Sitiveni Sivivatu took 48 tests to reach the
same figure, while Lomu ended his international career with 37 tries in 63
tests. Savea's speed, power and vision make him difficult to stop from virtually
anywhere on the field, and his fancy footwork can occasionally be seen before
the match, as the winger has been known to show off a few dance moves during
pregame preparations. He showed up to All Blacks camp overweight, which resulted
in his being put through some grueling training sessions, and he has seen
limited playing time in New Zealand's buildup to its title defense. Still,
expect him to have a big impact in what will be his first World Cup.

Eben Etzebeth (South Africa, lock)

At 6-foot-9 and 257 pounds, it's no wonder that Etzebeth has slipped easily into
the role of enforcer in the Springboks pack. He is regularly compared with
Bakkies Botha, but the 23-year-old Etzebeth, who made his international debut in
2012, has a far better disciplinary record than his predecessor, along with a
better all-round game. While he won't step back from a confrontation, Etzebeth
very rarely crosses the line, preferring instead to use his strength, aggression
and incredible agility for the benefit of the team. He is the perfect foil to
his locking partner Victor Matfield. Etzebeth excels in the lineout and does not
shirk from the hard work in scrums or on defense. He also is hard to stop when
he carries the ball -- as Springboks teammate Bismarck du Plessis learned a
couple of years ago in Super Rugby when he was flung aside like a rag doll by
the charging Etzebeth.

Jonathan Sexton (Ireland, flyhalf)

Sexton has been one of the best flyhalves in the world for the past couple of
years and will be determined to leave his mark on this World Cup after a mixed
tournament in New Zealand in 2011. He played a central role in the British &
Irish Lions' series victory against Australia in 2013 and during Ireland's
back-to-back Six Nations triumphs in 2014 and 2015. Ireland will need him to
stay fit if it wants to add the Webb Ellis Cup to its trophy cabinet. When he's
running the show at No.10, Ireland, whose game plan under Coach Joe Schmidt is
based on structure and accuracy rather than flamboyance, is a much tougher team
to beat. Whether he is running at defenses, raking kicks to the corners or
firing up high balls for his back line to chase, he has a knack of getting his
team to the right areas of the field so his team can attack. His goal-kicking
also will be invaluable. The 30-year-old, who has played 52 tests for his
country, sat out for 12 weeks before this year's Six Nations after suffering a
series of concussions. He returned in a match against France, where the giant
wrecking-ball Mathieu Bastareaud repeatedly sized him up. But despite being left
battered and bloody, Sexton showed his mettle in those exchanges and kicked
Ireland to victory.

Sam Burgess (England, center)

Burgess's inclusion is probably the most debated selection from any of the 20
teams competing in the tournament. Burgess has been picked as a center by Coach
Stuart Lancaster, yet he plays flanker for his club Bath, which moved him there
after only six starts at center. While the 26-year-old excelled in Australia's
National Rugby League, he has not been able to repeat his success since making
the switch to rugby union late last year. Burgess has played two tests for
England. In his first, against France last month, he made two monster tackles
but also spent 10 minutes in the sin bin. In his second outing against Ireland,
he played 20 minutes but made little impact. The former England captain Will
Carling has said Burgess does not yet understand the nuances of playing at
center and that rushing him into a World Cup squad is a huge gamble. But, after
Lancaster made the decision not to consider Manu Tuilagi for the World Cup after
Tuilagi pleaded guilty to three charges of assault and one of criminal damage,
the coach felt he needed the physical presence of the 6-foot-3, 255-pound
Burgess in the back line. ''To win at this level you need physicality,
ball-players and finishers,'' Lancaster said when he announced his team. ''Sam
certainly brings the physicality and is as quick as any of our centers. He is
powerful and understands and reads defenses very well.''




URL:
http://www.nytimes.com/2015/09/18/sports/rugby/5-players-to-watch-at-the-rugby-w
orld-cup.html

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                        The International New York Times

In Sydney, a Family Mansion of Many Makeovers

BYLINE: By MICHAEL MAPSTONE

SECTION: Section ; Column 0; Business/Financial Desk; Pg.

LENGTH: 712 words


SYDNEY, Australia -- An estate home built in 1871 for one of Sydney's best-known
retail merchant families is for sale after a fastidious restoration.

Jenner House, which was known as Stramshall when it was designed by a highly
regarded colonial architect, Edmund Blacket, is in Potts Point -- about two
miles east of the Sydney commercial business district.

Despite its location in Australia's second most populous suburb, the home sits
on 1,970 square meters, or 21,200 square feet, of land. The house, with
triple-layered brick walls, has more than 600 square meters of interior floor
space over three levels, and each level features ceilings four meters, or 13
feet, high.

Offers in excess of 20 million Australian dollars, or $14.3 million, are being
sought.

Blacket built Stramshall, a Georgian Regency house, for the Hordern family,
well-regarded merchants. The home's third level was added by another top
architect of the era, Thomas Rowe, in about 1881.

According to Robert Page, a sales agent from Black Diamondz Property Concierge,
the home was occupied by the future King George V of Britain during his time in
the Royal Navy (he visited Australia while serving from 1877 to 1891, before
ascending to the British throne in 1910).

The building has had various uses since.

When Stramshall was first built, its landholding would have stretched to the
waterfront of Elizabeth Bay. Views of the bay and Sydney Harbour, stretching
north toward Clark Island and Sydney Heads, remain.

The Australian government purchased the land in 1940.

The building operated as the Jenner Private Hospital from 1914 until the early
1950s. The Australian Navy, which has an operations base at neighboring Garden
Island, then used the premises until the late 1990s.

The property then passed back into private ownership. The current owners, Wendy
and Terry Mullens, purchased Jenner House, unrenovated, in 2009.

''The navy had put in a lot of dividers and commercial toilets that had to be
removed,'' Mrs. Mullens said. ''But the house that was here was sound.''

The thorough restoration has allowed for luxurious modern touches.

Entry is from ground level. Large numbers of tall windows light the rooms.
Original flooring and ornate cornice work around the light fittings in a
ground-floor sitting room are repeated in other rooms. The same room has one of
the 10 marble fireplaces -- all original French pieces -- scattered throughout
the home.

Also on the ground level is a full commercial kitchen, with handcrafted marble
benchtops and customized stainless steel refrigerators (the generators are in
the cellar, so there is no noise).

Even the kitchen has harbor views, but they are perhaps better enjoyed from the
adjoining large living room, which also leads to a large veranda.

The ground level also has a guests' powder room -- like all the marble areas in
the home, it has under-floor heating -- a cloakroom and a storage room. There is
also a gym and maid's quarters, opening to a deck.

The staircase to the second floor features original parquetry and leads to a
large, light-filled dining room with a Juliet balcony overlooking the gardens
and Elizabeth Bay. There is a kitchenette off the dining room.

There are five bedrooms in the house, including two master suites. Each of the
bedrooms features an en suite bathroom. The master suites have his-and-hers
showers, slipper claw-leg baths and slab marble floors.

Two of the bedrooms, including a master suite, are on the second level. Both
adjoin a large refurbished deck, its railings sandcast in the original pattern.
The laundry room is on this level and features marble benchtops and a big
storage cupboard.

On the upper level is a master suite and two more bedrooms. Another room is
currently an office. The home also has space for six cars, a storage shed that
was built as the hospital gatekeeper's quarters and a lawn area.

''We have enjoyed living in a beautiful home of this heritage significance,''
Mrs. Mullens said, ''and the landholding that it is, in one of the most densely
populated suburbs in Australia,'' makes it special.

The couple intend to buy a similar property in France. ''We've always loved big
old houses, and it is rare to find one like this in Sydney,'' Mrs. Mullens said.

http://www.nytimes.com/2015/09/18/greathomesanddestinations/in-sydney-a-family-m
ansion-of-many-makeovers.html

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                        The International New York Times

A Fortified Farmhouse Built With New World Wealth

BYLINE: By ANDREW ALLEN

SECTION: Section ; Column 0; Business/Financial Desk; Pg.

LENGTH: 1033 words


SANT PERE DE RIBES, Spain -- It stands five miles inland from the Costa del
Garraf in Catalonia, but Can Martí, an 1870 Spanish colonial-style farmhouse, is
so imposing that its owners say for many years local fishermen used it as a
navigation point.

With its ochre stucco facade and defensive turrets, the property, in the
municipality of Sant Pere de Ribes, a 30-minute drive from the Barcelona-El Prat
Airport, stands out firmly against the surrounding olive groves and cereal
fields.

The scent of wallflowers and hyacinths from outside drifts through the interior
of the house, which is owned by José Luis Hernández and María Dolores Alba. The
couple, owners of a game and hunting business, have put the property on the
market with Engel & Völkers Sitges for 6.8 million euros, or $7.7 million.

Mrs. Alba said that the colonial background of the house's original owner, Pau
Soler, a man who earned vast wealth from the sugar trade in Cuba in the mid-19th
century, explains many of the property's curiosities.

Like many young men in this area, Soler, later a railway magnate and farmer,
sought his fortune in the Caribbean, as there were few opportunities locally.

Those who returned as rich men from the Antilles during the period were known in
Spain as Indianos, or Indians, and the houses they built, funded with New World
wealth and influenced by Cuban architecture, are still referred to as casas
Indianas.

One of Spain's most famous Indianos hailed from Sitges, three miles away:
Facundo Bacardí, founder of the rum distillery that bears the family name.

Soler returned to Catalonia in his 40s. His determination to protect his fortune
against the bandits who infested the area in the late 1800s explains the turrets
that jut from each corner of the house. These are thick-walled defenses, rather
than decorative fortifications, with gun slits affording commanding views of the
walls.

All of the property's windows are protected with iron bars, particularly the
covered porch near the main entrance, with its Havana-inspired iron grilles.

Fear of bandits also finally explained a feature of the house that once puzzled
Mrs. Alba. Whereas most of the staircase is made of the traditional stone, one
section of the first-story staircase is made of iron and is reinforced in
certain parts.

The mystery was solved when an elderly woman who had worked at the house visited
Mrs. Alba.

''She explained that part of the lower portion of the staircase was originally
designed to be lifted on iron rods to isolate the second floor from attackers.
When she was young she had actually seen it working,'' Mrs. Alba said. Most of
the mechanism to lift the staircase is no longer in place.

The main living room has sliding wooden doors measuring five meters by three
meters, or 16.5 feet by 10 feet; when opened, these offer views across Sitges
and the Mediterranean.

On the other side of the first story of the house is an enclosed gallery, with
views over the Garraf mountain range. To such a room, men in Indiana houses
traditionally retired to smoke cigars and drink the rum for which they had
acquired a taste in Cuba.

Mrs. Alba's father bought the house in the 1980s, and she recalled its being in
poor condition.

''The previous residents occupied only a small part of the house, which they had
turned into a kind of apartment. They abandoned the rest,'' she said. ''Trash
was piled up in some of the rooms.''

The seven main bedrooms on the second floor are set around a central staircase,
and each has an alcove, an en suite bathroom and a dressing room. Wooden frames
that divided the bedrooms had been ripped out.

But as the previous owners had occupied only a small part of the house, which
has 14 bedrooms and a floor area of 2,500 square meters, or almost 27,000 square
feet, much of the property had been left intact.

Mrs. Alba's father, a farmer and horse breeder, restored the original local
stone floors, which had been stripped in some rooms, along with its surrounding
estate of 75 hectares, or 185 acres, and stables for 27 horses.

These days, 7,000 olive trees produce oil of the arbequina variety. A tree in
the kitchen garden provides a different variety of olive, sevillana, for eating.
''We can only water the olive trees by day, because if we water them by night
wild boar are attracted by the water and break open the tubes to drink,'' Mr.
Hernández said.

Josep Maria Fortià, a historical architect based in the city of Girona who is an
expert on casas Indianas, said that this house used an eclectic mix of
architecture mixed with Cuban elements. These include the elaborate ironwork
around the bell and palm and jacaranda trees in the garden.

''The first floor, that space of transition between sun and shade, with its
four-pointed interior arches and Havana ironwork, is also very typical of
Indiana houses,'' he said.

Mr. Fortià said the turrets were of a Cuban military design.

On the first floor of the house are three more bedrooms, a study with English
furniture and an area that is used as a private museum of horse-drawn carriages
collected by Mrs. Alba's father.

Much of the house's original furniture survives, including a luxurious carved
wooden commode with an adjoining bench in one of the bathrooms. The third floor
has four more bedrooms and has exposed ceiling beams made of Scots pine.

Damià Peña, director of Engel & Völkers Sitges, said that although the area was
associated with Indianos, there were few surviving Indiana houses to be found
there.

''It will probably appeal to a horse lover, as it's set up as a stables,'' said
Mr. Peña, who also believes the house's proximity to Sitges, a lively and
artistic town, is likely to be a draw. Whereas Can Martí's price per square
meter is about ?2,200 (the overall asking price also takes into account the
sizable estate), typical frontline properties in Sitges cost from ?7,000 to
?8,000 per square meter, he said.

When Soler embarked for Cuba it was precisely the poverty of Sitges and this
part of the coast that led him to emigrate. This year, however, Sitges was again
ranked by fotocasa.es, one of Spain's leading property portals, as the third
most expensive Spanish municipality.




URL:
http://www.nytimes.com/2015/09/18/greathomesanddestinations/a-fortified-farmhous
e-built-with-new-world-wealth.html

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

SUBJECT: WEALTHY PEOPLE (88%); SUGAR MARKETS (69%); DISTILLERIES (50%)

CITY: BARCELONA, SPAIN (92%); HAVANA, CUBA (77%)

STATE: CATALONIA, SPAIN (91%)

COUNTRY: SPAIN (91%); CUBA (77%); CARIBBEAN ISLANDS (70%)
