                              Late Edition - Final

Timex Museum Prepares to Shut Its Doors

BYLINE: By EVE M. KAHN

SECTION: Section C; Column 0; The Arts/Cultural Desk; Pg. 24

LENGTH: 506 words


Adieu to a Timex Trove

The imminent closing of Timexpo: The Timex Group Museum in Waterbury, Conn., has
inspired its share of puns about doomsdays and time running out. The museum,
devoted to the history of Timex and its clocks and watches, will close on Sept.
30, just 14 years after it was founded.

The number of visitors to Timexpo has decreased over the years, and the company
now plans to disperse its antiques, some of which date from the 1850s, when
workers in Waterbury helped popularize mass-produced timepieces.

The museum's director, Cathy Conti, lamented its short life span during a recent
tour.

''Doesn't it have great energy?'' she said as she walked through the building, a
turreted brick structure from the 1850s that originally housed a brass mill. The
museum sits between a highway and a strip mall, and a foam-and-steel copy of an
Easter Island statue sits rather incongruously on the front lawn. Around the
corner is Holy Land of Waterbury USA, a sculpture park from the 1950s with
crumbling facsimiles of ancient buildings in Jerusalem and Bethlehem.

Wall texts explain how Timex, originally incorporated as the Waterbury Clock
Company in the 1850s, adapted to changing tastes over the decades by ornamenting
clocks and watches with images of dragons, elephants and Mickey Mouse and coming
up with catchy product names like Radiolite, Armalloy and Sweepster.

The company is deciding how the collection will be broken up, with objects
transferred to its own corporate headquarters in nearby Middlebury, Waterbury
City Hall, the local Mattatuck Museum, the Smithsonian Institution in Washington
and the National Watch & Clock Museum in Columbia, Pa., Ms. Conti said. The
Easter Island statue's fate has yet to be determined.

The Mattatuck Museum plans to devote a corner gallery to Timexpo antiques,
exhibiting them alongside locally manufactured innovations, like lamp hardware,
munition parts and a warbling whistle called the Canary Songster. Robert Burns,
the museum's director, said that these Timexpo objects offer ''a nice succinct
telling of that really important Waterbury story.''

Noel Poirier, the director of the National Watch & Clock Museum, described the
loss of Timexpo's documentation of Connecticut clockmakers as ''heartbreaking in
a lot of ways.'' The museum is now restoring a 19th-century street clock made by
the Ansonia Clock Company, which was founded in Ansonia, Conn., and went out of
business in 1929.

Mr. Poirier says that there is still an abiding interest in historical devices
for measuring time. An exhibition about the French-Swiss watchmaker Breguet
opens on Saturday at the Legion of Honor museum in San Francisco. On Nov. 16,
European clocks and watches will go on display at the Metropolitan Museum of Art
in the exhibition ''The Luxury of Time.''

From Oct. 7 through 31, Galerie Delalande in Paris will exhibit 90 hourglasses
(many are for sale at prices starting at a few thousand dollars each), made as
far back as the 1400s, in materials including amber, ivory and gold.




URL:
http://www.nytimes.com/2015/09/18/arts/design/timex-museum-prepares-to-shut-its-
doors.html

GRAPHIC: PHOTOS: Two vintage clocks in the collection of the Timexpo museum in
Waterbury, Conn. The one with backward numerals was designed so that the time
could be read correctly in a barber-shop mirror. (PHOTOGRAPHS FROM TIMEXPO: THE
TIMEX GROUP MUSEUM)

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

SCULPTURE (78%); ANTIQUES & COLLECTIBLES (78%); FINE WATCHES (77%); HISTORIC
DISTRICTS & STRUCTURES (77%); BUSINESS CLOSINGS (50%)

CITY: JERUSALEM, ISRAEL (70%)

STATE: CONNECTICUT, USA (90%); PENNSYLVANIA, USA (79%); CALIFORNIA, USA (75%)

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (90%); ISRAEL (70%)

                               The New York Times

                           September 18, 2015 Friday
                              Late Edition - Final

A Trove of 'Letterlocking,' or Vintage Strategies to Deter Snoops

BYLINE: By EVE M. KAHN

SECTION: Section C; Column 0; The Arts/Cultural Desk; ANTIQUES; Pg. 24

LENGTH: 566 words


To Fend Off Snoops,Vintage 'Letterlocking'

Jana Dambrogio, the Thomas F. Peterson conservator at M.I.T. Libraries, is
analyzing how letter writers have tried through the ages to keep their
correspondence sealed and unread until it reached the intended recipients. She
has coined the word ''letterlocking'' to describe methods of folding and gluing
pages to deter snooping.

Ms. Dambrogio has been scouring archives for remnants of tabs, slits, pleats,
strings, wrappers and wax blobs that helped protect secrets. The locking
practice continued in different forms even after the 1830s, when the gummed
envelope, now ubiquitous, was introduced.

When Ms. Dambrogio tells other scholars about the varieties of letterlocking she
has unearthed, she said, the response is often along the lines of ''I'd never
thought about that before, but now I'll be looking around for it with fresh
eyes.''

With many collaborators, including Daniel Starza Smith at Oxford, she has
studied how figures like Queen Elizabeth I, Machiavelli, Galileo, Marie
Antoinette and the poet John Donne sought to safeguard their handwritten pages.
In her dictionary of historical letterlocking techniques, entries so far include
''triangle-shaped paper lock with slit perpendicular to the fore-edge'' and
''diamond-shaped paper lock cut from bottom of letter with slit parallel to the
fore-edge.''

Other subcategories keep surfacing. ''This is such a brand-new field of study,''
she said.

Examples of letterlocking turn up in paintings: Artists often depicted sealed
mail in the hands of royalty, politicians, poets, servants, soldiers, spies and
lovers. Novels, historical tomes, movies and plays also contain references to
locked letters with important and potentially embarrassing content.

Ms. Dambrogio is planning related exhibitions, and she is working on a book
about letterlocking. In a few weeks, she said, BBC History Magazine is scheduled
to publish an article that she jointly wrote about a rediscovered letter archive
in Europe that contains ''letterlocking like you've never seen it,'' she said.
She would not disclose more; she and her co-authors plan to reveal its secrets
bit by bit on Twitter via the hashtag #signedsealedundelivered.

She has handed out over 3,500 replicas of elaborately locked letters to people
interested in experimenting with them. Even though they know these are replicas,
she said, they sometimes still feel uncomfortable about breaking the seals. Ms.
Dambrogio said she is also researching antique sealing-wax formulas ''to be able
to mimic how they break.''

Colleagues who are scanning letters for online postings are advised by Ms.
Dambrogio to leave the fold and slit marks visible to show how the pages might
have appeared when first delivered.

Bringing attention to this niche topic ''is very evangelical'' for her, she
said.

Old correspondence with locking mechanisms can cost anywhere from a few dollars
to thousands each. Last year a bidder at Sotheby's in London paid about $38,000
for a note that Queen Elizabeth I wrote to Viscount Hereford in 1569, ordering
him to move her troublesome cousin Mary, Queen of Scots, whom he was guarding,
to Coventry in central England.

Sotheby's described the page as spotted, stained and ''folded with four pairs of
vertical slits for 'locking' the letter.'' A small tear marked where the
viscount had undone the queen's letterlocking.




URL:

A Trilogy Runs in Reverse, but Not Life

BYLINE: By GIA KOURLAS

SECTION: Section C; Column 0; The Arts/Cultural Desk; Pg. 4

LENGTH: 429 words


This week, the 2015 Crossing the Line festival hosts a trilogy by a celebrated
contemporary choreographer, which oddly works its way backward. The third
installment of Miguel Gutierrez's ''Age & Beauty,'' a series looking at the life
of an aging gay choreographer -- Mr. Gutierrez is 44 -- explores the emotional
toll that dance inflicts on the body and the mind.

While the first and second works will be shown later in the week, ''Age & Beauty
Part 3,'' performed at New York Live Arts on Wednesday, places a wistful, moody
cap on a triptych that began in 2014 at the Whitney Biennial. Personal, like all
of Mr. Gutierrez's works, this one also has reach. A co-commission by New York
Live Arts and the French Institute Alliance Française, Part 3 tempers Mr.
Gutierrez's midcareer anxiety in a subdued, almost hushed setting.

It also looks toward the future: What does a life spent making dances mean? Is
it time to quit? Judging by a line in a voiceover conversation between the
oldest and youngest cast members -- Ishmael Houston-Jones, 64, and Ezra Azrieli
Holzman, Mr. Gutierrez's 8-year-old godchild -- it seems improbable. Ezra,
perhaps Mr. Gutierrez's younger self, gets the last line: ''I love show
business. I'll go either way.'' It's from the Bob Fosse film ''All that Jazz.''
The exchange, marked by gesticulations but no live speaking, occurs while the
two performers are suspended in the air.

Ezra, an innocent in all black with a decent high kick and an aptitude for
stillness, is a highlight of the well-directed, multigenerational cast that also
includes Mr. Gutierrez -- cloud-like in white tulle -- Jen Rosenblit and Alex
Rodabaugh. They're dissimilar in age and body type, but what lingers is the
shared connection of dance.

Mr. Gutierrez's score evokes a dreamscape as the dancers run in counterclockwise
circles or extend their their arms loosely while stumbling to the floor. It's
intimate: The audience sits on the stage, surrounding the performance on four
sides, and the set, hinting at theatrical decay, features a pile of color
lighting gels, as well as deflated disco balls. Despite a scene in which the
cast frolics on the gels as if they were autumn leaves -- it's too much like
playtime -- there's an ancient and methodical drive to this affecting piece.
During a recorded loop of ''Do you worry about the future?'' the dancers glide
in and out of formations while lightly clapping their hands. It feels like
worship.

''Age & Beauty'' continues through Sept. 26 at New York Live Arts, Manhattan;
(212) 924-0077, newyorklivearts­.org.




URL:
http://www.nytimes.com/2015/09/18/arts/dance/review-miguel-gutierrezs-deep-quest
ions-in-age-beauty-part-3.html

GRAPHIC: PHOTO: Age & Beauty Part 3: Jen Rosenblit, left, Ishmael Houston-Jones,
Miguel Gutierrez and Erza Azrieli Holzman. (PHOTOGRAPH BY PIOTR REDLINSKI FOR
THE NEW YORK TIMES)

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

DOCUMENT-TYPE: Review

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

DANCERS (89%); DANCE (89%)

Meeting the Pope After a Fight for Better Pay

BYLINE: By JIM DWYER.

Email: dwyer@nytimes.com Twitter: @ jimdwyernyt

SECTION: Section A; Column 0; Metropolitan Desk; ABOUT NEW YORK; Pg. 23

LENGTH: 732 words


The modern carwash is a minor marvel. A car sits on a track and is pulled past
purifying machinery: A grid of pipes shoots high-pressure streams of water, then
soap; flapping, jiggling cloths lower from tracks to slather every inch of the
car body; spinning brushes rise along the sides, to begin the drying, and then a
wide vacuum rides just over the hood and roof to suck the water away.

It is the first robot most of us have ever met.

But at either end of the machine are people who do the dirty work that cannot be
left to robotics. At the front end, they pull open the doors, stoop to lift
floor mats that have taken on the leavings from shoes. They hand-vacuum cup
holders and the upholstery and all the seams where the cruft of other people's
lives and journeys has settled. At the back end, there are others waiting with
towels to dry and polish, and to clean the interiors of the windows.

''When I began, I think it was $3.65 an hour,'' said Patricio Santiago, 45, who
does detailing at a carwash in Flushing, Queens.

''Tres cincuenta,'' another worker called out, correcting him. That is, $3.50 an
hour, not $3.65.

The workers of the New York carwash operations are almost all men and immigrants
from Latin American countries or West Africa. In the winter months, when cars
quickly get filthy from slush, the work becomes most difficult, Mr. Santiago
said. ''The hardest is hand drying the cars when it is frigid cold,'' he said.

Mr. Santiago came to the United States from Oaxaca, Mexico, 14 years ago and has
worked at carwashes ever since. Improbably, a fight by Mr. Santiago and his
co-workers that began more than three years ago has led to union contracts at
nine carwashes in the city.

''The shifts are 12 hours,'' Mr. Santiago said. ''Before the contract, it was
seven days. Now it is six days.''

Workers at many carwashes have said there was no such thing as overtime; it was
as if neither the 40-hour workweek nor wage-and-hour laws had ever existed. Now,
Mr. Santiago said, he makes $8.65 an hour for the first 40 hours, and $11.36 for
overtime. He and his wife live in Elmhurst, Queens, and have two boys, ages 11
and 6, and a girl, age 2. Next week, Mr. Santiago and two other carwash workers,
Jose Reynaldo Sanches and Refugio Denicia, will be part of a group meeting Pope
Francis at Our Lady Queen of Angels School in East Harlem. The pope asked
specifically to meet with migrants and refugees, said Msgr. Kevin Sullivan, of
Catholic Charities.

So along with the carwashers, there will be Hudson Valley farmworkers,
day-laborers, immigrant mothers, and teenagers and children who have crossed the
border without their parents, many in desperate flights from violence in Central
America.

Mr. Santiago seemed abashed about his selection. ''I am happy and humble, but I
am representing the other workers,'' he said. ''I've seen the pope on
television. He's helped people and given a voice to working people and
immigrants.''

They may be symbols, but they are hardly props. Francis is far from the first
pope to have spoken about justice for the poor and the marginalized, though his
winning personal style has carried his words far beyond his own pews. Through
Catholic Charities, the infrastructure of the church in New York has long been
built on working with people who, broadly speaking, have no political or
economic power.

In the case of the carwashers -- they call themselves car washeros -- the role
of Catholic Charities was casual, Monsignor Sullivan said. The organizing effort
was led by the Retail, Wholesale and Department Store Union, in concert with
Make the Road New York and New York Communities for Change. ''The union
president, Stuart Appelbaum, asked if I would meet with the workers at a couple
of places in the Bronx,'' Monsignor Sullivan said. ''I talked to the workers,
expressed support for their efforts, and said a prayer for its success.''

Some of the church's principal guidance on the poor and forgotten is contained
in 53 words from the Gospel of Matthew. They are printed in the program for the
East Harlem gathering: ''For I was hungry and you gave me to eat,'' it begins,
listing acts of kindness to the thirsty, the naked, the sick the estranged and
the imprisoned. Matthew's account did not explicitly anticipate workers who put
in 80-hour workweeks helping robots to clean cars, but it looks like they're
covered.




URL:
http://www.nytimes.com/2015/09/18/nyregion/meeting-the-pope-after-a-fight-for-be
tter-pay.html

GRAPHIC: PHOTO: Patricio Santiago, at a Queens carwash Thursday, got higher
wages after a labor battle. He will be part of a group meeting with Pope Francis
next week. (PHOTOGRAPH BY ANDREW WHITE FOR THE NEW YORK TIMES)

Slaves and the Constitution

SECTION: Section A; Column 0; Editorial Desk; LETTER; Pg. 28

LENGTH: 259 words


To the Editor:

Prof. Sean Wilentz's essay arguing that the Constitution was not built on
slavery (''Lincoln and Douglass Had It Right,'' Op-Ed, Sept. 16) is profoundly
mistaken.

That the Southern delegates to the Constitutional Convention in Philadelphia
wanted more than they got doesn't matter, especially not to the millions of
slaves whose misery continued. What matters is the text of the Constitution as
ratified, which clearly and obviously sanctions slavery, in the three-fifths
clause and the fugitive slave clause.

The three-fifths clause was not, as Professor Wilentz argues, one of the
''consolation prizes'' for the slave states. By allowing Southern states to
count their slaves at all for purposes of representation, while denying those
slaves all other civil or human rights, the Constitution granted slave holders
magnified political power, while creating an incentive to acquire more slaves.

Professor Wilentz ignores (as many do) one of the most sinister aspects of the
three-fifths clause. Electoral votes are granted to states based on the number
of representatives in the House. Thus, the South had disproportionate power in
presidential elections as well.

Race-based slavery was this nation's original sin. We were born with it in our
charter. As Lincoln suggested, that sin could not be expurgated ''until every
drop of blood drawn with the lash shall be paid by another drawn with the
sword.''

PETER SAGAL

Chicago

The writer is host of ''Constitution USA With Peter Sagal'' on PBS and ''Wait,
Wait ... Don't Tell Me!'' on NPR.




URL: http://www.nytimes.com/2015/09/18/opinion/slaves-and-the-constitution.html

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

DOCUMENT-TYPE: Letter

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

SUBJECT: HUMAN RIGHTS VIOLATIONS (90%); SLAVERY (90%); LETTERS & COMMENTS (90%);
CONSTITUTIONAL LAW (78%); POLITICS (77%); ELECTIONS (74%); EDITORIALS & OPINIONS
(74%); CAMPAIGNS & ELECTIONS (73%); WRITERS (73%); VOTERS & VOTING (72%);
CONFERENCES & CONVENTIONS (72%); HEADS OF GOVERNMENT ELECTIONS (67%)

COMPANY: SA GUYOMARC'H ALIMENTAIRE (SAGAL) (54%)

A College's Value

SECTION: Section A; Column 0; Editorial Desk; LETTER; Pg. 28

LENGTH: 85 words


To the Editor:

Re ''Measuring a College's Value,'' by Frank Bruni (column, Sept. 13):

The single most important factor in any discussion of a college's value can be
summed up in one word: initiative.

Initiative is the unifying characteristic among students who seek out faculty
research mentors and enlist the support of alumni to help forge a pathway to the
work force. Initiative is the difference between complacency and ambition, and
ultimately mediocrity or meaningful success.

LINDSAY CHURA

Washington

Campaign Reform

SECTION: Section ; Column 0; Editorial Desk; LETTER; Pg.

LENGTH: 248 words


To the Editor:

Thomas B. Edsall is right to worry about the increasing influence of the
superrich on our elections (''Can Anything Be Done About All the Money in
Politics?,'' column, nytimes.com, Sept. 16). But his solution -- to let party
committees take unlimited contributions -- would be the wrong approach.

Lifting contribution limits entirely could make parties clones of super PACs,
top-down, unaccountable organizations controlled by megadonors and insider
consultants. That would negate the very qualities that make the parties
attractive as political actors.

Unlike outside groups fueled by unlimited donations, parties facilitate broad
participation in politics. They collect small donations from a vast number of
people and offer many opportunities for volunteers. And grass-roots activists
play a meaningful role in internal party governance.

In a new paper, we conclude that there are reforms worth considering, like
matching small donations with public funds and relaxing fund-raising
restrictions on state and local committees. These changes could strengthen the
aspects of parties that benefit our democracy, particularly their status as
engines of participation for ordinary citizens, without worsening the risk of
corruption.

DANIEL I. WEINER

IAN VANDEWALKER

New York

The writers are, respectively, senior counsel and counsel at the Brennan Center
for Justice at N.Y.U. School of Law and the authors of ''Stronger Parties,
Stronger Democracy: Rethinking Reform.''




URL: http://www.nytimes.com/2015/09/18/opinion/campaign-finance-reform.html

DOCUMENT-TYPE: Letter

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

FUNDRAISING (90%); LETTERS & COMMENTS (90%); WRITERS (78%); ASSOCIATIONS &
ORGANIZATIONS (77%); FUNDRAISING (76%); COMMUNITY ACTIVISM (74%); EDITORIALS &
OPINIONS (74%); VOLUNTEERS (69%)

Until Waves Us Do Part, Absurdity Will Suffice

BYLINE: By ALEXIS SOLOSKI

SECTION: Section C; Column 0; The Arts/Cultural Desk; Pg. 4

LENGTH: 359 words


If an existentialist philosopher ever attempted a light romantic comedy, it
might sound a little like ''Laugh It Up, Stare It Down,'' Alan Hruska's quaintly
absurdist play at the Cherry Lane Theater. An amiable, if surface-skimming
approach to love, marriage and all that sort of thing, it follows Joe (Jayce
Bartok) and Cleo (Katya Campbell) from first date to probable death after a
storm surge threatens to obliterate Rhode Island.

There's a lot of whimsy here -- a misplaced baby, a chatty home invader, a
restaurant that doesn't seem to serve food -- and it would grow more wearing if
not for the extravagant pace of Chris Eigeman's direction and the brisk
brightness of the performances. The dialogue seems mostly motivated by Mr.
Hruska's love of the quip rather than anything a real person might say or do.
But though credible characters aren't on offer, the four actors all comfortably
inhabit the same talky, lightly surreal world, and it's pleasant enough to
reside there with them for an hour and a half.

There are echoes here of Edward Albee, of course, and sometimes of his
inheritors, Will Eno or Dan LeFranc. But while Mr. Hruska occasionally gestures
toward weightier themes -- like, you know, death -- the central symbol is a
buoy, not an anchor. The tough stuff is steamrollered and sidelined by energetic
repartee. That repartee is often quite good, though perhaps not worth quoting.
Enjoyment is in the delivery and in the way short and longer sentences chase
each other down through the scenes.

This keeps the play afloat until an abrupt and puzzling ending, when a long
promised hurricane finally materializes and snatches away a command of tone for
both Mr. Hruska and Mr. Eigeman. Joe and Cleo clutch their buoy and try to
maintain that same snappy back-and-forth even as they're starving, freezing and
exhausted.

Ain't life strange? they ask. And often grand? And at the moment, uncomfortably
damp?

''Laugh It Up, Stare It Down'' continues through Oct. 10 at the Cherry Lane
Theater, West Village; 866-811-4111, laughitupplay.com.

This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in
print.




URL:
http://www.nytimes.com/2015/09/11/theater/review-laugh-it-up-stare-it-down-on-lo
ve-and-marriage.html

DOCUMENT-TYPE: Review

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

STARVATION (76%); RESTAURANTS (70%)

LENGTH: 221 words


WONHAM--Ann Brunie, of Vero Beach, Florida, and formerly Stamford, Connecticut,
died peacefully in the Adirondacks on September 14, of complications from
Parkinson's Disease. An avid bridge player and teacher, tennis and paddle tennis
player, and a low handicap golfer, she brought, fun, laughter, and a love of
competition and of friends, whom she adored, to every game and match she played.

Ann grew up in New York City, graduated from the Brearley School in 1950, and
was a member of the class of 1954 of Smith College. She was a former president
of the Women's Westchester and Fairfield County Golf Association, and a member
of the board of the Fresh Air Fund of New York for a number of years. She is
survived by her devoted husband of 62 years, Frederick S. Wonham, her daughter
Stapley Emberling (David) of Weston, Connecticut, her son Henry B. Wonham.
(Connie) of Eugene, OR, and her younger son Lincoln Wonham of Lake Forest, IL,
as well as her sister Susan Hughes of Vero Beach (Ed) and formerly Greenwich,
Connecticut, and her half-brother Charles (Rex) Hubbard (Libby) of Huntington,
L.I. She also leaves seven dearly loved grandchildren: Anna Emory Wonham, Henry
Grant and Walker Lincoln Wonham, Ryan and Rachel Emberling, and Jack and Cal
Wonham. With Annie at every step since 1998, her beloved Tiger lives on. 1/3

Paid Notice: Deaths RIOS, SARA ELENA

SECTION: Section B; Column 0; Classified; Pg. 15

LENGTH: 215 words


RIOS--Sara Elena, passed away peacefully at her home in Toledo, Ohio on
Thursday, September 10, 2015, surrounded by her loving family. She was born
October 31, 1952 in Toledo, Ohio to Sara (Vasquez) and Martin Rios. Sara's
career history included: Vice President of the Farm Labor Organizing Committee;
Senior Attorney and Interim Executive Director of the Center for Constitutional
Rights; Executive Director of the National Employment Law Project; Director of
Litigation at the Puerto Rican Legal Defense and Education Fund; and Director of
the Human Rights, Peace and Social Justice unit at the Ford Foundation. Sara
retired unexpectedly from her position as President of the Ruth Mott Foundation
in Flint, MI in November 2013 due to ALS against which she waged a valiant
battle. Sara dedicated her life to peace and social justice causes, and equality
for all. Her philanthropic work took her across the U.S. and around the world.
She is survived by her parents, seven siblings, six nephews and nieces, and many
dear friends. In lieu of flowers, please consider making a donation in Sara's
memory to the following organizations: Farm Labor Organizing Committee,
www.floc.com; and or, ALS Association, www.alsa.org/research/. Online
condolences may be offered at: reebfuneralhome.com 1/3

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

Paid Notice: Deaths REINIG, WILLIAM CHARLES

SECTION: Section B; Column 0; Classified; Pg. 15

LENGTH: 310 words


REINIG--William Charles, 91, died on August 25, 2015, in Annapolis, MD. A
graduate of Polytechnic Institute of Brooklyn, Reinig was the leader of the
radiation protection program for the first peacetime nuclear reactor at
Brookhaven National Laboratory. He subsequently led the research team that
performed the preoperational survey of the Savannah River Site near Aiken, SC,
the first large-scale assay of naturally occurring radioactivity.

He later served as Superintendent of Health Physics and Deputy General Manager
at SRS. He was a fellow and President of the Health Physics Society, Chairman of
the American Board of Health Physics, and served on the NCRP. He enjoyed
gardening, watching movies and reading The New York Times. He maintained an
out-of-town subscription to the Times for 64 years. After retirement, he wrote a
remarkably detailed memoir about growing up in Queens describing the smallest
details of daily life including the daily meals, how Mayor La Guardia read the
Sunday comic pages of the New York papers over the radio in the 1930s during a
newspaper distribution strike, the presence of a speech teacher at PS 108 who
attempted to correct the Brooklyn accents of many of the students, including
Bill, and watching Memorial Day parades down Rockaway Blvd led by Civil War
Veterans followed by Spanish-American War Vets wearing Teddy Roosevelt hats and
World War I Vets marching behind. He greatly enjoyed movies for the simple
pleasure of watching, a habit begun in the movie theaters of Queens during the
Depression. Bill was a survivor of the 1950 LIRR crash in Rockville Center. In
1949, he married Marion Borgstrom whom he met at Brookhaven. She died in 2007.
He is survived by Dr. James Reinig (Ellen) of Annapolis, Dr. Christine Reinig of
Santa Fe, NM, and grandchildren Margaret and Ann Reinig and Dennis and Alice
Flournoy. 1/3

Paid Notice: Deaths NOBLE, WILLIAM L

SECTION: Section B; Column 0; Classified; Pg. 15

LENGTH: 109 words


NOBLE--William L. August 22, 1932 - September 15, 2015. Resident of New York
City and Wainscott, NY. Graduate of The Lawrenceville School and Columbia
University. Served honorably in The Marine Corps during the Korean War.
Life-long member of The Blue Hill Troupe and Squadron A Association. He is
survived by his wife, Jennifer; children, Nick, Maggie, Kate and Polly;
stepchildren, Roxanne and Jared; and grandsons, Jonathan, Owen and Graham. Bill
was a friend to all and will be remembered fondly as the Mayor of East 68th
Street. Service will be held at The Brick Presbyterian Church at 91st Street and
Park Avenue, Monday, September 21 at 11:00am. 1/3

Paid Notice: Deaths GROSS, MARTIN M.

SECTION: Section B; Column 0; Classified; Pg. 15

LENGTH: 89 words


GROSS--Martin M.,aged 98, passed peacefully September 14th. Predeceased by his
loved wives Florence (died 1995), Irene (died 2002) and Rosalyn (died 2014).
Proud WWII Veteran who received The Purple Heart, Bronze Star, and French Croix
de Guerre. Beloved father of Janet (Bill) Schnall, Barbara (Richard) Weinberg,
and Andrew (Linda Koenig) Gross. Grandfather of Lisa, Laura, Amy, Matthew
(Arielle Gordon), and Benjamin. Great- grandfather to Sophia. Services on
Friday, 12:45pm at "The Riverside" on Amsterdam Ave. and West 76th St. 1/3

Paid Notice: Deaths GREENE, ETHAN FREDERICK, D.M.A.

SECTION: Section B; Column 0; Classified; Pg. 15

LENGTH: 124 words


GREENE--Ethan Frederick, D.M.A.,University of Texas (2013), and graduate of
Columbia High School, South Orange, NJ, Amherst College (2004), and Rice
University (2010), passed away September 13, 2015 at age 32. A brilliant and
prolific composer in diverse musical genres, he is survived by loving wife, Alma
Lagarda, 18-month old son Mateo, parents, Peter and Rebecca, and brother
Abraham. Ethan was an Assistant Professor of Digital Arts at Stetson University
in DeLand, FL. Services will take place September 18, 2015, 10:00am at Menorah
Chapels at Millburn, 2950 Vauxhall Road, Vauxhall (Union), NJ 07088. In lieu of
flowers, contributions may be made in memory of Ethan Frederick Greene to
Anthropos Arts at:

https://anthroposarts.org/efg/ 1/3

Paid Notice: Deaths BROZINSKY, HILDA

SECTION: Section B; Column 0; Classified; Pg. 15

LENGTH: 80 words


BROZINSKY--Hilda, 97. Devoted daughter of Hymie and Anna Needell. Beloved wife
of the late Nathan and loving mother to Michael (Susan) and Steven (Roseann).
Adoring grandmother of Shari, Craig, Amanda and Noah. Big sister to the late
Burton, Melvin and to Martin. Wonderful aunt to countless nieces and nephews.
Mouthwatering mandel bread and strudel were her specialties. Green- thumbed
gardener. Truly the "hostess with the mostess." For information: jewish-
funeral-home.com 1/3

Paid Notice: Deaths BRENER, JACOB L.

SECTION: Section B; Column 0; Classified; Pg. 15

LENGTH: 130 words


BRENER--Jacob L.,M.D. Passed away on September 8th. Beloved husband of Goldie.
Cherished father of Michelle (Yitzchak) Teitelbaum, Judy (Marty) Grumet and
Stanley Brener. Adored grandfather of Yonina, Jonathan (Basya) and Naava
Teitelbaum; Avi (Leah), Alexandra, and Duvi Grumet. Proud great-grandfather of
Noa Hadar Grumet. Devoted brother of Rabbi Pynchas Brener and the late Rabbi
Mark Brener. Dr. Brener was a physician whose dedication to his patients was
unparalleled. A Professor of Medicine at New York Medical College for over fifty
years, he was a well-respected teacher and clinician. Dr. Brener was steadfast
in his commitment to his family, his faith and his profession. Donations in his
memory may be made to American Friends of Magen David Adom or Chai Lifeline. 1/3

Paid Notice: Deaths BELSON, JEROME

SECTION: Section B; Column 0; Classified; Pg. 15

LENGTH: 106 words


BELSON--Jerome, passed away peacefully on Thursday morning September 17th
surrounded by his family. He was predeceased by his beloved wife Maxine and son
Michael (Kathy). He is survived by his son Tad, daughter Brianne (Sanford),
brother Victor and grandchildren Matthew (Jodi), Joshua (Katy), Jaclyn, Toby and
Jonathan, and great grandchildren Noah, Ariel, and Paisley. The funeral will be
held Sunday, September 20th at 12pm at Community Synagogue of Rye, 200 Forest
Ave, Rye, NY. He will be missed by those who knew him best for his larger than
life personality. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to New Hope
Community, Inc. 1/3
